916365_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States and is focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	We operate retail stores under the names Tractor Supply Company and Del s Farm Supply and operate a website under the name TractorSupply.com .
916365_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	Our stores are located in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities, and they offer the following comprehensive selection of merchandise:
916365_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Tractor Supply stores typically range in size from 15,500 to 18,500 square feet of inside selling space and additional outside selling space.
916365_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	We use a standard 15,500 square foot prototype for most new purpose-built locations.
916365_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	For new stores located in existing buildings, one of several layout formats is utilized.
916365_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our wholly-owned subsidiary, Del s Farm Supply, LLC ( Del s ), operated 26 stores as of December 25, 2010 in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Hawaii.
916365_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	Del s stores currently range in size from approximately 2,000 to 6,000 square feet of inside selling space plus additional outside and covered/sheltered selling space.
916365_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Tractor Supply Company has one reportable industry segment farm and ranch retail sales, both at our retail locations and online.
916365_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	At December 25, 2010, we operated 1,001 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states.
916365_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	Historically, our sales and profits have been the highest in the second and fourth fiscal quarters due to the sale of seasonal products.
916365_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	Unseasonable weather, excessive precipitation, drought, and early or late frosts may also affect our sales.
916365_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	We believe, however, that the impact of extreme weather conditions is somewhat mitigated by the geographic dispersion of our stores.
916365_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	We experience our highest inventory and accounts payable balances during the first fiscal quarter for purchases of seasonal products in anticipation of the spring selling season and again during the third fiscal quarter in anticipation of the winter selling season.
916365_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	We believe our sales and earnings growth is a result of executing our business strategy, which includes the following key components:
916365_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	We have identified a specialized market niche: supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle (which we refer to as the Out Here lifestyle), as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	By focusing our product mix on these core customers, we believe we are differentiated from general merchandise, home center and other specialty retailers.
916365_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	We are committed to providing our customers a high level of in-store service through our motivated, well-trained store team members.
916365_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	We believe the ability of our store team members to provide friendly, responsive and seasoned advice helps to promote strong customer loyalty and repeat shopping.
916365_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	As such, we seek to provide our store team members with decision-making authority, product knowledge and training to enable them to meet our customers needs.
916365_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	We endeavor to staff our stores with courteous, highly motivated team members and devote considerable resources to training store team members, often in cooperation with our vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our training programs include (i) a full management training program which covers all aspects of our operations, (ii) product knowledge modules produced in conjunction with key vendors, (iii) frequent management skills training classes, (iv) semi-annual store manager meetings with vendor product presentations, (v) vendor sponsored in-store training programs and (vi) ongoing product information updates from our management headquarters, the Store Support Center.
916365_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	We seek to hire and train store team members with farming and ranching backgrounds, with particular emphasis on general maintenance, equine and welding.
916365_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	Our online shopping site is TractorSupply.com .
916365_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	The availability of certain of our products online provides our customers the ability to purchase products and have them shipped to one of our retail stores, their homes or offices.
916365_11_ITEM1_P12_S2	We believe this capability further enhances customer service and extends our market to areas where our retail stores are not currently located.
916365_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	We offer proprietary, private label credit cards for individuals and business customers.
916365_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	In addition, we accept cash, checks, debit cards, Visa, MasterCard, American Express and Discover credit cards and gift cards.
916365_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our stores are designed and managed to make shopping an enjoyable experience and to maximize sales and operating efficiencies.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	Stores utilize several layouts, designed to provide an open environment, optimal product placement and visual display locations.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	In addition, these layouts allow for departmental space to be easily reallocated and visual displays to be easily changed for seasonal products and promotions.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	Display and product placement information is sent to stores weekly to ensure quality and uniformity among the stores.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S3	Informative signs are located throughout each store to assist customers with purchasing decisions and merchandise location.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S4	These signs provide customers with a comparison of product qualities, clear pricing and useful information regarding product benefits and suggestions for appropriate accessories.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S5	The general uniformity of our store layouts and visual displays afford our customers a feeling of familiarity and enhances the shopping experience.
916365_11_ITEM1_P15_S6	To further enhance the shopping experience, all of our store team members wear highly visible red vests, aprons or smocks and nametags, and our customer service and checkout counters are conveniently located.
916365_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	We offer a differentiated assortment of products for our customers.
916365_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our broad product assortment is tailored to meet the regional and geographic needs of our markets, as well as the physical store size.
916365_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	Our full line of product offerings is supported by a strong in-stock inventory position with an average of 15,500 to 19,000 unique products per store.
916365_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	No one product accounted for more than 10% of our sales during 2010.
916365_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	Our stores carry a wide selection of high quality, nationally recognized, name brand merchandise.
916365_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	We also market a growing list of products under our private-label programs, i.e. products manufactured for us by a number of vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	The trademarks in the private label brand names are owned by us.
916365_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	We believe that the availability of high quality private label products at compelling prices provides superior value for our customers, a strategic advantage for us, and positions us as a destination store.
916365_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	The following chart indicates the average percentages of sales represented by each of our major product categories during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008.
916365_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	We offer a differentiated assortment of products that are sourced through domestic and international vendors for those seeking to enjoy the Out Here lifestyle.
916365_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	Our business is not dependent upon any one vendor or particular group of vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	We purchase our products from a core group of approximately 700 vendors, with no one vendor representing more than 10% of our purchases during fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM1_P21_S3	Approximately 250 vendors accounted for approximately 90% of our purchases during fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	We have not experienced any significant difficulty in obtaining satisfactory alternative sources of supply for our products, and we believe that adequate sources of supply exist at substantially similar costs for nearly all of our produc ts.
916365_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	We have no material long-term contractual commitments with any of our vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	We maintain a dedicated inventory management team to focus exclusively on all forecasting and replenishment functions.
916365_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	This centralized direction permits our buying teams to focus more strategic attention toward vendor line reviews, assortment planning and testing of new products and programs.
916365_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	Through the combined efforts of these teams, we have improved our overall inventory productivity and in-stock position.
916365_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Over 98% of our purchase orders are transmitted through an electronic data interchange ("EDI") system, and approximately 95% of merchandise vendor invoices are transmitted through EDI.
916365_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	We are expanding the percentage of vendors who electronically transmit invoices and increasing the amount of sales history transmitted.
916365_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	We currently operate a distribution network for supplying our stores with merchandise, and in fiscal 2010 our stores received approximately 67% of our merchandise through this network.
916365_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	Our six distribution centers are located in Indiana, Georgia, Maryland, Texas, Nebraska, and Washington, representing total distribution capacity of 2.9 million square feet.
916365_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	In 2011 we have begun construction on our seventh distribution center, a new 834,000 square foot facility in Kentucky to be operational during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
916365_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	We manage our inbound and outbound transportation activity in-house through the use of a web-based transportation management system.
916365_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	We utilize several common carriers for store deliveries.
916365_11_ITEM1_P26_S2	We manage our transportation costs through carrier negotiations, the monitoring of transportation routes, and the scheduling of deliveries.
916365_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	We utilize an "everyday value prices" strategy to consistently offer our products at competitive prices complemented by promotions primarily implemented during peak selling seasons.
916365_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	We regularly monitor prices at competing stores and adjust our prices as appropriate.
916365_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	To generate store traffic and position ourselves as a destination store, we promote broad selections of merchandise with newspaper circulars, customer targeted direct mail and internet offerings.
916365_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	Vendors frequently support these specific programs by offering temporary cost reductions, honoring coupons and funding gift card rebate programs.
916365_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Due to the relatively small size of our stores, increased traffic in the store ensures increased exposure to our products.
916365_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	Our vendors are committed to helping us promote our brand and position ourselves as a destination store.
916365_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	Our vendors provide assistance with product presentation and rack design, brochures, point-of-purchase materials for customers education and product education for our team members.
916365_11_ITEM1_P29_S3	We also receive funding through contributions and incentives on purchases to promote new stores and earn rebates from vendors on product purchases based on volume.
916365_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	We operate in a competitive retail industry.
916365_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	The principal competitive factors include location of stores, price and quality of merchandise, in-stock consistency, merchandise assortment and presentation, and customer service.
916365_11_ITEM1_P30_S2	We compete with general merchandise retailers, home center retailers and other specialty and discount retailers, as well as independently owned retail farm and ranch stores, numerous privately-held regional farm store chains and farm cooperatives.
916365_11_ITEM1_P30_S3	Some of these competitors are units of national or regional chains and may have substantially greater resources and financial capacities than we do.
916365_11_ITEM1_P30_S4	However, we believe we have successfully differentiated ourselves from these entities by focusing on our specialized market niche for customers living the rural lifestyle.
916365_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	As of December 25, 2010, we employed approximately 7,900 full-time and approximately 6,800 part-time team members.
916365_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	We also employ additional part-time team members during peak periods.
916365_11_ITEM1_P31_S2	We are not party to any collective bargaining agreements.
916365_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our store operations are organized into nine regions, including Del s.
916365_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	Each region is led by a regional manager and the region is further organized into districts, which are led by a district manager or area manager.
916365_11_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our regional managers, district managers, area managers, store managers and other distribution and support personnel have contributed significantly to our performance.
916365_11_ITEM1_P32_S3	We have internal advisory boards, one comprised of store managers and the other comprised of district managers.
916365_11_ITEM1_P32_S4	These groups bring a grassroots perspective to operational initiatives and generate chain-wide endorsement of proposed best-practice solutions.
916365_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	We are committed to a continuous improvement program called Tractor Value System ( TVS ).
916365_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	TVS is a business management system that emphasizes, through team member engagement, a focus on continuous improvement.
916365_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	Utilizing the TVS system, we improve processes by embracing change of current practices to reduce cost, shorten lead times, and drive innovation.
916365_11_ITEM1_P33_S3	We have implemented numerous continuous improvement project teams (comprised of team members from all areas of our operations) to evaluate key operations and implement process changes that will improve efficiency, reduce costs and strengthen processes.
916365_11_ITEM1_P33_S4	Our management encourages the participation of all team members in decision-making, regularly solicits input and suggestions from our team members and incorporates suggestions into our improv ement activities.
916365_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	All of our team members participate in one of various incentive programs, which provide the opportunity to receive additional compensation based upon team and/or Company performance.
916365_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	We also provide our team members the opportunity to participate in an employee stock purchase plan and a 401(k) retirement savings plan (we contribute to the 401(k) savings plan solely through a cash match).
916365_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	Additionally, we share in the cost of health insurance provided to our team members, and team members receive a discount on merchandise purchased at our stores.
916365_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	We encourage a promote from within environment when internal resources permit.
916365_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	We also provide internal leadership development programs designed to mentor our high potential team members for continued progress and believe we have satisfactory relationships with our team members.
916365_11_ITEM1_P35_S2	Our district managers, area managers, and store managers have an average length of service of approximately five years.
916365_11_ITEM1_P35_S3	Management believes internal promotions, coupled with the hiring of individuals with previous retail experience, will provide the management structure necessary to support our planned store growth.
916365_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	We have invested considerable resources in our management information and control systems to ensure superior customer service, manage the purchase and distribution of our merchandise and improve our operating efficiencies.
916365_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	Our management information and control systems include a point-of-sale system, a supply chain management and replenishment system, a radio frequency and voice picking system in the distribution centers, a vendor purchase order control system and a merchandise presentation system.
916365_11_ITEM1_P36_S2	These systems are integrated through an enterprise resource planning ( ERP ) system.
916365_11_ITEM1_P36_S3	This ERP system tracks merchandise from initial order through ultimate sale and interfaces with our financial systems.
916365_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	We continue to evaluate and improve the functionality of our systems to maximize their effectiveness.
916365_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	Such efforts include ongoing hardware and software evaluations and upgrades to support optimal software configurations and application performance.
916365_11_ITEM1_P37_S2	We plan to upgrade our information technology and implement other efficiency-driving system enhancements (including the rollout of a new warehouse management system to distribution centers, implementation of price optimization software, point-of-sale system upgrades, and store and support center hardware refreshes) in 2011.
916365_11_ITEM1_P37_S3	In addition, we will continue to strengthen the security of our information systems and support the areas of store and distribution center expansion.
916365_11_ITEM1_P37_S4	These efforts are directed toward constantly improving the overall business processes and achieving the most efficient and effective use of the systems to manage our operations while ensuring a secure and reliable environment.
916365_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Our current and long-term growth strategy is to: (1) expand geographic market presence through opening new retail stores, (2) enhance financial performance through same-store sales increases, achieved through targeted merchandising programs with an everyday value prices philosophy and supported by strong customer service, (3) enhance product margin through assortment management, vendor management, global sourcing, and optimization of transportation and distribution costs, (4) leverage operating costs, especially advertising, distribution and corporate overhead, (5) expand market opportunities via internet sales, and (6) expand through selective acquisition, as such opportunities arise, to enhance penetration into new and existing markets as a complementary strategy to organic growth.
916365_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	We have experienced considerable sales growth over the past five years, with a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 12.0%.
916365_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	We project an increase of 80 to 85 new stores in 2011, an increase of approximately 8%.
916365_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	We opened 74 new stores in 2010 and 76 new stores in 2009, an increase of approximately 8% and 9%, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	We operated 1,001 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states as of December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified over 800 potential additional markets for new Tractor Supply stores in the United States.
916365_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Pursuant to General Instruction G(3) of Form 10-K, the following list is included as an unnumbered item in Part I of this Report in lieu of being included in the Proxy Statement for the Annual Meeting of Stockholders to be held on April 28, 2011.
916365_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	The following is a list of the names and ages of all executive officers of the registrant, indicating all positions and offices with the registrant held by each such person and each person s principal occupations and employment during at least the past five years:
916365_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	James F. Wright has served as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of the Company since February 2009, and prior to that time served as Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer from November 2007 to February 2009, and as President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company from October 2004 to November 2007.
916365_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	Mr. Wright previously served as President and Chief Operating Officer of the Company from October 2000 to October 2004.
916365_11_ITEM1_P43_S2	Mr. Wright has served as a director of the Company since 2002.
916365_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Gregory A. Sandfort has served as President and Chief Merchandising Officer of the Company since February 2009, and prior to that time served as Executive Vice President-Chief Merchandising Officer of the Company since November 2007.
916365_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Mr. Sandfort previously served as President and Chief Operating Officer at Michaels Stores, Inc. from March 2006 to August 2007 and as Vice President General Merchandise Manager at Michaels Stores, Inc. from January 2004 to February 2006.
916365_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	Mr. Sandfort served as Vice Chairman and Co-Chief Executive Officer of Kleinert s Inc. (d/b/a Buster Brown) from 2002 to 2003 and as a Vice President, General Merchandise Manager for Sears, Roebuck and Co. from 1998 to 2002.
916365_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	Stanley L. Ruta has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of the Company since February 2009, and prior to that time served as Executive Vice President-Store Operations since January 2007, after having served as Senior Vice President-Store Operations since June 2000 and as Vice President-Store Operations of the Company since 1994.
916365_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	Anthony F. Crudele has served as Executive Vice President-Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer since January 2007, after having served as Senior Vice President-Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer of the Company since November 2005.
916365_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	Mr. Crudele previously served as Chief Financial Officer at Gibson Guitar from August 2003 to September 2005, as Chief Financial Officer of Xcelerate Corp. from 2000 to January 2003, and at The Sports Authority from 1989 through 1999 (serving as Chief Financial Officer from 1996 through 1999).
916365_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	Kimberly D. Vella has served as Senior Vice President and Chief People Officer since July 2010, and prior to that time served as Senior Vice President-Human Resources of the Company since January 2007, after having served as Vice President-Human Resources of the Company since October 2001.
916365_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	We file reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), including Annual Reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and other reports as required.
916365_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	The public may read and copy any materials the Company files with the SEC at the SEC s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549.
916365_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
916365_11_ITEM1_P48_S3	We are an electronic filer and the SEC maintains an Internet site at sec.gov that contains the reports, proxy and information statements, and other information filed electronically.
916365_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	We make available free of charge through our Internet website, TractorSupply.com , our Annual Report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and all amendments to those reports as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.
916365_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	The information provided on our website is not part of this report, and is therefore not incorporated by reference unless such information is otherwise specifically referenced elsewhere in this report.
916365_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	Our code of ethics, which is applicable to all of our team members, including our Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer and Controller, along with our Corporate Governance Guidelines and the charters of our Audit, Compensation, Nominating and Corporate Governance Committees of our Board of Directors, is posted on our website.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Those risks which we are currently aware and we deem to be material are described below.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the events or circumstances described in the following risk factors occur, our business, financial condition or results of operations may significantly suffer, and the trading price of our common stock could decline.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	These risk factors should be read in conjunction with the other information in this Form 10-K.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	General economic conditions may adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our results of operations may be sensitive to changes in overall economic conditions that impact consumer spending, including discretionary spending.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Economic conditions affecting disposable consumer income such as employment levels, business conditions, interest rates, tax rates, fuel and energy costs, higher labor and healthcare costs, the impact of natural disasters or acts of terrorism, and other matters could reduce consumer spending or cause consumers to shift their spending to lower-priced competitors.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	A general reduction in the level of discretionary spending or shifts in consumer discretionary spending to our competitors could adversely affect our growth and profitability.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Additionally, changes in the mix of products sold to a mix with a lower overall gross margin or other increased cost of sales, along with slower inventory turnover and greater markdowns on inventory, could adversely affect our operations and operating results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Purchase price volatility, including inflationary and deflationary pressures, may adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Although we cannot determine the full effect of inflation and deflation on our operations, we believe our sales and results of operations are affected by both.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We are subject to market risk with respect to the pricing of certain products and services, which include, among other items, steel, grain, petroleum, corn, soybean and other commodities as well as transportation services.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Therefore, we may experience both inflationary and deflationary pressure on product cost, which may impact consumer demand and, as a result, sales and gross margin.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Our strategy is to reduce or mitigate the effects of purchase price volatility principally by taking advantage of vendor incentive programs, economies of scale from increased volume of purchases, adjusting retail prices and selectively buying from the most competiti ve vendors without sacrificing quality.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Due to the competitive environment, such conditions have and may continue to adversely impact our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	There is no assurance that we will be able to continue to increase sales at our existing stores.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We experience fluctuations in our same-store sales, which are defined as stores which have completed twelve months of sales.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Our success depends, in part, upon our ability to improve sales at our existing stores.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Various factors affect same-store sales, including the general retail sales environment, our ability to efficiently source and distribute products, changes in our merchandise mix, competition, current economic conditions, the timing of release of new merchandise and promotional events, the success of marketing programs and weather conditions.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P7_S3	These factors may cause our same-store sales results to differ materially from prior periods and from expectations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P7_S4	Past same-store sales are not necessarily an indication of future results, and there can be no assurance that our same-store sale s will not decrease in the future.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Even if we are able to implement, to a significant degree, our key business strategy of expanding our store base, we may experience managerial or operational problems, which may prevent any expected increase in profitability or negatively impact our cash flow.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	To manage our planned expansion, we must ensure the continuing adequacy of our existing systems, controls and procedures, including product distribution facilities, store management, financial controls and information systems.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	There can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve our planned expansion, that the new stores will be effectively integrated into our existing operations or that such stores will be profitable.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Capital requirements for growth may not be available.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The construction and opening or acquisition of new stores and the development of new production and distribution facilities, along with the remodeling and renovation of existing stores, require significant amounts of capital.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In the past, our growth has been funded primarily through bank borrowings and internally generated cash flow.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Disruptions in the capital and credit markets could adversely affect the ability of the banks to meet their commitments.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our access to funds under the credit facility is dependent on the ability of the banks that are parties to the facility to meet their funding commitments.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Those banks may not be able to meet their funding commitments to us if they experience shortages of capital and liquidity or if they experience excessive volumes of borrowing requests within a short period of time.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	In addition, tighter lending practices have made it more challenging for our real estate developers to obtain financing under reasonable loan terms and conditions.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Unfavorable lending trends could impact the timing of our store openings and materially adversely affect our ability to open new purpose-built store s in desirable locations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Longer term disruptions in the capital and credit markets as a result of uncertainty, changing or increased regulation, reduced alternatives, or failures of significant financial institutions could adversely affect our access to liquidity needed for our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Any disruption could require us to take measures to conserve cash until the markets stabilize or until alternative credit arrangements or other funding for our business needs can be arranged.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Such measures could include deferring capital expenditures, and reducing or eliminating future share repurchases or other discretionary uses of cash.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Failure to open new stores in the manner currently contemplated could adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	An integral part of our business strategy includes the expansion of our base of stores by opening new stores.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	This expansion strategy is dependent on our ability to find suitable locations, and we face competition from many retailers for such sites.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P15_S2	If we are unable to implement this strategy, our ability to increase our sales, profitability, and cash flow could be impaired significantly.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P15_S3	To the extent that we are unable to open new stores in the manner we anticipate (due to, among other reasons, site approval or unforeseen delays in construction), our sales growth may be impeded.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	New stores may negatively impact our results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	There can be no assurance that our new store openings will be successful or result in greater sales and profitability for the Company.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	New stores build their sales volumes and refine their merchandise selection over time and, as a result, generally have lower gross margins and higher operating expenses as a percentage of sales than our more mature stores.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	As we continue to open new stores, there may be a negative impact on our results from a lower contribution margin of these new stores until their sales levels ramp to chain average, if at all, as well as from the impact of related pre-opening costs.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Competition in our industry may hinder our ability to execute our business strategy and adversely affect our operations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We operate in a very competitive market.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The principal competitive factors include location of stores, price and quality of merchandise, in-stock consistency, merchandise assortment and presentation, and customer service.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	We believe we have successfully differentiated ourselves from general merchandise retailers, home center retailers and other specialty and discount retailers by focusing on our specialized market niche.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P19_S3	However, we do face competition from these entities, as well as competition from independently-owned retail farm and ranch stores, privately-held regional farm store chains and farm cooperatives.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Some of our competitors are units of national or regional chains that have substantially greater financial and other resources.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Weather conditions may have a significant impact on our financial results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Historically, weather conditions have had a significant impact on our operating results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Weather conditions affect the demand for, and in some cases the supply of, products, which in turn has an impact on prices.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	In past years, we have experienced extreme weather conditions, including snow and ice storms, flood and wind damage, hurricanes, tornadoes and droughts in some states.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P21_S3	Weather conditions also directly affect the demand for seasonal products, particularly during the winter heating season.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Accordingly, the weather can have a material effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	There are certain risks associated with the seasonal nature of our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our working capital needs and borrowings (if necessary) generally peak in our first and third fiscal quarters because lower sales are generated while expenses are incurred and inventory is increased in preparation for the spring and winter selling seasons.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	If cash on hand and borrowings under existing credit facilities are insufficient to meet the seasonal needs or if cash flow generated during the spring and winter is insufficient to repay associated borrowings on a timely basis, this seasonality could have a material adverse effect on our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	There is no assurance that our merchandising initiatives and marketing emphasis will provide expected results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	We believe our past performance has been based on, and future success will depend upon, in part, the ability to develop and execute merchandising initiatives with effective marketing.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	There is no assurance that we will be successful, or that new initiatives will be executed in a timely manner to satisfy our customers needs or expectations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Failure to execute and promote such initiatives in a timely manner could harm our ability to grow the business and could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S3	Additionally, our success depends on our ability to anticipate and respond in a timely manner to changing customer demand and preferences for merchandise.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S4	If we misjudge the market, we may significantly overstock unpopular products and be forced to take significant inventory markdowns.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P25_S5	Shortages of key items could also have a materially adverse impact on operating results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We face risks associated with vendors from whom our products are sourced.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The products we sell are sourced from a variety of domestic and international vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	As a general rule, we have agreements with our vendors in which the vendors agree to comply with applicable laws, including labor and environmental laws, and to indemnify us against certain liabilities and costs.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Our ability to recover liabilities and costs under these vendor agreements is dependent upon the financial condition and integrity of the vendors.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We rely on foreign manufacturers for various products that we sell.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	In addition, many of our domestic suppliers purchase a portion of their products from foreign sources.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	We rely on long-term relationships with our suppliers but have no long-term contracts with such suppliers.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Our future success will depend in large measure upon our ability to maintain our existing supplier relationships or to develop new ones.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S4	This reliance increases the risk of inadequate and untimely supplies of various products due to local political, economic, social, or environmental conditions, transportation delays, restrictive actions by foreign governments, or changes in United States laws and regulations affecting imports or domestic distribution.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Our vendors may be forced to reduce their production, shu t down their operations or file for bankruptcy protection, which in some cases would make it difficult for us to serve the market s needs and could have a material adverse effect on our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	As an importer, our business is subject to the risks generally associated with doing business abroad, such as foreign governmental regulations, economic disruptions, delays in shipments, transportation capacity and costs, currency exchange rates and changes in political or economic conditions in countries from which we purchase products.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	If any such factors were to render the conduct of business in particular countries undesirable or impractical or if additional United States quotas, duties, taxes or other charges or restrictions were imposed upon the importation of our products in the future, our financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Our failure to attract and retain qualified team members could adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our ability to continue expanding operations depends on our ability to attract and retain a large and growing number of qualified team members.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Our ability to meet labor needs while controlling wage and related labor costs is subject to numerous external factors, including the availability of a sufficient number of qualified persons in the work force, unemployment levels, prevailing wage rates, changing demographics, health and other insurance costs and changes in employment legislation.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P31_S2	If we are unable to locate, attract or retain qualified personnel, or if costs of labor or related costs increase significantly, our financial performance could be adversely affected.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We may be subject to product liability and other claims in the ordinary course of business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our business involves a risk of product liability and other claims in the ordinary course of business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We maintain general liability insurance with a deductible for each occurrence and a $36,000,000 aggregate retention applicable to all general liability and workers compensation claims.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P33_S2	We also maintain umbrella limits above the primary general liability and product liability cover.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	In many cases, we have indemnification rights against the manufacturers of the products and their products liability insurance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Our ability to recover under such insurance or indemnification arrangements is subject to the financial viability of the insurers and manufacturers and the specific allegations of a claim.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P34_S2	No assurance can be given that our insurance coverage or the manufacturers indemni ty will be available or sufficient in any claims brought against us.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Our costs of doing business could increase as a result of changes in federal, state or local regulations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Changes in the federal, state or local minimum wage or living wage requirements or changes in other wage or workplace regulations could increase our costs of doing business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	In addition, changes in federal, state or local regulations governing the sale of some of our products or tax regulations could increase our costs of doing business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Because we are subject to numerous laws and governmental regulations, we could incur substantial judgments, fines, legal fees and other costs.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We are subject to numerous federal, state and local laws and governmental regulations relating to environmental protection, consumer product safety, building, land use and zoning requirements, workplace regulations, wage and hour, privacy and information security and employment law matters.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	If we fail to comply with existing or future laws or regulations, or if these laws or regulations are violated by importers, manufacturers or distributers, we may be subject to governmental or judicial fines or sanctions, while incurring substantial legal fees and costs.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P38_S2	In addition, our capital expenditures could increase due to remediation measures that may be required if we are found to be noncompliant with any existing or future laws or regulations.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	A privacy breach could result in negative publicity and adversely affect the Company s business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	The protection of customer, employee and company data is critical to the Company.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P40_S1	The regulatory environment surrounding information security and privacy is increasingly demanding, with the frequent imposition of new and constantly changing requirements.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	In connection with credit card sales, we transmit confidential credit card information.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Third parties may have the technology or know-how to breach the security of this customer information, and our security measures and those of our technology vendors may not effectively preclude others from obtaining improper access to this information.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P41_S2	Any security breach could expose us to risks of data loss, litigation and liability and could seriously disrupt our operations and any resulting negative publicity could significantly harm our reputation.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	In addition, states and the federal government are increasingly enacting laws and regulations to protect consumers against identity theft.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We collect personal information from consumers in the course of doing business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P43_S1	These laws will likely increase the costs of doing business and, if we fail to comply with these laws and regulations or to implement appropriate safeguards or to detect and provide prompt notice of unauthorized access as required by some of these new laws, we could be subject to potential claims for damages and other remedies, which could harm our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Legal proceedings could materially impact our results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P45_S0	From time to time, we are party to legal proceedings including matters involving personnel and employment issues, personal injury, intellectual property, and other proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Our results could be materially impacted by the decisions and expenses related to pending or future proceedings.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P46_S0	If we experience difficulties with our management information systems, our financial performance may be adversely affected.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P47_S0	We depend on management information systems for many aspects of our business.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P47_S1	We could be materially adversely affected if our management information systems are disrupted or if we are unable to improve, upgrade, maintain and expand systems, particularly in light of the contemplated continued store growth.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Many of our information systems contain confidential customer, Company or employee data.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P48_S1	If we fail to adequately restrict access to this information, our results of operations could be adversely affected.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Effective tax rate changes and results of examinations by taxing authorities could materially impact our results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Our future effective tax rates could be adversely affected by the earnings mix being lower than historical results in states where we have lower statutory rates and higher than historical results in states where we have higher statutory rates, by changes in the measurement of our deferred tax assets and liabilities, or by changes in tax laws or interpretations thereof.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S1	In addition, we are subject to periodic audits and examinations by the Internal Revenue Service ("IRS") and other state and local taxing authorities.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S2	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S4	These circumstances create risk that we could be challenged as to the propriety of our sales tax compliance.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P50_S5	Our results could be materially impacted by the determinations and expenses related to these and other proceedings by the IRS and other state and local taxing authorities.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Failure to maintain an effective system of internal control over financial reporting could materially impact our business and results.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P52_S0	The Company's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P52_S1	An internal control system, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P52_S2	Further, the design of a control system must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Because of the inherent limitations in all internal control systems, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Any failure to maintain an effective system of internal control over financial reporting could limit our ability to report our financial results accurately and timely or to detect and prevent fraud, and could expose us to li tigation or adversely affect the market price of our common stock.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Changes in accounting standards and subjective assumptions, estimates and judgments by management related to complex accounting matters could significantly affect our financial results or financial condition.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Generally accepted accounting principles and related accounting pronouncements, implementation guidelines and interpretations with regard to a wide range of matters that are relevant to our business, such as revenue recognition, asset impairment, inventories, lease obligations, self-insurance, tax matters and litigation, are highly complex and involve many subjective assumptions, estimates or judgments.
916365_11_ITEM1A_P55_S1	Changes in these rules or their interpretation or changes in underlying assumptions, estimates or judgments could significantly change our reported or expected financial performance or financial condition.
916365_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	At December 25, 2010, we operated 1,001 stores in 44 states.
916365_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	We lease more than 94% of our stores, two of our six distribution centers and our management headquarters.
916365_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	Store leases typically have initial terms of between 10 and 15 years, with two to four renewal periods of five years each, exercisable at our option.
916365_11_ITEM2_P0_S3	No single lease is material to our operations.
916365_11_ITEM2_P1_S0	Following is a count of our store locations by state:
916365_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company received and responded to a Request for Information from the United States Environmental Protection Agency ( EPA ) relating to certain recreational vehicles and non-road spark ignition engines sold by the Company.
916365_11_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the first quarter of fiscal 2011, the Environmental Enforcement Section of the Department of Justice ( DOJ ), on behalf of the EPA, informed the Company that it believed the Company had violated the Clean Air Act by importing or causing the importation of certain engines not covered by certificates of conformity issued by the EPA, and that unless the DOJ and the Company were able to reach a settlement, the DOJ was prepared to commence a civil action.
916365_11_ITEM3_P0_S2	The Company is currently engaged in settlement discussions with the DOJ that would call for the payment of a civil penalty and c ertain injunctive relief.
916365_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	The engines were purchased by the Company pursuant to agreements with vendors under which the vendors represented that their products complied with all applicable laws and regulations and under which the vendors agreed to indemnify the Company for any liabilities or costs relating to, among other matters, the noncompliance or alleged noncompliance of their products.
916365_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company has notified these vendors of the EPA s position and expects to be reimbursed for any liabilities or costs relating to this matter.
916365_11_ITEM3_P1_S2	The Company does not expect the resolution of this matter to have a material adverse effect on its financial condition or results of operations.
916365_11_ITEM3_P2_S0	We are also involved in various litigation matters arising in the ordinary course of business.
916365_11_ITEM3_P2_S1	We expect these matters will be resolved without material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position or results of operations.
916365_11_ITEM3_P2_S2	We believe that any estimated loss related to such matters has been adequately provided in accrued liabilities to the extent probable and reasonably estimable.
916365_11_ITEM3_P2_S3	It is possible, however, that future results of operations for any particular quarterly or annual period could be materially affected by changes in circumstances relating to these proceedings.

916365_11_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following selected financial data are derived from the consolidated financial statements of Tractor Supply Company.

916365_11_ITEM6_P1_S1	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_11_ITEM6_P1_S2	All fiscal years presented below consist of 52 weeks.
916365_11_ITEM6_P2_S0	Effective December 25, 2010, the Company elected to change its method of accounting for inventories from the lower of cost, as determined by the last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) method, or market to the lower of cost, as determined by average cost method, or market.
916365_11_ITEM6_P2_S1	The following table provides summary historical financial information adjusted for the change in accounting for inventory for the periods ended and as of the dates indicated (in thousands, except per share amounts and selected operating data):
