916365_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States and is focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and of those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	We operate retail stores under the names Tractor Supply Company and Del s Farm Supply and operate a website under the name TractorSupply.com .
916365_11_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our stores are located in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities, and they offer the following comprehensive selection of merchandise:
916365_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our Tractor Supply stores typically range in size from 15,500 to 18,500 square feet of inside selling space and additional outside selling space.
916365_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	We use a standard 15,500 square foot prototype for new purpose-built locations.
916365_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	For new stores located in existing buildings, one of several layout formats is utilized.
916365_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our wholly-owned subsidiary, Del s, operated 26 stores as of December 25, 2010 in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Hawaii.
916365_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	Del s stores currently range in size from approximately 2,000 to 6,000 square feet of inside selling space plus additional outside and covered/sheltered selling space.
916365_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Our current and long-term growth strategy is to: (1) expand geographic market presence through opening new retail stores, (2) enhance financial performance through same-store sales increases, achieved through targeted merchandising programs with an everyday value prices philosophy and supported by strong customer service, (3) enhance product margin through assortment management, vendor management, sourcing and optimization of transportation and distribution costs, (4) leverage operating costs, especially advertising, distribution and corporate overhead, (5) expand market opportunities via internet sales, and (6) expand through selective acquisition, as such opportunities arise, to enhance penetration into new and existing markets as a complimentary strategy to organic growth.
916365_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	We have experienced considerable sales growth over the past five years, with a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 12.0%.
916365_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	We project an increase of 80 to 85 new stores in 2011, an increase of approximately 8%.
916365_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	We opened 74 new stores in 2010 and 76 new stores in 2009, an increase of approximately 8% and 9%, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	We operated 1,001 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states as of December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified over 800 potential additional markets for new Tractor Supply stores in the United States.
916365_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	The average cash investment for new leased stores opened in 2010 was $1.2 million for retrofit stores and $0.9 million for prototype stores.
916365_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	A majority of the cash outlay was for initial acquisition of inventory and capital expenditures (principally leasehold improvements, fixtures and equipment), and approximately $92,000 for pre-opening costs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	We have placed significant emphasis on our merchandising programs, evaluating the sales and profitability of our products through detailed line reviews, review of vendor performance measures and modification of the overall product offerings.
916365_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	We believe these efforts, coupled with a strong marketing program and in-depth product knowledge training of our store team members, have enhanced our sales and financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	Effective December 25, 2010, the Company elected to change its method of accounting for inventories from the lower of cost, as determined by the last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) method, or market to the lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or market.
916365_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The Company believes the change is preferable as the average cost method better reflects the current value of inventory on the consolidated balance sheets, provides a better reflection of periodic income and improves comparability with our peers.
916365_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	The Company has applied this change in method of inventory costing retrospectively to all prior periods presented herein in accordance with accounting principles relating to accounting changes.
916365_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	All financial information in Item 8 of this 10-K has been retrospectively adjusted.
916365_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	See Note 1, Significant Accounting Policies, to the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, for a complete discussion of our change in accounting method.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	On July 29, 2010, our Board of Directors announced a two-for-one split of our outstanding shares of common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	On September 2, 2010, stockholders of record at the close of business on August 19, 2010, were issued one additional share of common stock for each share owned by such stockholder.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	The stock split increased the number of shares of common stock outstanding from approximately 36.3 million to approximately 72.7 million.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S3	Share and per-share amounts (including stock options and restricted stock units) shown in this Form 10-K reflect the split.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S4	The total number of authorized common shares and the par value thereof was not changed by the split.
916365_11_ITEM7_P11_S5	The number of shares held in treasury was not adjusted for the split.
916365_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Historically, our sales and profits have been the highest in the second and fourth fiscal quarters due to the sale of seasonal products.
916365_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	Unseasonable weather, excessive precipitation, drought, and early or late frosts may also affect our sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	We believe, however, that the impact of extreme weather conditions is somewhat mitigated by the geographic dispersion of our stores.
916365_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	We experience our highest inventory and accounts payable levels during our first fiscal quarter for purchases of seasonal product in anticipation of the spring selling season and again during our third fiscal quarter in anticipation of the winter selling season.
916365_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	Although we cannot determine the full effect of inflation and deflation on our operations, we believe our sales and results of operations are affected by both.
916365_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	We are subject to market risk with respect to the pricing of certain products and services, which include, among other items, steel, grain, petroleum, corn, soybean and other commodities as well as transportation services.
916365_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Therefore, we may experience both inflationary and deflationary pressure on product cost, which may impact consumer demand and, as a result, sales and gross margin.
916365_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	Our strategy is to reduce or mitigate the effects of purchase price volatility principally by taking advantage of vendor incentive programs, economies of scale from increased volume of purchases, adjusting retail prices and selectively buying from the most competiti ve vendors without sacrificing quality.
916365_11_ITEM7_P15_S3	Due to the competitive environment, such conditions have and may continue to adversely impact our financial performance.
916365_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Management s discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make informed estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Our financial position and/or results of operations may be materially different when reported under different conditions or when using different assumptions in the application of such policies.
916365_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	In the event estimates or assumptions prove to be different from actual amounts, adjustments are made in subsequent periods to reflect more current information.
916365_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	Our significant accounting policies are disclosed in Note 1 to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
916365_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	The following discussion addresses our most critical accounting policies, which are those that are both important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results of operations and that require significant judgment or use of complex estimates.
916365_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	We recognize revenue at the time the customer takes possession of merchandise or receives services.
916365_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	If we receive payment before the customer has taken possession of the merchandise (as per our special order and layaway programs), the revenue is deferred until the sale is complete.
916365_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	Revenues from the sale of gift cards are deferred and recognized when the gift card or merchandise return card is redeemed by the customer.
916365_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	Income is recognized when the likelihood of the gift card or merchandise return card being redeemed by the customer is remote (referred to as breakage ).
916365_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	We estimate a liability for sales returns based on a rolling average of historical return trends, and we believe that our estimate for sales returns is an accurate reflection of future returns associated with past sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	Our estimation methodologies have been consistently applied from year to year; however, as with any estimate, refund activity may vary from estimated amounts.
916365_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	The gift card and merchandise return card breakage rate is based upon historical redemption patterns and a benefit is recognized for estimated unredeemed gift cards and merchandise return cards in proportion to those historical redemption patterns.
916365_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize sales returns or breakage in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate sales returns or gift card and merchandise return card breakage.
916365_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	However, if actual consumer return or gift card and merchandise return card redemption patterns are not consistent with our estimates or assumptions, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	A 50 basis point change in our sales return rate at December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $170,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	A 50 basis point change in our gift card and merchandise return card breakage rate would have affected net income by approximately $340,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	We identify potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	The estimated inventory valuation reserve to recognize any impairment in value (i.e., an inability to realize the full carrying value) is based on our aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	We do not believe our merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	Our impairment reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding forecasted customer demand, and the promotional environment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize inventory impairment reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate impairment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	However, if assumptions regarding consumer demand or clearance potential for certain products are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	A 10% change in our impairment reserve at December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $490,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	We perform physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and we have established reserves for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods' sales volumes.
916365_11_ITEM7_P32_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	We believe historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	Our shrinkage reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding future shrinkage trends and the effect of loss prevention measures and new merchandising strategies.
916365_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	We have not made any material changes in the methodology used to recognize shrinkage in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate our shrinkage reserve.
916365_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	However, if our estimates regarding inventory losses are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	A 10% change in our shrinkage reserve at December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $815,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	We receive funding from substantially all of our significant merchandise vendors for the promotion of our brand as well as the sale of their products through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed funding and volume rebate programs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, which have varying expiration dates ranging in duration from several months to a few years.
916365_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	Many agreements are negotiated annually and are based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_11_ITEM7_P38_S3	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_11_ITEM7_P38_S4	During interim periods, the amount of e xpected funding is estimated based upon initial guaranteed commitments, as well as anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	The estimated purchase volume and related vendor funding is based on our current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	Although we believe we can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related vendor funding at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could significantly differ from previously estimated amounts.
916365_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	Our allocation methodology contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding customer demand, purchasing activity, target thresholds, vendor attrition and collectibility.
916365_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	At the end of each fiscal year, a significant portion of the actual purchase activity is known.
916365_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	Thus, we do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the amounts recorded as vendor support.
916365_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	We do not believe there is a significant collectibility risk related to vendor support amounts due us at the end of fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	If a 10% reserve had been applied against our outstanding vendor support due as of December 25, 2010, net income would have been affected by approximately $1.6 million.
916365_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	Although it is unlikely that there will be any significant reduction in historical levels of vendor support, if such a reduction were to occur in future periods, the Company could experience a higher inventory balance and higher cost of sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	We incur various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	We allocate freight as a component of total cost of sales without regard to inventory mix or unique freight burden of certain categories.
916365_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	This assumption has been consistently applied for all years presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	If a 10% increase or decrease had been applied against our current inventory capitalized freight balance, net income would have been affected by approximately $3.4 million.
916365_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	We have share-based compensation plans, which include incentive and non-qualified stock options, restricted stock units, and an employee stock purchase plan.
916365_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	See Note 1, Significant Accounting Policies, and Note 2, Share-Based Compensation, to the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, for a complete discussion of our share-based compensation programs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	We estimate the fair value of our stock option awards at the date of grant utilizing a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
916365_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	We estimate the fair value of our market-based restricted stock units at the date of grant utilizing average market price of our stock on the date of the related award.
916365_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	Option-pricing models and generally accepted valuation techniques require management to make subjective assumptions and to apply judgment to determine the fair value of our awards.
916365_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	These assumptions and judgments include estimating the future volatility of our stock price, expected dividend yield, future employee turnover rates and future employee stock option exercise behaviors.
916365_11_ITEM7_P50_S2	In addition to the key assumptions used to estimate the fair value, the estimated forfeiture rate of the awarded options is a critical assumption, as it reduces expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_11_ITEM7_P50_S3	Changes in these assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate and the amount of share-based compensation recognized.
916365_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	While we update our assumptions annually, we do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to determine share-based compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	However, if actual results are not consistent with our estimates or assumptions, we may be exposed to changes in share-based compensation expense that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P51_S2	The reported share-based compensation expense may not be representative of the actual economic cost of the share-based compensation.
916365_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	A 10% change in our share-based compensation expense for the year ended December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $750,000.
916365_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	We self-insure a significant portion of our employee medical insurance, workers' compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	We have stop-loss insurance policies to protect from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	When estimating our self-insured liabilities, we consider a number of factors, including historical claims experience, demographic factors and severity factors.
916365_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers' compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	Our self-insured liabilities contain uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the ultimate cost to settle reported claims and claims incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date.
916365_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our self-insurance reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the assumptions we use to calculate insurance reserves.
916365_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	However, if we experience a significant increase in the number of claims or the cost associated with these claims, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	A 10% change in our self-insurance reserves at December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $1.8 million in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers.
916365_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	We obtain exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	Many of the states in which we conduct business will perform audits to verify our compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P60_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that we could be challenged as to the propriety of our sales tax compliance.
916365_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	While we believe we reasonably enforce sales tax compliance with our customers and endeavor to fully comply with all applicable sales tax regulations, there can be no assurance that we, upon final completion of such audits, would not have a significant liability for disallowed exemptions.
916365_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	We review our past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to determine if we have potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and our to-date experience with each audit.
916365_11_ITEM7_P62_S2	As each audit progresses, we quantify the exposure based on preliminary assessments made by the state auditors, adjusted for additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	Our sales tax audit reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding the regulatory support for the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits, and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	We have not made any material changes in the methodology used to establish the sales tax audit reserve in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate the sales tax liability reserve for current audits.
916365_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	However, if our estimates regarding the ultimate sales tax liability are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	A 10% change in our sales tax liability reserve at December 25, 2010, would have affected net income by approximately $470,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	Our income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_11_ITEM7_P67_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	In evaluating the exposures associated with our various tax filing positions, we record reserves for probable exposures.
916365_11_ITEM7_P68_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which we have established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	We adjust our tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from our established reserve, the st atute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	We recognize a liability for certain tax benefits that do not meet the minimum requirements for recognition in the financial statements.
916365_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	Our tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our effective income tax rate is also affected by changes in tax law, the tax jurisdiction of new stores or business ventures, the level of earnings and the results of tax audits.
916365_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the reserves established for tax benefits not recognized.
916365_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	Although management believes that the judgments and estimates discussed herein are reasonable, actual results could differ, and we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	To the extent we prevail in matters for which reserves have been established, or are required to pay amounts in excess of our reserves, our effective income tax rate in a given financial statement period could be materially affected.
916365_11_ITEM7_P75_S1	An unfavorable tax settlement would require use of our cash and would result in an increase in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_11_ITEM7_P75_S2	A favorable tax settlement would be recognized as a reduction in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	A 10% change in our unrecognized tax benefit reserve at December 25, 2010 would have affected net income by approximately $370,000 in fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are not amortized.
916365_11_ITEM7_P77_S1	We evaluate goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of the goodwill may not be recoverable.
916365_11_ITEM7_P77_S2	We complete our impairment evaluation by performing internal valuation analyses, considering other publicly available market information and using an independent valuation firm, as appropriate.
916365_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	At December 26, 2009 all goodwill was associated with the Del s business and, for purposes of the fiscal 2009 impairment testing, Del s was considered the reporting unit.
916365_11_ITEM7_P78_S1	In October 2010, we reevaluated the Del s reporting unit and concluded that since Del s has become closely aligned in terms of management, infrastructure, philosophy and performance, we now have only one reporting unit for goodwill impairment evaluation.
916365_11_ITEM7_P78_S2	All goodwill at December 25, 2010 is associated with the Company as a whole.
916365_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010, we completed our annual impairment testing of goodwill, and determined there was no impairment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P79_S1	We determined that the fair value of the reporting unit (including goodwill) was in excess of the carrying value of the reporting unit.
916365_11_ITEM7_P79_S2	In reaching this conclusion, the fair value of the reporting unit was determined based on a market approach.
916365_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	Under the market approach, the fair value is based on observed market prices.
916365_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	We determine fair value using widely accepted valuation techniques, including discounted cash flow and market multiple analyses.
916365_11_ITEM7_P81_S1	These types of analyses contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate industry economic factors and the profitability of future business strategies.
916365_11_ITEM7_P81_S2	Estimates include revenues, gross margins, operating costs and cash flows.
916365_11_ITEM7_P81_S3	We considered historical and estimated future results, economic and market conditions and the impact of planned business and operational strategies in deriving these estimates.
916365_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	In developing the key judgments and assumptions used to assess impairment, we consider economic, operational and market conditions that could impact the fair value of the reporting unit.
916365_11_ITEM7_P82_S1	These estimates and the judgments and assumptions upon which the estimates are based may differ in some respects from actual results.
916365_11_ITEM7_P82_S2	Should a significant or prolonged deterioration in economic conditions persist, then key judgments and assumptions may be impacted.
916365_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	At December 25, 2010, the fair value of the reporting unit exceeded the carrying value of its net assets by a significant amount.
916365_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	However, if actual results are not consistent with our current estimates or assumptions, we may be exposed to an impairment charge that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_11_ITEM7_P85_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, we first compare the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges).
916365_11_ITEM7_P85_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_11_ITEM7_P85_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_11_ITEM7_P86_S0	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, we calculate an impairment loss.
916365_11_ITEM7_P86_S1	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_11_ITEM7_P86_S2	We recognize an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_11_ITEM7_P86_S3	If we recognize an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_11_ITEM7_P87_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining useful life of that asset.
916365_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	Our impairment loss calculations contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate future cash flows and asset fair values, including forecasting useful lives of the assets and selecting the discount rate that reflects the risk inherent in future cash flows.
916365_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	We have not made any material changes in our impairment loss assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the estimates or assumptions we use to calculate long-lived asset impairment losses.
916365_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	None of these estimates and assumptions are significantly sensitive, and a 10% change in any of these estimates would not have a material impact on our analysis.
916365_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	However, if actual results are not consistent with our estimates and assumptions used in estimating future cash flows and asset fair values, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	Our unaudited quarterly operating results for each fiscal quarter of 2010 and 2009 are shown below (in thousands, except per share amounts):
916365_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	Amounts have been adjusted for the change in inventory accounting method from LIFO to average cost.
916365_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	The fiscal fourth quarter does not require an adjustment for the change in inventory accounting method as this change occurred during this period.
916365_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	Due to the nature of interim earnings per share calculations, the sum of quarterly earnings per share amounts may not equal the reported earnings per share for the year.
916365_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Our fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_11_ITEM7_P95_S2	The fiscal years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009 and December 27, 2008 contain 52 weeks.
916365_11_ITEM7_P95_S3	All amounts have been adjusted to reflect the Company s election to change its method of accounting for inventories from the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method to the average cost method.
916365_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain items in our Consolidated Statements of Income expressed as a percentage of net sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	(a) Our gross margin amounts may not be comparable to those of other retailers since some retailers include all of the costs related to their distribution network in cost of merchandise sold and others like us exclude a portion of these distribution network costs from gross margin and instead include them in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses; refer to Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
916365_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	Net sales increased 13.5% to $3.64 billion in fiscal 2010 from $3.21 billion in fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	This increase resulted from the opening of new stores and a 7.0% increase in same-store sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P98_S2	The same-store average daily transaction count increased 7.4%, while same-store transaction value decreased 0.3% for fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	Same-store sales increased 7.0% compared with a same-store sales decrease of 1.1% in the prior year.
916365_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	This same-store sales increase was broad-based and driven by strong results in core consumable categories, principally animal and pet-related products, as well as seasonal products, including heating, insulated outerwear and outdoor power equipment.
916365_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	In fiscal 2010, we opened 74 new stores (compared to 76 new stores in fiscal 2009), relocated no stores (compared to two in fiscal 2009) and closed three stores (compared to one store in fiscal 2009).
916365_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	Gross margin increased 15.5% to $1.20 billion compared to $1.04 billion in 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P101_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased to 33.1% for fiscal 2010 compared to 32.5% for fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P101_S2	The improvement in gross margin is primarily due to expanded direct product margin and a decrease in shrink, partially offset by increased transportation costs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P101_S3	The direct product margin improvement resulted from continued progress on margin driving initiatives which include strategic sourcing, inventory management, and more effective pricing.
916365_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses including depreciation and amortization improved 70 basis points to 25.8% in fiscal 2010 from 26.5% in fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P102_S1	The improvement as a percent to sales was primarily attributable to the leverage of strong same-store sales and expense management, partially offset by an increase in incentive compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	Net interest expense decreased 21.9% to $1.3 million in fiscal 2010 from $1.6 million in fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P103_S1	This decrease is directly related to lower average borrowings and a decline in interest charges associated with sales tax audits.
916365_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.6% for fiscal 2010 compared to 36.9% in fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P104_S1	This reduction in the tax resulted from a greater tax benefit received on the disqualified disposition of incentive stock options during fiscal 2010 compared to fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2010 increased 40.3% to $168.0 million, or $2.25 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $119.7 million, or $1.63 per diluted share, in fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	During 2010, we repurchased approximately 0.8 million shares of stock for $38.2 million as part of our previously announced $400 million share repurchase program.
916365_11_ITEM7_P106_S1	In 2009, we repurchased approximately 0.4 million shares at a total cost of $15.3 million.
916365_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	As mentioned in Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies in Part II of this Form 10-K, the shares added to treasury were not adjusted for the stock split.
916365_11_ITEM7_P108_S0	Net sales increased 6.6% to $3.21 billion in fiscal 2009 from $3.01 billion in fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P108_S1	This increase resulted from the opening of new stores partially offset by a 1.1% decrease in same-store sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P108_S2	The same-store average daily transaction count increased 5.3%, while same-store transaction value decreased 6.0% for fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P109_S0	Same-store sales decreased 1.1% compared with a same-store sales increase of 1.4% in the prior year.
916365_11_ITEM7_P109_S1	This same-store sales decline was primarily driven by softness in sales of seasonal big ticket (merchandise priced $350 or greater) and discretionary merchandise, partially offset by continued strong results in core consumable categories, including animal and pet-related products.
916365_11_ITEM7_P110_S0	In fiscal 2009, we opened 76 new stores (compared to 91 new stores in fiscal 2008), relocated two stores (compared to one in fiscal 2008) and closed one store (compared to no stores in fiscal 2008).
916365_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	Gross margin increased 9.1% to $1,041.9 million compared to $955.1 million in 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P111_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased to 32.5% for fiscal 2009 compared to 31.8% for fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P111_S2	The increase in gross margin resulted primarily from lower transportation costs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P112_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses increased 60 basis points to 24.4% in fiscal 2009 from 23.8% in fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P112_S1	This increase as a percent of sales was primarily attributable to the deleveraging related to the same-store sales decrease and higher incentive compensation and occupancy costs, partially offset by reduced marketing costs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P112_S2	Depreciation and amortization expense increased 10 basis points as a percent of sales in fiscal 2009 over fiscal 2008 due mainly to costs associated with new stores.
916365_11_ITEM7_P113_S0	Net interest expense decreased 22.9% to $1.6 million in fiscal 2009 from $2.1 million in fiscal 2008; however, net interest expense remained consistent as a percent of sales.
916365_11_ITEM7_P113_S1	This decrease is directly related to lower average borrowings partially offset by higher interest charges associated with sales tax audits.
916365_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.9% for fiscal 2009 compared to 38.7% in fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P114_S1	This reduction in the tax resulted from the favorable impact of certain federal tax credits and a lower percentage of unfavorable permanent tax differences relative to income before taxes.
916365_11_ITEM7_P115_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2009 increased 10.9% to $119.7 million, or $1.63 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $108.0 million, or $1.44 per diluted share, in fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	During 2009, we repurchased approximately 0.4 million shares of stock for $15.3 million as part of our previously announced $400 million share repurchase program.
916365_11_ITEM7_P116_S1	In 2008, we repurchased approximately 1.6 million shares at a total cost of $53.9 million.
916365_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	As mentioned in Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies in Part II of this Form 10-K, the shares added to treasury were not adjusted for the stock split.
916365_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	In addition to normal operating expenses, our primary ongoing cash requirements are for expansion, remodeling and relocation programs, including inventory purchases and capital expenditures.
916365_11_ITEM7_P118_S1	Our primary ongoing sources of liquidity are existing cash balances, funds provided from operations, commitments available under our revolving credit agreement, capital and operating leases and normal trade credit.
916365_11_ITEM7_P118_S2	Our inventory and accounts payable levels typically build in the first and third fiscal quarters in anticipation of the spring and winter selling seasons, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	Financial markets experienced volatility in the past few years, resulting in disruptions in credit and lending activities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P119_S1	Further, disruptions in the capital and credit markets could adversely affect the ability of the banks to meet their commitments.
916365_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	Our access to funds under the credit facility is dependent on the ability of the banks that are parties to the facility to meet their funding commitments.
916365_11_ITEM7_P120_S1	Those banks may not be able to meet their funding commitments to us if they experience shortages of capital and liquidity or if they experience excessive volumes of borrowing requests within a short period of time.
916365_11_ITEM7_P120_S2	We have a diversified banking group which we believe should help mitigate any potential disruptions, if one occurs.
916365_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	At December 25, 2010, we had working capital of $617.1 million, a $141.2 million increase from December 26, 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P121_S1	This increase was primarily attributable to changes in the following components of current assets and current liabilities (in millions):
916365_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	In comparison to prior year end, working capital increased primarily as a result of an increase in cash and inventory.
916365_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	The increase in cash resulted principally from stronger earnings.
916365_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	The increase in inventory was primarily due to new store growth.
916365_11_ITEM7_P122_S3	Average inventory per store remained nearly flat at $709,000 for fiscal 2010 compared to $707,000 for fiscal 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P122_S4	This was partially offset by an increase in accrued expenses principally as a result of timing of payments and higher incentive compensation accruals over the prior year.
916365_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	Accounts payable has declined as a result of an increase in cash held in our bank concentration account, which nets against accounts payable, as well as more timely payments in order to capture payment discounts offered by our vendors.
916365_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	Trade credit arises from our vendors granting payment terms for inventory purchases.
916365_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	Payment terms generally vary from 30 days to 180 days depending on the inventory product.
916365_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	Certain vendors offer payment discounts for payments made within a shorter period, typically within 10 to 15 days.
916365_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	We are party to a Senior Credit Facility with Bank of America, N.A., as agent for a lender group (the Credit Agreement ), which provides for borrowings up to $350 million (with sublimits of $75 million and $20 million for letters of credit and swingline loans, respectively).
916365_11_ITEM7_P125_S1	The Credit Agreement has an Increase Option for $150 million (subject to additional lender group commitments).
916365_11_ITEM7_P125_S2	The Credit Agreement is unsecured and matures in February 2012, with proceeds expected to be used for working capital, capital expenditures and share repurchases.
916365_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, there were no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement.
916365_11_ITEM7_P126_S1	There were $27.4 million and $35.2 million outstanding letters of credit as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM7_P126_S2	Borrowings bear interest at either the bank s base rate (3.25% at December 25, 2010) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) (0.26% at December 25, 2010) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.35% to 0.90% per annum, adjusted quarterly based on our performance (0.40% at December 25, 2010).
916365_11_ITEM7_P126_S3	We are also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee ranging from 0.06% to 0.18% per annum and adjusted quarterly based on our performance, for unused capacity (0.075% at December 25, 2010).
916365_11_ITEM7_P126_S4	There are no com pensating balance requirements associated with the Credit Agreement.
916365_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	The Credit Agreement requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_11_ITEM7_P127_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio principally compares earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, stock compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding straight-line rent).
916365_11_ITEM7_P127_S2	The leverage ratio principally compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding straight-line rent) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_11_ITEM7_P127_S3	The Credit Agreement also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiar ies or affiliates, and liens.
916365_11_ITEM7_P127_S4	We were in compliance with all covenants at December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operations.
916365_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	Principal uses of cash for investing activities are capital expenditures and financing activities are payments on debt, repurchase of the Company s common stock, and payment of common stock dividends.
916365_11_ITEM7_P128_S2	The following table presents a summary of cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities for the last three fiscal years (in millions):

916365_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	Cash flow from operating activities continues to provide the primary source of our liquidity.
916365_11_ITEM7_P130_S1	The increase in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2010 compared with fiscal 2009 was primarily due to stronger net income and an increase in accrued expenses partially offset by an increase in inventory, net of accounts payable, and an increase in prepaids and other current assets.
916365_11_ITEM7_P130_S2	Continued store growth has resulted in increased inventory balances.
916365_11_ITEM7_P130_S3	Accounts payable levels have decreased as a result of more timely payments in order to capture payment discounts offered by vendors and also as a result of an increase in cash held in our bank concentration account.
916365_11_ITEM7_P130_S4	The bank concentration account nets against the related book overdraft included in accounts payable.
916365_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	Accrued expenses increased as a result of timing of pa yments as well as incentive compensation earned in fiscal 2010 but not paid until fiscal 2011.

916365_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	The decrease in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2009 compared with fiscal 2008 was due to changes in inventory levels and the timing of payments, partially offset by higher net income and an increase in accrued expenses.
916365_11_ITEM7_P133_S1	Inventory levels remained nearly flat in 2009 compared to 2008 due to a continued focus on inventory management in 2009.
916365_11_ITEM7_P133_S2	Accounts payable levels have decreased substantially as a result of more timely payments to capture payment discounts offered by vendors.
916365_11_ITEM7_P133_S3	Accrued expenses increased as a result of timing of payments as well as incentive compensation earned in fiscal 2009 but not paid until fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	Investing activities used $112.1 million, $73.8 million and $88.4 million in fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM7_P134_S1	The majority of this cash requirement relates to our capital expenditures.

916365_11_ITEM7_P135_S0	Our long-term growth strategy anticipates continued geographic market expansion and further concentration within existing markets.
916365_11_ITEM7_P135_S1	This growth will also require continuing investment in information technology.
916365_11_ITEM7_P135_S2	The costs reflected above are typically building improvements, as we lease the majority of our facilities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P135_S3	We currently estimate that capital expenditures will range between $150 million and $160 million in fiscal 2011.
916365_11_ITEM7_P135_S4	While we plan to open only a few more stores in 2011 compared to 2010, we expect to have additional capital expenditures next year as we construct a new distribution center and implement a comprehensive warehouse management system designed to improve throughput and efficiencies in the distribution center network, along with other efficiency-driving system enhancements in 2011.
916365_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	Financing activities used $26.0 million, $5.6 million, and $105.5 million in fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	The cash used by financing activities in fiscal 2010 is mainly the result of quarterly cash dividends paid to stockholders and repurchases of common stock, partially offset by increased net proceeds from issuance of common stock related to share-based compensation.

916365_11_ITEM7_P137_S3	Repurchased shares will be held in treasury.
916365_11_ITEM7_P137_S4	The program may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.

916365_11_ITEM7_P147_S0	In June 2009, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) Topic 810 (originally issued as Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 167, Amendments to FASB Interpretation No. ( FIN ) 46(R) ).
916365_11_ITEM7_P147_S1	Among other items, ASC 810 responds to concerns about an enterprise s application of certain key provisions of FIN 46(R), including those regarding the transparency of the enterprise s involvement with variable interest entities.
916365_11_ITEM7_P148_S0	ASC 810 is effective for the first annual period that begins after November 15, 2009, and for interim periods within that first annual reporting period.
916365_11_ITEM7_P148_S1	The Company adopted the standard for the interim period ended March 27, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM7_P148_S2	There was no impact on the C ompany s financial position, results of operations, cash flows, or disclosures.
916365_11_ITEM7_P149_S0	In February 2010, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2010-09 (ASU No. 2010-09), Subsequent Events (Topic 855): Amendments to Certain Recognition and Disclosure Requirements.
916365_11_ITEM7_P149_S1	The amendments remove the requirements for an SEC filer to disclose a date, in both issued and revised financial statements, through which subsequent events have been reviewed.
916365_11_ITEM7_P150_S0	Revised financial statements include financial statements revised as a result of either correction of an error or retrospective application of U.S. GAAP.
916365_11_ITEM7_P150_S1	ASU No. 2010-09 was effective upon issuance.
916365_11_ITEM7_P150_S2	The adoption of this guidance did not have an impact on our financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.
916365_11_ITEM7_P151_S0	We may be exposed to changes in interest rates primarily from the Credit Agreement.
916365_11_ITEM7_P151_S1	The Credit Agreement bears interest at either the bank s base rate (3.25% at both December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009) or LIBOR (0.26% and 0.23% at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.35% to 0.90% per annum, adjusted quarterly, based on our performance (0.40% and 0.50% at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively).
916365_11_ITEM7_P151_S2	We are also required to pay (quarterly in arrears) a commitment fee ranging from 0.06% to 0.18% based on the daily average unused portion of the credit line (0.075% at December 25, 2010 and 0.10% December 26, 2009).
916365_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited Tractor Supply Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
916365_11_ITEM8_P0_S1	Tractor Supply Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
916365_11_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
916365_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
916365_11_ITEM8_P1_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
916365_11_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
916365_11_ITEM8_P1_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
916365_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations o f management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
916365_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, Tractor Supply Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, based on the COSO criteria .
916365_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Tractor Supply Company as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010 and our report dated February 23, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
916365_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Tractor Supply Company as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM8_P6_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
916365_11_ITEM8_P6_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
916365_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
916365_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
916365_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P8_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P8_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
916365_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Tractor Supply Company at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	As discussed in Note 1 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company has elected to change its method of accounting for inventory from the lower of cost, as determined by the last-in first-out (LIFO) method, or market, to the lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or market, effective December 25, 2010.
