916365_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies :
916365_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	Tractor Supply Company (the Company , we , us and/or our ) is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States.
916365_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	We are focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_11_ITEM8_P16_S2	Stores are located in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	Our wholly-owned subsidiary, Del s Farm Supply, LLC ( Del s ) operated 26 stores as of December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM8_P17_S1	At December 25, 2010, we operated a total of 1,001 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states and also offered a number of products online at TractorSupply.com .
916365_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	Our fiscal year ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year and includes 52 or 53 weeks.
916365_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	The fiscal years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009 and December 27, 2008 consist of 52 weeks.
916365_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries.
916365_11_ITEM8_P19_S1	All material intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
916365_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	Effective December 25, 2010, the Company elected to change its method of accounting for inventories from lower of cost, as determined by the LIFO method, or market, to lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or market.
916365_11_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company believes the change is preferable as the average cost method better reflects the current value of inventory on the consolidated balance sheets, provides a better reflection of periodic income and improves comparability with our peers.
916365_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	The Company has applied this change in method of inventory costing retrospectively to all prior periods presented herein in accordance with accounting principles relating to accounting changes.
916365_11_ITEM8_P21_S1	As a result of the retrospective change in accounting principle, opening retained earnings as of December 29, 2007 increased by $15.6 million.
916365_11_ITEM8_P21_S2	The effect of the change in method on previously reported consolidated operating results for fiscal 2009 and 2008 was to increase net income by $4.3 million ($0.05 per dilutive share), and $26.1 million ($0.35 per dilutive share), respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P21_S3	The effect on the consolidated balance sheet at December 26, 2009 was to increase inventory, tax liabilities and retained earnings by $75.2 million, $29.3 million and $45.9 million, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	Certain components of the Company s financial statements affected by the change in costing methodology as originally reported under the LIFO method and as adjusted for the change to the average cost method are as follows (in thousands, except per share data):
916365_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	* As described below, certain other amounts in the previously issued balance sheet have been reclassified to conform to the fiscal 2010 presentation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	On July 29, 2010, our Board of Directors announced a two-for-one split of our outstanding shares of common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S1	On September 2, 2010, stockholders of record at the close of business on August 19, 2010, were issued one additional share of common stock for each share owned by such stockholder.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S2	The stock split increased the number of shares of common stock outstanding from approximately 36.3 million to approximately 72.7 million.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S3	Share and per-share amounts (including stock options and restricted stock units) shown in the consolidated financial statements and related notes reflect the split.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S4	The total number of authorized common shares and the par value thereof was not changed by the split.
916365_11_ITEM8_P24_S5	The number of shares held in treasury was not adjusted for the split .
916365_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	Certain amounts in previously issued financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the fiscal 2010 presentation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	Marketing support fund receivables due from vendors previously classified in prepaid expenses and other current assets have been reclassified to reduce vendor accounts payable ($11.6 million at December 26, 2009).
916365_11_ITEM8_P25_S2	Amounts related to accrued employee compensation ($22.7 million at December 26, 2009) have been reclassified from other accrued expenses to accrued employee compensation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P25_S3	A portion of the liabilities related to self-insured workers compensation and general liability claims ($14.0 million at December 26, 2009) previously classified in other accrued expenses have been reclassified to other long-term liabilities to reflect their long-term status.
916365_11_ITEM8_P25_S4	Also amou nts related to tenant improvement allowances ($18.0 million at December 26, 2009) previously classified in other long-term liabilities and amounts related to straight-line rent ($45.5 million at December 26, 2009) previously classified as straight-line rent liability have been reclassified as deferred rent to conform to the December 25, 2010 presentation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	These changes have affected our December 26, 2009 Consolidated Balance Sheet and the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for the fiscal years ended December 26, 2009 and December 27, 2008.
916365_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	Tractor Supply Company has one reportable industry segment which is the operation of farm and ranch retail stores.
916365_11_ITEM8_P27_S1	We also offer a number of products online at TractorSupply.com .
916365_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	Our preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States inherently requires estimates and assumptions by us that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosures.
916365_11_ITEM8_P28_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
916365_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	Significant estimates and assumptions by management primarily impact the following key financial statement areas:
916365_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	We recognize revenue at the time the customer takes possession of merchandise.
916365_11_ITEM8_P30_S1	If we receive payment before the customer has taken possession of the merchandise (as per our special order and layaway programs), the revenue is deferred until the sale is complete.
916365_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	We are required to collect certain taxes and fees from customers on behalf of government agencies and remit such collections to the applicable governmental entity on a periodic basis.
916365_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	These taxes are collected from customers at the time of purchase, but are not included in net sales.
916365_11_ITEM8_P31_S2	We record a liability upon collection from the customer and relieve the liability when payments are remitted to the applicable governmental agency.
916365_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	We estimate a liability for sales returns based on a rolling average of historical return trends, and we believe that our estimate for sales returns is an accurate reflection of future returns associated with past sales.
916365_11_ITEM8_P32_S1	Our estimation methodologies have been consistently applied from year to year; however, as with any estimate, refund activity may vary from estimated amounts.
916365_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	At December 25, 2010 we had a liability of $3.0 million reserved for sales returns, compared to $3.1 million at December 26, 2009.
916365_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	We recognize revenue when a gift card or merchandise return card is redeemed by the customer and recognize income when the likelihood of the gift card or merchandise return card being redeemed by the customer is remote (referred to as breakage ).
916365_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	The gift card and merchandise return card breakage rate is based upon historical redemption patterns and income is recognized for unredeemed gift card and merchandise return cards in proportion to those historical redemption patterns.
916365_11_ITEM8_P34_S2	We recognized income of $1.6 million, $1.1 million and $1.4 million in fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	We identify potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	The estimated inventory valuation reserve to recognize any impairment in value (i.e. an inability to realize the full carrying value) is based on our aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_11_ITEM8_P35_S2	We do not believe our merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_11_ITEM8_P35_S3	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	We perform physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and we have established reserves for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods sales volumes.
916365_11_ITEM8_P36_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	We believe historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	We receive funding from substantially all of our significant merchandise vendors for the promotion of our brand as well as the sale of their products through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed funding and volume rebate programs.
916365_11_ITEM8_P38_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, which have varying expiration dates ranging in duration from several months to a few years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P38_S2	Many agreements are negotiated annually and are based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_11_ITEM8_P38_S3	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	During the interim periods, the amount of expected funding is estimated based upon initial guaranteed commitments, as well as anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_11_ITEM8_P39_S1	The estimated purchase volume and related vendor funding is based on our current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_11_ITEM8_P39_S2	Although we believe we can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related vendor funding at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could differ significantly from the previously estimated amounts.
916365_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	We incur various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	We have share-based compensation plans, which include incentive and non-qualified stock options, restricted stock units, and an employee stock purchase plan, covering certain members of management and non-employee directors.
916365_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	We estimate the fair value of our stock option awards at the date of grant utilizing a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
916365_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of short-term traded options that have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
916365_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	However, key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model are adjusted to incorporate the unique characteristics of our stock option awards.
916365_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	Option pricing models and generally accepted valuation techniques require management to make subjective assumptions including expected stock price volatility, expected dividend yield, risk-free interest rate and expected life.
916365_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	We rely on historical volatility trends to estimate future volatility assumptions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	The risk-free interest rates used were actual U.S. Treasury Constant Maturity rates for bonds matching the expected term of the option on the date of grant.
916365_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	The expected life of the option on the date of grant was estimated based on our historical experience for similar options.
916365_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	In addition to the key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model, the estimated forfeiture rate at the time of valuation (which is based on historical experience for similar options) is a critical assumption, as it reduces expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	We adjust this estimate periodically, based on the extent to which actual forfeitures differ, or are expected to differ, from the previous estimate.
916365_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	We believe our estimates are reasonable in the context of historical experience.
916365_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	Future results will depend on, among other matters, levels of share-based compensation granted in the future, actual forfeiture rates and the timing of option exercises.
916365_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	We self-insure a significant portion of our employee medical insurance, workers compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_11_ITEM8_P48_S1	We have stop-loss insurance policies to protect from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P49_S1	Therefore, we estimate potential obligations for liabilities that have been incurred but not yet reported based upon historical data and experience.
916365_11_ITEM8_P49_S2	Although we believe the reserves established for these obligations are reasonably estimated, any significant increase in the number of claims or costs associated with claims made under these plans could have a material adverse effect on our financial results.
916365_11_ITEM8_P49_S3	At December 25, 2010 , we had recorded net insurance reserves of $29.0 million compared to $23.7 million at December 26, 2009.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S1	We obtain exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S2	Many of the states in which we conduct business will perform audits to verify our compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that we could be challenged as to the propriety of our sales tax compliance.
916365_11_ITEM8_P50_S5	While we believe we reasonably enforce sales tax compliance with our customers and endeavor to fully comply with all applicable sales tax regulations, there can be no assurance that we, upon final completion of such audits, will not have a significant liabil ity for disallowed exemptions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	We review our past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to determine if we have potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_11_ITEM8_P51_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and our to-date experience with each audit.
916365_11_ITEM8_P51_S2	As each audit progresses, we quantify the exposure based on preliminary assessments made by the state auditors, adjusted for additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_11_ITEM8_P51_S3	The reserve for these tax audits can fluctuate depending on numerous factors, including the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	Our income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P52_S1	These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P52_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	In evaluating the exposures associated with our various tax filing positions, we record reserves for probable exposures.
916365_11_ITEM8_P53_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which we have established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	We adjust our tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from our established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant ta x authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	We recognize a liability for certain tax benefits that do not meet the minimum requirements for recognition in the financial statements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	Our tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	Our effective income tax rate is also affected by changes in tax law, the tax jurisdiction of new stores or business ventures, the level of earnings and the results of tax audits.
916365_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	Sales generated through our private label credit cards are not reflected as accounts receivable.
916365_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	Under an agreement with Citi Cards, a division of Citigroup ( Citigroup ), consumer and business credit is extended directly to customers by Citigroup.
916365_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	All credit program and related services are performed and controlled directly by Citigroup.
916365_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	Non-capital expenditures incurred in connection with opening new store and distribution centers, primarily payroll and rent, are expensed as incurred.
916365_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	Preopening costs were approximately $7.1 million, $7.5 million and $8.7 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P61_S0	We regularly evaluate the performance of our stores and periodically close those that are under-performing.
916365_11_ITEM8_P62_S0	We record a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred, usually in the period the store closes.
916365_11_ITEM8_P62_S1	Store closing costs were not significant to results of operations for any of the fiscal years presented.
916365_11_ITEM8_P63_S0	Temporary cash investments, with a maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
916365_11_ITEM8_P64_S0	The majority of payments due from banks for customer credit card transactions process within 24-48 hours and are accordingly classified as cash and cash equivalents.
916365_11_ITEM8_P65_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in an orderly transaction between market participants on the measurement date.
916365_11_ITEM8_P65_S1	The Company uses a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
916365_11_ITEM8_P65_S2	These tiers include: Level 1, defined as observable inputs such as quoted prices in active markets; Level 2, defined as inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are either directly or indirectly observable; and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists, therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P66_S0	Our financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments, short-term receivables, trade payables and long-term debt instruments.
916365_11_ITEM8_P66_S1	The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, short-term receivables and trade payables approximate current fair value.
916365_11_ITEM8_P66_S2	We had no borrowings under the revolving credit facility at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009.
916365_11_ITEM8_P67_S0	Our short-term investment in a U.S. Treasury note is classified as Level 1 as these types of investments trade with sufficient frequency and volume to enable us to obtain pricing information on an ongoing basis.
916365_11_ITEM8_P67_S1	The U.S. Treasury note is held as collateral for a standby letter of credit and is expected to be held to maturity.
916365_11_ITEM8_P67_S2	The fair value of short-term investments at December 25, 2010 was $15.9 million.
916365_11_ITEM8_P67_S3	We had no short-term investments at December 26, 2009.
916365_11_ITEM8_P68_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or market.
916365_11_ITEM8_P69_S0	Inventory cost consists of the direct cost of merchandise including freight.
916365_11_ITEM8_P69_S1	Inventories are net of shrinkage, obsolescence, other valuations and vendor allowances.
916365_11_ITEM8_P70_S0	Approximately 250 vendors accounted for 90% of our purchases for fiscal 2010, with no one vendor representing more than 10% of purchases during the year.
916365_11_ITEM8_P71_S0	Cost of merchandise sold includes the total cost of products sold; freight expenses associated with moving merchandise inventories from our vendors to our distribution centers; from our distribution centers to our retail stores; and from one distribution center to another; vendor support; damaged, junked or defective product; cash discounts from payments to merchandise vendors; and adjustments for shrinkage (physical inventory losses), lower of cost or market valuation, slow moving product and excess inventory quantities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P72_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses ( SG A ) include payroll and benefit costs for retail, distribution center and corporate employees; occupancy costs of retail, distribution center and corporate facilities; advertising; tender costs, including bank charges and costs associated with credit and debit card interchange fees; outside service fees; and other administrative costs, such as computer maintenance, supplies, travel and lodging.
916365_11_ITEM8_P73_S0	Costs incurred at our distribution centers for receiving, warehousing and preparing product for delivery are expensed as incurred and are included in SG A expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_11_ITEM8_P73_S1	Because the Company does not include these costs in cost of sales, the Company s gross margin may not be comparable to other retailers that include these costs in the calculation of gross margin.
916365_11_ITEM8_P73_S2	Distribution center costs for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 were approximately $64.4 million, $59.0 million and $52.8 million, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	Property and equipment are carried at cost.
916365_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
916365_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	Improvements to leased premises are amortized using the straight-line method over the initial term of the lease or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is less.
916365_11_ITEM8_P75_S2	Leasehold improvements added late in the lease term are amortized over the term of the lease (including the first renewal option, if the renewal is reasonably assured) or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is less.
916365_11_ITEM8_P75_S3	The following estimated useful lives are generally applied:
916365_11_ITEM8_P76_S0	Depreciation includes expenses related to all retail, distribution center and corporate assets.
916365_11_ITEM8_P76_S1	Amortization includes expenses related to definite-lived intangible assets.
916365_11_ITEM8_P77_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs related to the acquisition and development of software and amortizes these costs using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the software, which is three to five years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P77_S1	These costs are included in computer software and hardware in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
916365_11_ITEM8_P77_S2	Certain software costs not meeting the criteria for capitalization are expensed as incurred.
916365_11_ITEM8_P78_S0	Assets under capital leases are amortized in accordance with our normal depreciation policy for owned assets or over the lease term, if shorter, and the related charge to operations is included in depreciation expense in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_11_ITEM8_P79_S0	Certain leases include rent increases during the initial lease term.
916365_11_ITEM8_P79_S1	For these leases, we recognize the related rental expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease (which includes the pre-opening period of construction, renovation, fixturing and merchandise placement) and record the difference between the expense charged to operations and amounts paid as a deferred rent liability.
916365_11_ITEM8_P80_S0	We occasionally receive reimbursements from landlords to be used towards improving the related store to be leased.
916365_11_ITEM8_P80_S1	Reimbursements are primarily for the purpose of performing work required to divide a much larger location into smaller segments, one of which we will use for our store.
916365_11_ITEM8_P80_S2	This work could include the addition of demising walls, separation of plumbing, utilities, electric work, entrances (front and back) and other work as required.
916365_11_ITEM8_P81_S0	Leasehold improvements are recorded at their gross costs including items reimbursed by landlords.
916365_11_ITEM8_P81_S1	Related reimbursements are amortized on a straight-line basis as a reduction of rent expense over the initial lease term.
916365_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_11_ITEM8_P83_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, we first compare the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated undiscounted future cash flows.
916365_11_ITEM8_P83_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_11_ITEM8_P83_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_11_ITEM8_P84_S0	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, we calculate an impairment loss.
916365_11_ITEM8_P84_S1	et s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_11_ITEM8_P85_S0	We recognize an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_11_ITEM8_P85_S1	If we recognize an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_11_ITEM8_P86_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining useful life of that asset.
916365_11_ITEM8_P87_S0	In fiscal 2010, the company recognized impairment charges of $1.1 million related to the write-off of certain capitalized software development costs.
916365_11_ITEM8_P87_S1	These assets were not expected to provide any future benefit to the Company and were determined to have no significant fair value.
916365_11_ITEM8_P87_S2	During fiscal year 2009 impairment charges of $0.8 million were recorded representing the amount required to write-down the carrying value of certain leasehold improvements to the assets estimated fair value.
916365_11_ITEM8_P87_S3	Impairment charges are included in SG A expenses in the Consolidated Statement of Income.
916365_11_ITEM8_P87_S4	No significant impairment charges were recognized in fiscal 2008.
916365_11_ITEM8_P88_S0	Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are not amortized.
916365_11_ITEM8_P88_S1	We evaluate goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of the goodwill may not be recoverable.
916365_11_ITEM8_P88_S2	We complete our impairment evaluation by performing internal valuation analyses, considering other publicly available market information and using an independent valuation firm, as appropriate.
916365_11_ITEM8_P89_S0	All goodwill at December 25, 2010 is associated with the Company as a whole.
916365_11_ITEM8_P89_S1	At December 26, 2009 all goodwill was associated with the Del s business and, for purposes of the fiscal 2009 impairment testing, Del s was considered the reporting unit.
916365_11_ITEM8_P89_S2	In October 2010, we reevaluated the Del s reporting unit and concluded that since Del s has be come closely aligned in terms of management, infrastructure, philosophy and performance, we now have only one reporting unit for goodwill impairment evaluation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P90_S0	The test for goodwill impairment is a two step process.
916365_11_ITEM8_P91_S0	The first step of the goodwill impairment test, used to identify the potential for impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with the carrying value of its net assets, including goodwill.
916365_11_ITEM8_P91_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit, the second step of the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recorded, if any.
916365_11_ITEM8_P91_S2	The second step, if required, would compare the implied fair value of goodwill with the current carrying amount of goodwill.
916365_11_ITEM8_P91_S3	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value, an impairment charge would be recorded as a charge to our operations.
916365_11_ITEM8_P92_S0	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010, we completed our annual impairment testing of goodwill and determined there was no impairment.
916365_11_ITEM8_P92_S1	We determined that the fair value of the reporting unit (including goodwill) was in excess of the carrying value of the reporting unit and as such, the second step was not necessary.
916365_11_ITEM8_P92_S2	In reaching this conclusion, the fair value of the reporting unit was determined based on a market approach.
916365_11_ITEM8_P93_S0	Under the market approach, the fair value is based on observed market prices.
916365_11_ITEM8_P94_S0	Advertising costs consist of expenses incurred in connection with newspaper circulars, television and radio, as well as direct mail, newspaper advertisements and other promotions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P94_S1	Costs are expensed when incurred with the exception of television advertising and circular and direct mail promotions, which are expensed upon first showing.
916365_11_ITEM8_P94_S2	Advertising expenses for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 were approximately $48.6 million, $45.7 million and $58.0 million, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P94_S3	Prepaid advertising costs were approximately $0.1 million and $0.2 million at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P95_S0	We account for income taxes using the liability method, whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities and are measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
916365_11_ITEM8_P96_S0	Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average number of shares outstanding during the period.
916365_11_ITEM8_P96_S1	Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average diluted shares outstanding.
916365_11_ITEM8_P96_S2	Diluted shares are computed using the treasury stock method for options and restricted stock units.
916365_11_ITEM8_P97_S0	Share-based compensation includes stock option and restricted stock unit awards and certain transactions under our Employee Stock Purchase Plan (the ESPP ).
916365_11_ITEM8_P97_S1	Share-based compensation expense is recognized based on grant date fair value of all options and restricted stock unit awards plus a discount on shares purchased by employees as a part of the ESPP.
916365_11_ITEM8_P97_S2	The discount under the ESPP represents the difference between the grant date market value and the employee s purchase price.
916365_11_ITEM8_P98_S0	Share-based compensation expense including reductions in expense for modifications of awards was $11.8 million, $12.1 million and $12.3 million for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P99_S0	Forfeitures are estimated at the time of valuation and reduce expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_11_ITEM8_P99_S1	This estimate is adjusted periodically based on the extent to which actual forfeitures differ, or are expected to differ, from the previous estimate.
916365_11_ITEM8_P100_S0	Effective May 7, 2009, the Company adopted the 2009 Stock Incentive Plan replacing the 2006 Stock Incentive Plan.
916365_11_ITEM8_P100_S1	Following the adoption of the 2009 Stock Incentive Plan, no further grants may be made under the 2006 Stock Incentive Plan.
916365_11_ITEM8_P101_S0	Under our 2009 Stock Incentive Plan, options may be granted to officers, non-employee directors and other employees.
916365_11_ITEM8_P101_S1	The per share exercise price of options granted shall not be less than the fair market value of the stock on the date of grant and such options will expire no later than ten years from the date of grant.
916365_11_ITEM8_P101_S2	Also, the aggregate fair market value of the stock with respect to which incentive stock options are exercisable on a tax deferred basis for the first time by an individual in any calendar year may not exceed $100,000.
916365_11_ITEM8_P102_S0	Vesting of options commences at various anniversary dates following the dates of grant.
916365_11_ITEM8_P103_S0	Under the terms of the 2009 Stock Incentive Plan, a maximum of 6,200,000 shares are available for grant as stock options or other awards.
916365_11_ITEM8_P103_S1	At December 25, 2010, we had 5,146,530 shares available for future equity awards under the Company s 2009 Stock Incentive Plan.
916365_11_ITEM8_P104_S0	The fair value of each option grant is separately estimated for each vesting date.
916365_11_ITEM8_P104_S1	The fair value of each option is recognized as compensation expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_11_ITEM8_P105_S0	We have estimated the fair value of all stock option awards as of the date of the grant by applying a Black-Scholes pricing valuation model.
916365_11_ITEM8_P105_S1	The application of this valuation model involves assumptions that are judgmental and highly sensitive in the determination of compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P105_S2	The weighted averages for key assumptions used in determining the fair value of options granted during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, as well as a summary of the methodology applied to develop each assumption, are as follows:
916365_11_ITEM8_P106_S0	This is a measure of the amount by which a price has fluctuated or is expected to fluctuate.
916365_11_ITEM8_P106_S1	We use actual historical changes in the market value of the stock to calculate expected price volatility because we believe that this is the best indicator of future volatility.
916365_11_ITEM8_P106_S2	We calculate daily market value changes from the date of grant over a past period generally representative of the expected life of the options to determine volatility.
916365_11_ITEM8_P106_S3	An increase in the expected volatility will increase compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P107_S0	This is the U.S. Treasury Constant Maturity rate over a term equal to the expected life of the option.
916365_11_ITEM8_P107_S1	An increase in the risk-free interest rate will increase compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P108_S0	This is the period of time over which the options granted are expected to remain outstanding and is based on historical experience.
916365_11_ITEM8_P108_S1	Options granted generally have a maximum term of ten years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P108_S2	An increase in the expected life will increase compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P109_S0	Forfeiture Rate This is the estimated percentage of options granted that are expected to be forfeited or cancelled before becoming fully vested.
916365_11_ITEM8_P109_S1	This estimate is based on historical experience.
916365_11_ITEM8_P109_S2	An increase in the forfeiture rate will decrease compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P110_S0	This is the estimated dividend yield for the weighted average expected life of the option granted.
916365_11_ITEM8_P110_S1	An increase in the dividend yield will decrease compensation expense.
916365_11_ITEM8_P111_S0	We issue new shares for options when exercised.
916365_11_ITEM8_P111_S1	A summary of stock option activity is as follows:
916365_11_ITEM8_P112_S0	The aggregate intrinsic values in the table above represents the total difference between our closing stock price at each year-end and the option exercise price, multiplied by the number of in-the-money options at each year-end.
916365_11_ITEM8_P113_S0	As of December 25, 2010, total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested stock options is $9,156,000 with a weighted average expense recognition period of 1.4 years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P114_S0	There were no material modifications to options in 2010, 2009 or 2008.

916365_11_ITEM8_P116_S1	The units vest over a one to three-year term.

916365_11_ITEM8_P117_S0	Other information relative to restricted unit activity during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 is as follows (in thousands):
916365_11_ITEM8_P118_S0	For the majority of restricted stock units granted, the number of shares issued on the date the restricted stock units vest is net of the minimum statutory tax withholding requirements that we pay on behalf of our employees.
916365_11_ITEM8_P118_S1	We issued 90,203, 10,896, and 2,020 shares as a result of vested restricted stock units during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P118_S2	The 2010 amount is net of 28,981 shares, withheld to satisfy $0.8 million of employees tax obligations.
916365_11_ITEM8_P118_S3	Although shares withheld are not issued, they are treated similar to common stock repurchases as they reduce the number of shares that would have been issued upon vesting.
916365_11_ITEM8_P119_S0	There were no material modifications to restricted stock units in 2010, 2009, or 2008.
916365_11_ITEM8_P120_S0	As of December 25, 2010, total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested restricted stock units is $4,705,000 with a weighted average expense recognition period of 1.7 years.
916365_11_ITEM8_P121_S0	The ESPP provides our employees the opportunity to purchase, through payroll deductions, shares of common stock at a 15% discount.
916365_11_ITEM8_P121_S1	Pursuant to the terms of the ESPP, we issued 74,788, 101,470 and 122,696 shares of common stock during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P121_S2	The total cost related to the ESPP, including the compensation expense calculations, was approximately $439,000, $449,000 and $485,000 in fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P121_S3	In connection with the stock split, the number of shares of our common stock that are reserved under the ESPP increased from 4,000,000 shares to 8,000,000 shares.
916365_11_ITEM8_P121_S4	At December 25, 2010, there were 6,299,852 shares of common stock reserved for future issuance under the ESPP.
916365_11_ITEM8_P122_S0	There were no significant modifications to the Company's share-based compensation plans during fiscal 2010.
916365_11_ITEM8_P123_S0	We are party to a Senior Credit Facility with Bank of America, N.A., as agent for a lender group (the Credit Agreement ), which provides for borrowings up to $350 million (with sublimits of $75 million and $20 million for letters of credit and swingline loans, respectively).
916365_11_ITEM8_P123_S1	The Credit Agreement has an Increase Option for $150 million (subject to additional lender group commitments).
916365_11_ITEM8_P123_S2	The Credit Agreement is unsecured and matures in February 2012, with proceeds expected to be used for working capital, capital expenditures and share repurchases.
916365_11_ITEM8_P124_S0	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, there were no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement.
916365_11_ITEM8_P124_S1	There were $27.4 million and $35.2 million outstanding letters of credit as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P124_S2	Borrowings bear interest at either the bank s base rate (3.25% at December 25, 2010) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate (0.26% at December 25, 2010) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.35% to 0.90% per annum, adjusted quarterly based on our performance (0.40% at December 25, 2010).
916365_11_ITEM8_P124_S3	We are also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee ranging from 0.06% to 0.18% per annum and adjusted quarterly based on our performance, for unused capacity (0.075% at December 25, 2010).
916365_11_ITEM8_P124_S4	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the Credit Agreement.
916365_11_ITEM8_P125_S0	The Credit Agreement requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_11_ITEM8_P125_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio principally compares consolidated EBITDAR to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding straight-line rent).
916365_11_ITEM8_P125_S2	The leverage ratio principally compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding straight-line rent) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_11_ITEM8_P125_S3	The Credit Agreement also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_11_ITEM8_P125_S4	We were in compliance with all covenants at December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S0	We lease the majority of our office space and retail store locations, certain distribution centers, transportation equipment and other equipment under various noncancellable operating leases.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S1	The leases have varying terms and expire at various dates through 2029 and 2025 for capital leases and operating leases, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S2	Store leases typically have initial terms of between 10 and 15 years, with two to four optional renewal periods of five years each.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S3	Some leases require the payment of contingent rent that is based upon store sales above agreed-upon sales levels for the year.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S4	The sales levels vary for each store and are established in the lease agreements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P126_S5	Generally, most of the leases also require that we pay associated taxes, insurance and maintenance costs.
916365_11_ITEM8_P127_S0	Total rent expense for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 was approximately $169.4 million, $162.2 million and $144.4 million, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P127_S1	Total contingent rent expense for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 was insignificant.

916365_11_ITEM8_P129_S0	Assets under capital leases were as follows (in thousands):

916365_11_ITEM8_P131_S0	We have a Board-approved share repurchase program which provides for repurchase of up to $400 million of common stock, exclusive of any fees, commissions, or other expenses related to such repurchases, through December 2011.
916365_11_ITEM8_P131_S1	The repurchases may be made from time to time on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P131_S2	The timing and amount of any shares repurchased under the program will depend on a variety of factors, including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, capital availability, and other market conditions.
916365_11_ITEM8_P131_S3	Repurchased shares will be held in treasury.
916365_11_ITEM8_P131_S4	The program may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.

916365_11_ITEM8_P144_S0	Note 9 - Retirement Benefit Plans:
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S0	We have a defined contribution benefit plan, the Tractor Supply Company 401(k) Retirement Savings Plan (the Plan ), which provides retirement benefits for our employees.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S1	Employees become eligible on the first month following their fulfillment of the eligibility requirements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S2	To be eligible, an employee must be at least 21 years of age, have completed 12 months of employment, and performed 1,000 hours of service in a year of service as defined by the Plan.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S3	We match (in cash) 100% of the employee s elective contributions up to 3% of the employee s eligible compensation plus 50% of the employee s elective contributions from 3% to 6% of the employee s eligible compensation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S4	In no event shall the total Company match made on behalf of the employee exceed 4.5% of the employee s eligible compensation.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S5	All current contributions are immediately 100% vested.
916365_11_ITEM8_P145_S6	Company contributions to the Plan during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, were approximately $3.7 million, $3.2 million and $2.8 million, respectively.
916365_11_ITEM8_P146_S0	We offer, through a deferred compensation program, the opportunity for certain qualifying employees to elect a deferral of up to 40% of their annual base salary and up to 100% of their annual incentive bonus under their respective incentive bonus programs.
916365_11_ITEM8_P146_S1	To be eligible for the salary deferral, each participant must contribute the maximum amount of salary to the Plan subject to the Company s match.
916365_11_ITEM8_P146_S2	Under the deferred compensation program, the participants salary deferral is matched by the Company, 100% on the first $3,000 of base salary contributed and 50% on the next $3,000 of base salary contributed limited to a maximum annual matching contribution of $4,500.
916365_11_ITEM8_P147_S0	Each participant s account earns simple annual interest at the prime rate as in effect on January 1 each year.
916365_11_ITEM8_P147_S1	Ea ch participant is fully vested in all amounts credited to their deferred compensation account.
916365_11_ITEM8_P147_S2	Payments under the program, which are made in cash and paid in ten annual installments or in a single lump sum payment at the election of the participant, are made within 30 days following the earlier of the participant s (i) death, (ii) retirement, plus six months if the participant is a key employee, (iii) total and permanent disability, (iv) separation from service, plus six months if the participant is a key employee, or (v) some other date designated by the participant at the time of the initial deferral.
916365_11_ITEM8_P147_S3	The Company s contributions, including accrued interest, were $0.3 million in each of the fiscal years 2010, 2009 and 2008.
916365_11_ITEM8_P148_S0	At December 25, 2010, we had commitments related to construction projects for new stores and a distribution center totaling approximately $32.2 million.
916365_11_ITEM8_P149_S0	The Company received and responded to a Request for Information from the United States Environmental Protection Agency ( EPA ) relating to certain recreational vehicles and non-road spark ignition engines sold by the Company.
916365_11_ITEM8_P149_S1	In the first quarter of fiscal 2011, the Environmental Enforcement Section of the Department of Justice ( DOJ ), on behalf of the EPA, informed the Company that it believed the Company had violated the Clean Air Act by importing or causing the importation of certain engines not covered by certificates of conformity issued by the EPA, and that unless the DOJ and the Company were able to reach a settlement, the DOJ was prepared to commence a civil action.
916365_11_ITEM8_P149_S2	The Company is currently engaged in settlement discussions with the DOJ that would call for the payment of a civil penalty and c ertain injunctive relief.
916365_11_ITEM8_P150_S0	The engines were purchased by the Company pursuant to agreements with vendors under which the vendors represented that their products complied with all applicable laws and regulations and under which the vendors agreed to indemnify the Company for any liabilities or costs relating to, among other matters, the noncompliance or alleged noncompliance of their products.
916365_11_ITEM8_P150_S1	The Company has notified these vendors of the EPA s position and expects to be reimbursed for any liabilities or costs relating to this matter.
916365_11_ITEM8_P150_S2	The Company does not expect the resolution of this matter to have a material adverse effect on its financial condition or results of operations.
916365_11_ITEM8_P151_S0	We are also involved in various litigation matters arising in the ordinary course of business.
916365_11_ITEM8_P151_S1	Management expects these matters will be resolved without material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position or results of operations.
916365_11_ITEM8_P151_S2	We believe that any estimated loss related to such matters has been adequately provided in accrued liabilities to the extent probable and reasonably estimable.
916365_11_ITEM8_P151_S3	It is possible, however, that future results of operations for any particular quarterly or annual period could be materially affected by changes in circumstances relating to these proceedings.
916365_11_ITEM8_P152_S0	Note 11 - Impact of Recently Issued Accounting Standards:
916365_11_ITEM8_P153_S0	In June 2009, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) Topic 810 (originally issued as Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 167, Amendments to FASB Interpretation No. ( FIN ) 46(R) ).
916365_11_ITEM8_P153_S1	Among other items, ASC 810 responds to concerns about an enterprise s application of certain key provisions of FIN 46(R), including those regarding the transparency of the enterprise s involvement with variable interest entities.
916365_11_ITEM8_P154_S0	ASC 810 is effective for the first annual period that begins after November 15, 2009, and for interim periods within that first annual reporting period.
916365_11_ITEM8_P154_S1	The Company adopted the standard for the interim period ended March 27, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM8_P154_S2	There was no impact on the C ompany s financial position, results of operations, cash flows, or disclosures.
916365_11_ITEM8_P155_S0	In February 2010, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2010-09 (ASU No. 2010-09), Subsequent Events (Topic 855): Amendments to Certain Recognition and Disclosure Requirements.
916365_11_ITEM8_P155_S1	The amendments remove the requirements for an SEC filer to disclose a date, in both issued and revised financial statements, through which subsequent events have been reviewed.
916365_11_ITEM8_P156_S0	Revised financial statements include financial statements revised as a result of either correction of an error or retrospective application of U.S. GAAP.
916365_11_ITEM8_P156_S1	ASU No. 2010-09 was effective upon issuance.
916365_11_ITEM8_P156_S2	The adoption of this guidance did not have an impact on our financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.
916365_11_ITEM8_P157_S0	On February 4, 2011, we announced that our board of directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.07 per share of the Company s common stock.
916365_11_ITEM8_P157_S1	The dividend will be paid on March 8, 2011 to stockholders of record as of the close of business on February 22, 2011.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We carried out an evaluation required by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the 1934 Act ), under the supervision and with the participation of our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the 1934 Act) as of December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Disclosure controls and procedures include, without limitation, controls and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by an issuer in the reports that it files or submits under the 1934 Act is accumulated and communicated to the issuer s management, including its principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Based on this evaluation, our principal executive officer and principal financial officer concluded that, as of December 25, 2010, our disclosure controls and procedures were effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in the reports that we file or submit under the 1934 Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the 1934 Act.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal Control Integrated Framework.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on this assessment, management believes that, as of December 25, 2010, the Company s internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Ernst Young LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm which also audited the Company s consolidated financial statements, has issued a report on the Company s internal control over financial reporting, which is included herein.
916365_11_ITEM9A_P5_S0	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during our last fiscal quarter that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect our internal control over financial reporting.
