916365_12_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following selected financial data is derived from the consolidated financial statements of Tractor Supply Company.
916365_12_ITEM6_P0_S1	Our fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_12_ITEM6_P0_S2	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_12_ITEM6_P0_S3	Fiscal year 2011 consisted of 53 weeks while all other fiscal years below consisted of 52 weeks.
916365_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	The following table provides summary historical financial information for the periods ended and as of the dates indicated (in thousands, except per share amounts and selected operating and other data):
916365_12_ITEM6_P2_S0	(a) Basic net income per share is calculated based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding applied to net income.
916365_12_ITEM6_P2_S1	Diluted net income per share is calculated using the treasury stock method for stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_12_ITEM6_P3_S0	(b) Same-store sales increases (decreases) are calculated on an annual basis, including relocations in 2011, 2010, 2009 and 2008 and excluding relocations in 2007, using all stores open at least one year.
916365_12_ITEM6_P4_S0	(c) Average sales per store is calculated based on total sales divided by the weighted average number of stores open in the year.
916365_12_ITEM6_P5_S0	(d) Long-term debt includes borrowings under the Company's revolving credit agreement and amounts outstanding under its capital lease obligations, excluding the current portion.
916365_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States and is focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	We operate retail stores under the names Tractor Supply Company and Del s Farm Supply and operate a website under the name TractorSupply.com .
916365_12_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our stores are located in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities, and they offer the following comprehensive selection of merchandise:
916365_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	We operated 1,085 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states as of December 31, 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	Given the size of the communities that we target, we believe that there is ample opportunity for new store growth in existing and new markets.
916365_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified over 1,000 additional markets for new Tractor Supply stores, inclusive of recently identified small market locations.
916365_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	Approximately 55% of our stores are in freestanding buildings and 45% are located in strip shopping centers.
916365_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	Fiscal 2011 was once again a year of strong performance for our Company.
916365_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	We achieved double-digit increases in both sales and earnings on top of last year s record results.
916365_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	In fiscal 2011, our net revenues increased 16.3% to $4.23 billion compared to $3.64 billion in fiscal 2010, and we increased our fiscal 2011 diluted earnings per share to $3.01 versus $2.25 in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	We also ended the year with $199 million in cash and restricted cash after returning nearly $211 million to our stockholders through stock repurchases and dividends.
916365_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	Over the past five years we have experienced considerable sales growth, with a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 12.3%.
916365_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	We plan to open 90 to 95 new stores in 2012, a selling square footage increase of approximately 8.0%.
916365_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	We opened 85 new stores in 2011 and 74 new stores in 2010, a square footage increase of approximately 7.8% and 7.4%, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our current and long-term growth strategy is to: (1) expand geographic market presence through opening new retail stores, (2) enhance financial performance through same-store sales growth achieved through targeted merchandising programs with an everyday value prices philosophy and supported by strong customer service, (3) enhance product margin through strategic product sourcing and regional allocation, a strong private label offering, and optimization of product pricing, transportation and distribution costs, (4) leverage operating costs, especially advertising, distribution and corporate overhead by focusing on opportunities for continuous improvement and elimination of waste in all of our processes, (5) expand market opportunities via internet sales accomplished by improving our product content and enhancing our customers online experience and (6) expand through selective acquisition, as such opportunities arise, to enhance penetration into new and existing markets as a complementary strategy to organic growth.
916365_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	Our store strategy features low initial capital expenditures, limited maintenance capital, and low occupancy and operating costs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	The average cash investment for new leased stores opened in 2011 was approximately $1.2 million.
916365_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	A majority of the cash outlay was for initial acquisition of inventory and capital expenditures (principally leasehold improvements, fixtures and equipment), and approximately $82,000 for pre-opening costs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P6_S3	Our new stores are typically profitable in the first full year of operation and reach chain average in approximately five years.
916365_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	Our capital allocation strategy focuses first on capital expenditure requirements (to support growth and invest in existing facilities and improved information technology processes and systems), and promotes effective stockholder return through our share repurchase and dividend programs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	Our capital expenditures for fiscal 2011 and 2010 were $166.2 million and $96.5 million, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	We expect capital expenditures in 2012 to be approximately $160 million to $170 million as we continue to invest in new store growth, existing stores, distribution center capacity and information technology.
916365_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	We place significant emphasis on our merchandising programs, evaluating the sales and profitability of our products through detailed line reviews, review of vendor performance measures and modification of the overall product offerings.
916365_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	Modifications of product offerings include increasing the quality and affordability of some items through strategic sourcing, improving our private label offerings and ensuring we have the best product mix in our stores based on the regional needs of our customers.
916365_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	We believe these efforts, coupled with a strong marketing program and in-depth product knowledge training of our store team members, have enhanced our sales and financial performance.
916365_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	Management s discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make informed estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
916365_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our financial position and/or results of operations may be materially different when reported under different conditions or when using different assumptions in the application of such policies.
916365_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	In the event estimates or assumptions prove to be different from actual amounts, adjustments are made in subsequent periods to reflect more current information.
916365_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Our significant accounting policies are disclosed in Note 1 to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
916365_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	The following discussion addresses our most critical accounting policies, which are those that are both important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results of operations and that require significant judgment or use of complex estimates.
916365_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	We identify potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	The estimated inventory valuation reserve to recognize any impairment in value (i.e., an inability to realize the full carrying value) is based on our aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	We do not believe our merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our impairment reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding forecasted customer demand and the promotional environment.
916365_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize inventory impairment reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate impairment.
916365_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	However, if assumptions regarding consumer demand or clearance potential for certain products are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	A 10% change in our impairment reserve at December 31, 2011, would have affected net income by approximately $590,000 in fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	We perform physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and we have established reserves for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods' sales volumes.
916365_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	We believe historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Our shrinkage reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding future shrinkage trends, the effect of loss prevention measures and new merchandising strategies.
916365_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize shrinkage in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate our shrinkage reserve.
916365_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	However, if our estimates regarding inventory losses are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	A 10% change in our shrinkage reserve at December 31, 2011, would have affected net income by approximately $860,000 in fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	We receive funding from substantially all of our significant merchandise vendors for the promotion of our brand as well as the sale of their products through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed funding and volume rebate programs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, which have varying expiration dates ranging in duration from several months to a few years.
916365_12_ITEM7_P24_S2	Many agreements are negotiated annually and are based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_12_ITEM7_P24_S3	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_12_ITEM7_P24_S4	During interim periods, the amount of expected funding is estimated based upon initial commitments, as well as anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	The estimated purchase volume and related vendor funding is based on our current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	Although we believe we can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related vendor funding at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could significantly differ from previously estimated amounts.
916365_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Our allocation methodology contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding customer demand, purchasing activity, target thresholds, vendor attrition and collectibility.
916365_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our vendor support reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	At the end of each fiscal year, a significant portion of the actual purchase activity is known.
916365_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	Thus, we do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the amounts recorded as vendor support.
916365_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	We do not believe there is a significant collectibility risk related to vendor support amounts due us at the end of fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	If a 10% reserve had been applied against our outstanding vendor support due as of December 31, 2011, net income would have been affected by approximately $1.2 million.
916365_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	Although it is unlikely that there will be any significant reduction in historical levels of vendor support, if such a reduction were to occur in future periods, the Company could experience a higher inventory balance and higher cost of sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	We incur various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	We allocate freight as a component of total cost of sales without regard to inventory mix or unique freight burden of certain categories.
916365_12_ITEM7_P33_S1	This assumption has been consistently applied for all years presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our capitalized freight balance or freight allocation in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	If a 10% increase or decrease had been applied against our current inventory capitalized freight balance, net income would have been affected by approximately $4.1 million.
916365_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	We self-insure a significant portion of our employee medical insurance, workers' compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	We have stop-loss insurance policies to protect from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	When estimating our self-insured liabilities, we consider a number of factors, including historical claims experience, demographic factors and severity factors.
916365_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers' compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	Our self-insured liabilities contain uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the ultimate cost to settle reported claims and claims incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date.
916365_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our self-insurance reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the assumptions we use to calculate insurance reserves.
916365_12_ITEM7_P41_S1	However, if we experience a significant increase in the number of claims or the cost associated with these claims, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P42_S0	A 10% change in our self-insurance reserves at December 31, 2011, would have affected net income by approximately $2.0 million in fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers.
916365_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	We obtain exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_12_ITEM7_P43_S2	Many of the states in which we conduct business will perform audits to verify our compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_12_ITEM7_P43_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_12_ITEM7_P43_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that we could be challenged as to the accuracy of our sales tax compliance.
916365_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	While we believe we reasonably enforce sales tax compliance with our customers and endeavor to fully comply with all applicable sales tax regulations, there can be no assurance that we, upon final completion of such audits, would not have a significant liability for disallowed exemptions.
916365_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	We review our past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to continually determine if we have potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_12_ITEM7_P45_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and our historical experience with each state.
916365_12_ITEM7_P45_S2	We continually reassess the exposure based on historical audit results, changes in policies, preliminary and final assessments made by state sales tax auditors, and additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	Our sales tax audit reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits, and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our sales tax audit assessment methodology remained materially consistent in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate the sales tax liability reserve.
916365_12_ITEM7_P48_S1	However, if our estimates regarding the ultimate sales tax liability are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	A 10% change in our sales tax audit reserve at December 31, 2011, would have affected net income by approximately $720,000 in fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	Our income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_12_ITEM7_P50_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_12_ITEM7_P50_S3	In evaluating the exposures associated with our various tax filing positions, we record a liability for unrecognized tax benefits resulting from uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
916365_12_ITEM7_P50_S4	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which we have established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	We recognize the effect of income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained.
916365_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely of being realized.
916365_12_ITEM7_P51_S2	Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	We adjust our tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from our established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	Our tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our tax contingencies in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the reserves established for tax benefits not recognized.
916365_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	Although management believes that the judgments and estimates discussed herein are reasonable, actual results could differ, and we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	To the extent we prevail in matters for which reserves have been established, or are required to pay amounts in excess of our reserves, our effective income tax rate in a given financial statement period could be materially affected.
916365_12_ITEM7_P57_S1	An unfavorable tax settlement would require use of our cash and would result in an increase in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_12_ITEM7_P57_S2	A favorable tax settlement would be recognized as a reduction in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	A 10% change in our unrecognized tax benefit reserve at December 31, 2011 would have affected net income by approximately $460,000 in fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, we first compare the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges).
916365_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, we calculate an impairment loss.
916365_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	We recognize an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_12_ITEM7_P61_S3	If we recognize an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining estimated useful life of that asset.
916365_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Our impairment loss calculations contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate future cash flows and asset fair values, including forecasting useful lives of the assets and selecting the discount rate that reflects the risk inherent in future cash flows.
916365_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	We have not made any material changes in our impairment loss assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the estimates or assumptions we use to calculate long-lived asset impairment losses.
916365_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	None of these estimates and assumptions are significantly sensitive, and a 10% change in any of these estimates would not have a material impact on our analysis.
916365_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	However, if actual results are not consistent with our estimates and assumptions used in estimating future cash flows and asset fair values, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	Our unaudited quarterly operating results for each fiscal quarter of 2011 and 2010 are shown below (in thousands, except per share amounts):
916365_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	Our fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	The fiscal year ended December 31, 2011 consisted of 53 weeks while fiscal years ended December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 contained 52 weeks.
916365_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain items in our Consolidated Statements of Income expressed as a percentage of net sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	(a) Our gross margin amounts may not be comparable to those of other retailers since some retailers include all of the costs related to their distribution network in cost of merchandise sold and others like us exclude a portion of these distribution network costs from gross margin and instead include them in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses; refer to Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	Net sales increased 16.3% to $4.23 billion in fiscal 2011 from $3.64 billion in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S1	Fiscal 2011 included an additional week compared to fiscal 2010, representing approximately 170 basis points of the net sales increase.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S2	Same-store sales for fiscal 2011 were $3.99 billion, an 8.2% increase over fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S3	This compares to a 7.0% same-store sales increase in the prior year.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S4	The same-store transaction count increased 5.0%, while same-store average ticket increased 3.1% for fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S5	The same-store sales increase was driven by continued strong results in core consumable, usable and edible (C.U.E.) products, principally animal and pet-related merchandise.
916365_12_ITEM7_P70_S6	Emergency response related merchandise also performed well during the year as a result of Hurricane Irene and tornadoes across the southeast.
916365_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	We estimate that same-store sales were favorably impacted by approximately 340 basis points due to inflation, principally in key C.U.E. categories.
916365_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	Additionally, fiscal 2011 had one additional comp sales day in the year, which had a favorable impact on same-store sales of approximately 30 basis points.
916365_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	Store growth was approximately 8.4%, a net increase of 84 stores since December 25, 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	Non-comp sales (defined as stores opened less than one year) for fiscal 2011 were $237.5 million, a 6.4% increase over total fiscal 2010 net sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	Non-comp sales for fiscal 2010 were $205.4 million, a 6.5% increase over total fiscal 2009 net sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	In fiscal 2011, we opened 85 new stores (compared to 74 new stores in fiscal 2010), relocated three stores (compared to no relocations in fiscal 2010) and closed one store (compared to three closed stores in fiscal 2010).
916365_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	The following chart indicates the percentage of sales represented by each of our major product categories during fiscal 2011 and 2010:
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	Gross margin increased 16.9% to $1.41 billion compared to $1.20 billion in 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased 10 basis points to 33.2% for fiscal 2011 compared to 33.1% for fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S2	The increase in gross margin reflects improved direct product margin, partially offset by increased transportation costs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S3	Direct product margin increased as we continue to make progress on our four strategic margin initiatives which include inventory management, strategic sourcing, private branding and price optimization.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S4	We expect the effects of inflation to continue into and potentially throughout the remainder of fiscal 2012.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S5	Additionally, we expect transportation costs to continue to increase as a result of rising fuel costs and planned increases in our import volume as a percent of total purchases.
916365_12_ITEM7_P75_S6	However, we expect that we will be able to maintain reasonable margins through effective sourcing of product and retail price management.
916365_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses including depreciation and amortization improved 90 basis points to 24.9% in fiscal 2011 from 25.8% in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	The SG A improvement as a percent of sales for fiscal 2011 was primarily attributable to the leverage of strong same-store sales and expense control with respect to store operating costs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	Total SG A expenses for fiscal 2011 increased 12.5% to $1.05 billion from $937.4 million in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P76_S3	The increase in SG A expense primarily reflects new store growth, variable costs associated with our same-store sales performance, increased advertising for print media and special promotional events and expansion of our distribution center capacity and ongoing implementation of the new warehouse management system.
916365_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	The Company s new Franklin, Kentucky distribution center opened in the fourth quarter of 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.5% for fiscal 2011 compared to 36.6% in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P78_S1	This reduction in the effective tax rate resulted from the favorable impact of certain federal tax credits as well as the utilization of various state income tax credits during fiscal 2011 compared to fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2011 increased 32.6% to $222.7 million, or $3.01 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $168.0 million, or $2.25 per diluted share, in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	During 2011, we repurchased approximately 3.1 million shares of stock at a total cost of $180.0 million as part of our previously announced $1 billion share repurchase program.
916365_12_ITEM7_P80_S1	In 2010, we repurchased approximately 0.8 million shares at a total cost of $38.2 million.
916365_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	Net sales increased 13.5% to $3.64 billion in fiscal 2010 from $3.21 billion in fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	Same-store sales for fiscal 2010 were $3.43 billion, a 7.0% increase over fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P81_S2	This compares to a 1.1% same-store sales decrease in the prior year.
916365_12_ITEM7_P81_S3	The same-store transaction count increased 7.4%, while same-store average ticket decreased 0.3% for fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P81_S4	The same-store sales increase was broad-based and driven by strong results in core consumable categories, principally animal and pet-related products, as well as seasonal products, including heating, insulated outerwear and outdoor power equipment.
916365_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	New store growth was approximately 7.6% or 71 net stores opened since December 26, 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P82_S1	Non-comp sales for fiscal 2010 were $205.4 million, a 6.5% increase over total fiscal 2009 net sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P82_S2	Non-comp sales for fiscal 2009 were $230.7 million, a 7.7% increase over total fiscal 2008 net sales.
916365_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	In fiscal 2010, we opened 74 new stores (compared to 76 new stores in fiscal 2009), relocated no stores (compared to two relocations in fiscal 2009) and closed three stores (compared to one closed store in fiscal 2009).
916365_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	The following chart indicates the percentage of sales represented by each of our major product categories during fiscal 2010 and 2009:
916365_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	Gross margin increased 15.5% to $1.20 billion compared to $1.04 billion in 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P85_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased 60 basis points to 33.1% for fiscal 2010 compared to 32.5% for fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P85_S2	The improvement in gross margin is primarily due to expanded direct product margin and a decrease in shrink, partially offset by increased transportation costs.
916365_12_ITEM7_P85_S3	The direct product margin improvement resulted from progress on certain margin driving initiatives which include strategic sourcing, inventory management, and more effective pricing.
916365_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses including depreciation and amortization improved 70 basis points to 25.8% in fiscal 2010 from 26.5% in fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	The SG A improvement as a percent of sales was primarily attributable to the leverage of strong same-store sales and expense management, partially offset by an increase in incentive compensation expense.
916365_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	Total SG A expenses increased 10.2% to $937.4 million from $850.3 million in fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P86_S3	The increase in SG A expense primarily reflects new store growth, variable costs associated with our same-store sales growth and increased incentive compensation.
916365_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.6% for fiscal 2010 compared to 36.9% in fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	This reduction in the effective tax rate resulted from a greater tax benefit received on the disqualified disposition of incentive stock options during fiscal 2010 compared to fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2010 increased 40.3% to $168.0 million, or $2.25 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $119.7 million, or $1.63 per diluted share, in fiscal 2009.
916365_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	During 2010, we repurchased approximately 0.8 million shares of stock at a total cost of $38.2 million as part of our previously announced share repurchase program.
916365_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	In 2009, we repurchased approximately 0.4 million shares at a total cost of $15.3 million.
916365_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	In addition to normal operating expenses, our primary ongoing cash requirements are for new store expansion, remodeling and relocation programs (including inventory purchases and capital expenditures), distribution center capacity and improvements, information technology, share repurchases and cash dividends.
916365_12_ITEM7_P90_S1	Our primary ongoing sources of liquidity are existing cash balances, funds provided from operations, borrowings available under our revolving credit agreement, capital and operating leases and normal trade credit.
916365_12_ITEM7_P90_S2	Our inventory and accounts payable levels typically build in the first and third fiscal quarters in anticipation of the spring and cold-weather selling seasons, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	At December 31, 2011, we had working capital of $629.6 million, a $12.5 million increase from December 25, 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P91_S1	This increase was primarily attributable to changes in the following components of current assets and current liabilities (in millions):
916365_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	In comparison to prior year-end, working capital increased primarily as a result of an increase in inventory, partially offset by a decrease in cash.
916365_12_ITEM7_P92_S1	The increase in inventory was primarily due to new store growth and inflation.
916365_12_ITEM7_P92_S2	Average inventory per store increased to $723,000 for fiscal 2011 compared to $709,000 for fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P92_S3	The decrease in cash is primarily attributable to an increased volume of share repurchases as well as an increase in capital expenditures, principally due to the construction of a new distribution center.
916365_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	Through October 23, 2011 we were party to a Senior Credit Facility (the Credit Agreement ), which provided for borrowings up to $350 million (with sublimits of $75 million and $20 million for letters of credit and swingline loans, respectively) with proceeds available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases and other matters.
916365_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	The Credit Agreement had an Increase Option for $150 million (subject to additional lender group commitments).
916365_12_ITEM7_P93_S2	The Credit Agreement was unsecured and would have matured in February 2012.
916365_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	On October 24, 2011, we entered into a new Senior Credit Facility with largely the same lender group as under the previous Credit Agreement.
916365_12_ITEM7_P94_S1	The new Senior Credit Facility provides for borrowings of up to $250 million (with sublimits of $250 million and $20 million for letters of credit and swingline loans, respectively).
916365_12_ITEM7_P94_S2	This agreement is unsecured and matures in October 2016, with proceeds available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases and other matters.
916365_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	At December 31, 2011 and December 25, 2010, there were no outstanding borrowings under either Senior Credit Facility.
916365_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	There were $15.0 million and $27.4 million outstanding letters of credit as of December 31, 2011 and December 25, 2010, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P96_S0	Borrowings bear interest at either the bank s base rate (3.25% at December 31, 2011) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) (0.30% at December 31, 2011) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.40% to 1.00% per annum, adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio (0.50% at December 31, 2011).
916365_12_ITEM7_P96_S1	We are also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee ranging from 0.08% to 0.20% per annum and adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio, for unused capacity (0.10% at December 31, 2011).
916365_12_ITEM7_P96_S2	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_12_ITEM7_P97_S0	The Senior Credit Facility requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_12_ITEM7_P97_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio principally compares earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, stock compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding straight-line rent).
916365_12_ITEM7_P97_S2	The leverage ratio principally compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding straight-line rent) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_12_ITEM7_P97_S3	The Senior Credit Facility also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_12_ITEM7_P97_S4	We were in compliance with all covenants at December 31, 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operations.
916365_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	Principal uses of cash for investing activities are capital expenditures, while uses of cash for financing activities are repurchase of the Company s common stock and payment of common stock dividends.
916365_12_ITEM7_P98_S2	The following table presents a summary of cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities for the last three fiscal years (in millions):
916365_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	The $31.5 million increase in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2011 over fiscal 2010 is primarily due to changes in the following operating activities (in millions):
916365_12_ITEM7_P100_S0	Cash flow from operating activities continues to provide the primary source of our liquidity.
916365_12_ITEM7_P100_S1	The increase in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2011 compared with fiscal 2010 was primarily due to stronger net income and the impact of higher depreciation and amortization expense partially offset by a decrease in cash provided by accrued expenses and an increase in cash used for prepaids and other current assets.
916365_12_ITEM7_P100_S2	The increase in depreciation and amortization expense is related to store growth and capital expenditures associated with the construction of a new distribution center.
916365_12_ITEM7_P100_S3	The decrease in cash provided by accrued expenses was primarily due to timing of payments.
916365_12_ITEM7_P100_S4	The increase in cash used for prepaids and other current assets is primarily due to timing of payments due from our vendors.
916365_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	The $7.3 million increase in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2010 over fiscal 2009 is primarily due to changes in the following operating activities (in millions):
916365_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	The increase in net cash provided by operations in fiscal 2010 compared with fiscal 2009 was primarily due to stronger net income and an increase in cash provided by accrued expenses partially offset by an increase in cash used for inventory, net of accounts payable, and a decrease in cash provided by prepaids and other current assets.
916365_12_ITEM7_P102_S1	Continued store growth has resulted in increased inventory balances.
916365_12_ITEM7_P102_S2	Accounts payable levels have decreased as a result of more timely payments in order to capture payment discounts offered by vendors and also as a result of an increase in cash held in our bank concentration account.
916365_12_ITEM7_P102_S3	The bank concentration account nets against the related book overdraft included in accounts payable.
916365_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	The increase in cash provided by accrued expenses is a result of timing of payments as well as incentive compensation earned in fiscal 2010 but not paid until fiscal 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P103_S1	The decrease in cash provided by prepaids and other current assets is primarily due to timing of payments due from our vendors.
916365_12_ITEM7_P104_S0	Investing activities used $171.3 million, $112.1 million and $73.8 million in fiscal 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P104_S1	The majority of this cash requirement relates to our capital expenditures.
916365_12_ITEM7_P104_S2	Our significant store expansion, coupled with distribution network expansion and other required investments in infrastructure, resulted in the following capital expenditures (in millions):
916365_12_ITEM7_P105_S0	The above table reflects 85 new stores and three relocations in fiscal 2011, compared to 74 new stores during fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P105_S1	We also purchased 12 of our existing lease stores during fiscal 2011 compared to four existing stores in fiscal 2010.
916365_12_ITEM7_P105_S2	The increase in capital expenditures for distribution center capacity in fiscal 2011 compared to fiscal 2010 is primarily due to the construction of a new distribution center in Franklin, Kentucky and the implementation of a new warehouse management system in two of our seven distribution centers.
916365_12_ITEM7_P106_S0	Our long-term growth strategy anticipates continued geographic market expansion and further concentration within existing markets.
916365_12_ITEM7_P106_S1	We currently estimate that capital expenditures will range between $160 million and $170 million in fiscal 2012.
916365_12_ITEM7_P106_S2	We plan to open approximately five to 10 more stores in fiscal 2012 compared to 2011.
916365_12_ITEM7_P106_S3	While we do not plan to open a new distribution center in fiscal 2012, we estimate to spend approximately $30 million on our distribution center network, principally for the acquisition of a site to relocate our southeast distribution center as well as other improvements in the existing distribution centers such as conveyor systems and other infrastructure enhancements.
916365_12_ITEM7_P106_S4	Additionally, we plan to invest approximately $30 million in information technology upgrades, including point-of-sale system enhancements, continued roll-out of the new warehouse management system to distribution centers, an upgrade of our e-commerce site, and store and store support center hardware refreshes.

916365_12_ITEM7_P108_S0	On April 28, 2011, the Company s Board of Directors authorized a $600 million increase to the existing share repurchase program, bringing the total amount authorized to date under the program to an aggregate of $1 billion of common stock, exclusive of any fees, commissions, or other expenses related to such repurchases, through April 2015.
916365_12_ITEM7_P108_S1	The repurchases may be made from time to time on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions.
916365_12_ITEM7_P108_S2	The timing and amount of any shares repurchased under the program will depend on a variety of factors, including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, capital availability, and other market conditions.
916365_12_ITEM7_P108_S3	Repurchased shares will be held in treasury.
916365_12_ITEM7_P108_S4	The program may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
916365_12_ITEM7_P109_S0	We repurchased approximately 3.1 million, 0.8 million and 0.4 million shares under the share repurchase program at a total cost of $180.0 million, $38.2 million and $15.3 million in fiscal 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
916365_12_ITEM7_P109_S1	Repurchased shares are accounted for at cost and will be held in treasury for future issuance.
916365_12_ITEM7_P109_S2	As of December 31, 2011, we had remaining authorization under the share repurchase program of $562.9 million exclusive of any fees, commissions, or other expenses.
