916365_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis is intended to provide the reader with information that will assist in understanding the significant factors affecting our consolidated operating results, financial condition, liquidity and capital resources during the three-year period ended December 28, 2013 (our fiscal years 2013 , 2012 and 2011 ).
916365_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	Fiscal years 2013 and 2012 contained 52 weeks of operating results compared to fiscal year 2011 which contained 53 weeks.
916365_14_ITEM7_P0_S2	This discussion should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and notes to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report.
916365_14_ITEM7_P0_S3	See "Forward-Looking Statements" and "Risk Factors" included elsewhere in this report.
916365_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States and is focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and others who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	As of December 28, 2013 , we operated 1,276 retail stores in 48 states under the names Tractor Supply Company and Del s Feed Farm Supply.
916365_14_ITEM7_P1_S2	We also operate a website under the name TractorSupply.com .
916365_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our stores are located primarily in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities, and they offer the following comprehensive selection of merchandise:
916365_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	Maintenance products for agricultural and rural use.
916365_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our current and long-term growth strategy is to: (1) expand geographic market presence through opening new retail stores, (2) enhance financial performance through comparable store sales growth achieved through targeted merchandising programs with an everyday value price philosophy and supported by strong customer service, (3) enhance product margin through strategic product sourcing, inventory and markdown management, a strong exclusive brand offering, and optimization of product pricing and transportation costs, (4) leverage operating costs by focusing on opportunities for continuous improvement and elimination of waste in all of our processes, (5) expand market opportunities via e-commerce and internet-supported sales accomplished by improving our website product content and enhancing our customers online experience and (6) expand through selective acquisition, as such opportunities arise, to enhance penetration into new and existing markets to complement organic growth.
916365_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	Over the past five years we have experienced considerable growth in stores, growing from 855 stores at the end of 2008 to 1,276 stores at the end of fiscal 2013 , and in sales, with a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 11.4% .
916365_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	Given the size of the communities that we target, we believe that there is ample opportunity for new store growth in existing and new markets.
916365_14_ITEM7_P5_S2	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified over 800 additional markets for new Tractor Supply stores.
916365_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	On August 28, 2013, our Board of Directors declared a two-for-one split of our outstanding shares of common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend.
916365_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	On September 26, 2013, stockholders of record at the close of business on September 18, 2013, received one additional share of common stock for each share owned by such stockholder.
916365_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	All share and per-share information in the Annual Report on Form 10-K has been retroactively restated to reflect the stock split.
916365_14_ITEM7_P6_S3	The total number of authorized common shares and the par value of each share was not changed by the split.
916365_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	We opened 102 new stores in 2013 and 93 new stores in 2012 , a selling square footage increase of approximately 8.3% and 7.9% , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	During 2013 , we opened stores in 34 states, including our first stores in Arizona, Nevada and Wyoming, and in 2014 we expect to continue our expansion into these new markets.
916365_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	We achieved strong performance in fiscal 2013 , delivering diluted earnings per share growth of 22.1%, $2.32 versus $1.90 in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Net sales increased 10.7% to $5.16 billion in fiscal 2013 from $4.66 billion in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	Comparable store sales increased 4.8% in fiscal 2013 versus a 5.3% increase in fiscal 2012.
916365_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	in fiscal 2012, and gross margin increased 40 basis points to 34.0% of sales in fiscal 2013 from 33.6% of sales in fiscal 2012.
916365_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	Operating profit increased 60 basis points to 10.0% of sales in fiscal 2013 from 9.4% of sales in fiscal 2012.
916365_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	In fiscal 2013, diluted earnings per share grew 22.1%, to $2.32 compared to $1.90 in fiscal 2012.
916365_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	We ended the year with approximately $143 million in cash, after returning nearly $198 million to our stockholders through stock repurchases and dividends.
916365_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	Management s discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make informed estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
916365_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	Our financial position and/or results of operations may be materially different when reported under different conditions or when using different assumptions in the application of such policies.
916365_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	In the event estimates or assumptions prove to be different from actual amounts, adjustments are made in subsequent periods to reflect more current information.
916365_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our significant accounting policies are disclosed in Note 1 to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
916365_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	The following discussion addresses our most critical accounting policies, which are those that are both important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results of operations and that require significant judgment or use of complex estimates.
916365_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	We identify potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	The estimated inventory valuation reserve to recognize any impairment in value (i.e., an inability to realize the full carrying value) is based on our aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	We do not believe our merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	Our impairment reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding forecasted customer demand and the promotional environment.
916365_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize inventory impairment reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate impairment.
916365_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	However, if assumptions regarding consumer demand or clearance potential for certain products are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	A 10% change in our impairment reserve at December 28, 2013, would have affected net income by approximately $0.4 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	We perform physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and we have established reserves for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods' sales volumes.
916365_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	We believe historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	Our shrinkage reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding future shrinkage trends, the effect of loss prevention measures and new merchandising strategies.
916365_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize shrinkage in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate our shrinkage reserve.
916365_14_ITEM7_P25_S1	However, if our estimates regarding inventory losses are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	A 10% change in our shrinkage reserve at December 28, 2013, would have affected net income by approximately $1.0 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	We receive funding from substantially all of our significant merchandise vendors, in support of our business initiatives, through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed vendor support funds ("vendor support") and volume-based rebate funds ("volume rebates").
916365_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, most of which are "evergreen", reflecting the on-going relationship with our significant merchandise vendors.
916365_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	Certain of our agreements, primarily volume rebates, are renegotiated annually, based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	During interim periods, the amount of vendor support is known and is debited to vendors systematically; however, volume rebates are estimated during interim periods based upon initial commitments and anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	The estimated purchase volume (and related vendor funding through volume rebates) is based on our current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	Although we believe we can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related volume rebates at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could differ from previously estimated amounts.
916365_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	Our allocation methodology contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding customer demand, purchasing activity, target thresholds, vendor attrition and collectibility.
916365_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our vendor support reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	At the end of each fiscal year, a significant portion of the actual purchase activity is known.
916365_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	Thus, we do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the amounts recorded as vendor support.
916365_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	We do not believe there is a significant collectibility risk related to vendor support amounts due us at the end of fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	If a 10% reserve had been applied against our outstanding vendor support due as of December 28, 2013, net income would have been affected by approximately $1.1 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	Although it is unlikely that there will be any significant reduction in historical levels of vendor support, if such a reduction were to occur in future periods, the Company could experience a higher inventory balance and higher cost of sales.
916365_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	We incur various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	We allocate freight as a component of total cost of sales without regard to inventory mix or unique freight burden of certain categories.
916365_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	This assumption has been consistently applied for all years presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our capitalized freight balance or freight allocation in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	If a 10% increase or decrease had been applied against our current inventory capitalized freight balance as of December 28, 2013, net income would have been affected by approximately $4.9 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Self-Insurance Reserves:
916365_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	We self-insure a significant portion of our employee medical insurance, workers' compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	We have stop-loss insurance policies to protect from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	When estimating our self-insured liabilities, we consider a number of factors, including historical claims experience, demographic factors and severity factors.
916365_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers' compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	Our self-insured liabilities contain uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the ultimate cost to settle reported claims and claims incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date based upon historical data and experience, including actuarial calculations.
916365_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our self-insurance reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the assumptions we use to calculate insurance reserves.
916365_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	However, if we experience a significant increase in the number of claims or the cost associated with these claims, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	A 10% change in our self-insurance reserves at December 28, 2013, would have affected net income by approximately $2.6 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers, predominantly agricultural-based.
916365_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	We obtain exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_14_ITEM7_P49_S2	Many of the states in which we conduct business will perform audits to verify our compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_14_ITEM7_P49_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_14_ITEM7_P49_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that we could be challenged as to the accuracy of our sales tax compliance.
916365_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	While we believe we appropriately enforce sales tax compliance with our customers and endeavor to fully comply with all applicable sales tax regulations, there can be no assurance that we, upon final completion of such audits, would not have a significant liability for disallowed exemptions.
916365_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	We review our past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to continually determine if we have potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and our historical experience with each state.
916365_14_ITEM7_P51_S2	We continually reassess the exposure based on historical audit results, changes in policies, preliminary and final assessments made by state sales tax auditors, and additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	Our sales tax audit reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	We have not made any material changes to our sales tax audit assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate the sales tax liability reserve.
916365_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	However, if our estimates regarding the ultimate sales tax liability are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	A 10% change in our sales tax audit reserve at December 28, 2013, would have affected net income by approximately $0.6 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Tax Contingencies:
916365_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Our income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	In evaluating the exposures associated with our various tax filing positions, we record a liability for uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
916365_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which we have established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	We recognize the effect of income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained.
916365_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely of being realized.
916365_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
916365_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	We adjust our tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from our established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	Our tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our tax contingencies in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the reserves established for tax benefits not recognized.
916365_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	Although management believes that the judgments and estimates discussed herein are reasonable, actual results could differ, and we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	To the extent we prevail in matters for which reserves have been established, or are required to pay amounts in excess of our reserves, our effective income tax rate in a given financial statement period could be materially affected.
916365_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	An unfavorable tax settlement would require use of our cash and would result in an increase in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_14_ITEM7_P65_S2	A favorable tax settlement would be recognized as a reduction in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	A 10% change in our uncertain tax position reserve at December 28, 2013 would have affected net income by approximately $0.2 million in fiscal 2013.
916365_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Impairment of Long-Lived Assets:
916365_14_ITEM7_P68_S0	Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_14_ITEM7_P69_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, we first compare the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges).
916365_14_ITEM7_P69_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_14_ITEM7_P69_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_14_ITEM7_P70_S0	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, we calculate an impairment loss.
916365_14_ITEM7_P70_S1	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_14_ITEM7_P70_S2	We recognize an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_14_ITEM7_P70_S3	If we recognize an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_14_ITEM7_P71_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining estimated useful life of that asset.
916365_14_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our impairment loss calculations contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate future cash flows and asset fair values, including forecasting useful lives of the assets and selecting the discount rate that reflects the risk inherent in future cash flows.
916365_14_ITEM7_P73_S0	We have not made any material changes in our impairment loss assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the estimates or assumptions we use to calculate long-lived asset impairment losses.
916365_14_ITEM7_P74_S1	None of these estimates and assumptions are significantly sensitive, and a 10% change in any of these estimates would not have a material impact on our analysis.
916365_14_ITEM7_P74_S2	However, if actual results are not consistent with our estimates and assumptions used in estimating future cash flows and asset fair values, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	Our unaudited quarterly operating results for each fiscal quarter of 2013 and 2012 are shown below (in thousands, except per share amounts):
916365_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	(a) Due to the nature of interim net income per share calculations, the sum of quarterly net income per share amounts may not equal the reported net income per share for the year.
916365_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	All net income per share amounts except the third quarter and fourth quarter of fiscal 2013 have been split adjusted.
916365_14_ITEM7_P77_S0	Our fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_14_ITEM7_P77_S1	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_14_ITEM7_P77_S2	The fiscal years ended December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 consisted of 52 weeks and the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011 consisted of 53 weeks.
916365_14_ITEM7_P78_S0	The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain items in our Consolidated Statements of Income expressed as a percentage of net sales.
916365_14_ITEM7_P79_S0	(a) Our gross margin amounts may not be comparable to those of other retailers since some retailers include all of the costs related to their distribution network in cost of merchandise sold and others (like the Company) exclude a portion of these distribution network costs from gross margin and instead include them in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses; refer to Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
916365_14_ITEM7_P80_S0	Net sales increased 10.7% to $5.16 billion in fiscal 2013 from $4.66 billion in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P80_S1	Comparable store sales for fiscal 2013 were $4.89 billion , a 4.8% increase over fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P80_S2	This compares to a 5.3% comparable store sales increase in the prior year.
916365_14_ITEM7_P80_S3	The comparable store transaction count increased 4.7% , while comparable store average ticket remained flat for fiscal 2013 , principally as a result of big ticket sales being less of the sales mix.
916365_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	Comparable store sales are calculated based on the change in net sales of stores open at least one year and exclude certain adjustments to net sales.
916365_14_ITEM7_P82_S0	The comparable store sales increase was driven by continued strong results in key consumable, usable, edible (C.U.E.) products, principally animal- and pet-related merchandise.
916365_14_ITEM7_P82_S1	This was a result of continued investment in C.U.E. inventory, expanded product assortments and improved localized product offerings.
916365_14_ITEM7_P82_S2	Winter seasonal merchandise, predominantly heating and insulated outerwear, also performed well during the first part of the year and the end of the year due to the colder than average weather.
916365_14_ITEM7_P82_S3	We also estimate that comparable store sales were favorably impacted by approximately 70 basis points due to inflation, principally in pet food and livestock feed.
916365_14_ITEM7_P83_S0	In addition to comparable store sales growth in fiscal 2013 , sales from new stores and stores opened less than one year were $281.2 million in fiscal 2013 , which represented 6.0 percentage points of the 10.7% increase over fiscal 2012 net sales.
916365_14_ITEM7_P83_S1	Sales from stores opened less than one year were $276.2 million in fiscal 2012 , which represented 6.5 percentage points of the 10.2% increase over fiscal 2011 net sales.

916365_14_ITEM7_P86_S0	Gross profit increased 12.0% to $1.75 billion in fiscal 2013 compared to $1.57 billion in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P86_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased 40 basis points to 34.0% for fiscal 2013 compared to 33.6% for fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P86_S2	This improvement in gross margin reflects improved direct product margin.
916365_14_ITEM7_P86_S3	Direct product margin increased as a result of continued progress on our four strategic margin initiatives which include inventory and markdown management, strategic sourcing, exclusive branding and retail price management.
916365_14_ITEM7_P87_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses, including depreciation and amortization, improved 20 basis points to 24.0% in fiscal 2013 from 24.2% in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P87_S1	The SG A improvement as a percent of sales was primarily attributable to the leverage of continued solid comparable store sales growth, expense control related to store operating costs and lower year-over-year incentive compensation expense, partially offset by costs related to the new and expanded Southeast distribution center and relocation of our corporate data center.
916365_14_ITEM7_P87_S2	Total SG A expenses for fiscal 2013 increased 9.7% to $1.24 billion from $1.13 billion in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P87_S3	The increase in SG A primarily reflects new store growth and variable costs associated with our comparable store sales growth as well as operating costs relating to our new and expanded Southeast distribution center and corporate data center.
916365_14_ITEM7_P88_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.2% for fiscal 2013 compared to 36.6% in fiscal 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P88_S1	The reduction in the tax rate resulted primarily from the favorable impact of the reversal of various reserves for uncertain tax positions.
916365_14_ITEM7_P89_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2013 increased 18.7% to $328.2 million , or $2.32 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $276.5 million , or $1.90 per diluted share, in fiscal 2012 .

916365_14_ITEM7_P97_S1	This improvement was primarily attributable to the leverage of continued strong comparable store sales, expense control related to store operating costs and lower year-over-year incentive compensation expense.

916365_14_ITEM7_P97_S3	The increase in SG A primarily reflects new store growth as well as operating costs relating to our Franklin, Kentucky distribution center, which became operational in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011, offset in part by the favorable impact of one less week in fiscal 2012 compared to fiscal 2011, as part of the Company's 53-week calendar in the prior year.

916365_14_ITEM7_P101_S0	In addition to normal operating expenses, our primary ongoing cash requirements are for new store expansion, remodeling and relocation programs, distribution center and store support center capacity and improvements, information technology, inventory purchases, share repurchases and cash dividends.
916365_14_ITEM7_P101_S1	Our primary ongoing sources of liquidity are existing cash balances, funds provided from operations, borrowings available under our Senior Credit Facility, capital and operating leases and normal trade credit.
916365_14_ITEM7_P101_S2	Our inventory and accounts payable levels typically build in the first and third fiscal quarters to support the higher sales volume of the spring and cold-weather selling seasons, respectively.
916365_14_ITEM7_P102_S0	At December 28, 2013 , the Company had working capital of $677.1 million , which increased $107.6 million from December 29, 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P102_S1	The shifts in working capital were attributable to changes in the following components of current assets and current liabilities (in millions):
916365_14_ITEM7_P103_S0	In comparison to December 29, 2012, working capital as of December 28, 2013 was impacted most significantly by changes in our inventory and income taxes payable.
916365_14_ITEM7_P104_S0	We actively manage our inventory balances and in-stock levels at our stores.
916365_14_ITEM7_P104_S1	The increase in inventory was primarily due to new store growth.
916365_14_ITEM7_P104_S2	Average inventory per store decreased 0.5% compared to the prior year.
916365_14_ITEM7_P105_S0	The timing of receipt of seasonal goods was much earlier in the fourth quarter in the current year and imports made up a larger percentage of fourth quarter receipts, requiring payment on trade credit prior to year end.
916365_14_ITEM7_P105_S1	These factors drove the decline in accounts payable.
916365_14_ITEM7_P106_S0	Income taxes payable decreased due to timing of estimated tax payments, as a result of changes in allowable deductions for depreciation expense.
916365_14_ITEM7_P107_S0	The Senior Credit Facility provides for borrowings of up to $250 million (with a sub-limit of $20 million for swing-line loans).
916365_14_ITEM7_P107_S1	The Senior Credit Facility has an Increase Option for $150 million (subject to additional lender group commitments).
916365_14_ITEM7_P107_S2	This agreement is unsecured and matures in October 2016 , with proceeds available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases and other matters.
916365_14_ITEM7_P108_S0	At December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , there were no outstanding borrowings under the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_14_ITEM7_P108_S1	There were $38.2 million and $51.4 million outstanding letters of credit under the Senior Credit Facility as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM7_P109_S0	Borrowings bear interest at either the bank s base rate ( 3.25% at December 28, 2013 ) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) ( 0.16% at December 28, 2013 ) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.40% to 1.00% per annum ( 0.50% at December 28, 2013 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM7_P109_S1	We are also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.08% to 0.20% per annum ( 0.10% at December 28, 2013 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM7_P109_S2	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_14_ITEM7_P110_S0	The Senior Credit Facility requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM7_P110_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio compares earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, stock compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments).
916365_14_ITEM7_P110_S2	The leverage ratio compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_14_ITEM7_P110_S3	The Senior Credit Facility also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_14_ITEM7_P110_S4	We were in compliance with all covenants at December 28, 2013 .
916365_14_ITEM7_P111_S0	Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operations.
916365_14_ITEM7_P111_S1	Principal uses of cash for investing activities are capital expenditures, while uses of cash for financing activities are repurchase of the Company s common stock and cash dividends paid to stockholders.

916365_14_ITEM7_P124_S3	Repurchased shares are accounted for at cost and will be held in treasury for future issuance.
916365_14_ITEM7_P124_S4	The program may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
