916365_14_ITEM7_P132_S0	Our off-balance sheet arrangements are limited to operating leases and outstanding letters of credit.
916365_14_ITEM7_P132_S1	The balances for these arrangements are previously discussed.
916365_14_ITEM7_P133_S0	We typically lease buildings for retail stores and offices rather than acquiring these assets which allows us to utilize financial capital to operate the business rather than invest in fixed assets.
916365_14_ITEM7_P133_S1	Letters of credit allow us to purchase inventory, primarily sourced overseas, in a timely manner and support certain risk management programs.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We may be exposed to changes in interest rates primarily from the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The Senior Credit Facility bears interest at either the bank s base rate ( 3.25% at both December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 ) or LIBOR ( 0.16% and 0.21% at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , respectively) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.40% to 1.00% per annum ( 0.50% at both December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We are also required to pay quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.08% to 0.20% per annum ( 0.10% at both December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Although we cannot determine the full effect of inflation and deflation on our operations, we believe our sales and results of operations are affected by both.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We are subject to market risk with respect to the pricing of certain products and services, which include, among other items, steel, grain, petroleum, corn, cotton and other commodities as well as transportation services.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Therefore, we may experience both inflationary and deflationary pressure on product cost, which may impact consumer demand and, as a result, sales and gross margin.
916365_14_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our strategy is to reduce or mitigate the effects of purchase price volatility principally by taking advantage of vendor incentive programs, economies of scale from increased volume of purchases, adjusting retail prices and selectively buying from the most competitive vendors without sacrificing quality.
916365_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended).
916365_14_ITEM8_P0_S1	The Company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
916365_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P2_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (1992 framework).
916365_14_ITEM8_P2_S2	Based on this assessment, management believes that, as of December 28, 2013 , the Company's internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
916365_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	Ernst Young LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm which also audited the Company's consolidated financial statements, has issued a report on the Company's internal control over financial reporting, which is included herein.
916365_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	We have audited Tractor Supply Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013 , based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (1992 framework) (the COSO criteria).
916365_14_ITEM8_P4_S1	Tractor Supply Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
916365_14_ITEM8_P4_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
916365_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
916365_14_ITEM8_P5_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
916365_14_ITEM8_P5_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
916365_14_ITEM8_P5_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
916365_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_14_ITEM8_P6_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P7_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
916365_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	In our opinion, Tractor Supply Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013 , based on the COSO criteria .
916365_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Tractor Supply Company as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three fiscal years in the period ended December 28, 2013 , and our report dated February 19, 2014 , expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
916365_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Tractor Supply Company as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three fiscal years in the period ended December 28, 2013 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
916365_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
916365_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
916365_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
916365_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
916365_14_ITEM8_P12_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
916365_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Tractor Supply Company at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three fiscal years in the period ended December 28, 2013 , in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Tractor Supply Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013 , based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (1992 framework) and our report dated February 19, 2014 , expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
916365_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	(a) All share and per share information has been adjusted to reflect the two-for-one stock split as discussed in Note 1.
916365_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these financial statements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	(a) All share and related dollar information has been adjusted to reflect the two-for-one stock split as discussed in Note 1.
916365_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these financial statements .
916365_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	(a) All share and related dollar information has been adjusted to reflect the two-for-one stock split as discussed in Note 1.
916365_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these financial statements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these financial statements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Tractor Supply Company (the Company ) is the largest operator of retail farm and ranch stores in the United States.
916365_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company is focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_14_ITEM8_P22_S2	Stores are located in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities.
916365_14_ITEM8_P22_S3	At December 28, 2013 , the Company operated a total of 1,276 retail farm and ranch stores in 48 states and also offered a number of products online at TractorSupply.com .
916365_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	The Company's fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_14_ITEM8_P23_S1	The fiscal years ended December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 consisted of 52 weeks and the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011 consisted of 53 weeks.
916365_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries.
916365_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
916365_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	The presentation of non-cash accruals for construction in progress on the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows was changed to conform to the presentation used in the current period.
916365_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	On August 28, 2013, the Company's Board of Directors declared a two -for-one split of its outstanding shares of common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend.
916365_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	On September 26, 2013, stockholders of record at the close of business on September 18, 2013, received one additional share of common stock for each share owned by such stockholder.
916365_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	All share and per-share information in the Annual Report on Form 10-K has been retroactively restated to reflect the stock split.
916365_14_ITEM8_P26_S3	The total number of authorized common shares and the par value of each share was not changed by the split.
916365_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States inherently requires estimates and assumptions by management of the Company that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosures.
916365_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
916365_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	Significant estimates and assumptions by management primarily impact the following key financial statement areas:
916365_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Inventory Impairment Risk The Company identifies potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	The estimated inventory valuation reserve to recognize any impairment in value (i.e. an inability to realize the full carrying value) is based on the Company's aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	The Company does not believe its merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	Shrinkage The Company performs physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and the Company has established reserves for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods sales volumes.
916365_14_ITEM8_P31_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	The Company believes historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	Vendor Funding The Company receives funding from substantially all of its significant merchandise vendors, in support of its business initiatives, through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed vendor support funds ("vendor support") and volume-based rebate funds ("volume rebates").
916365_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, most of which are "evergreen", reflecting the on-going relationship with our significant merchandise vendors.
916365_14_ITEM8_P33_S2	Certain of the Company's agreements, primarily volume rebates, are renegotiated annually, based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_14_ITEM8_P33_S3	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	During interim periods, the amount of vendor support is known and is debited to vendors systematically; however, volume rebates are estimated during interim periods based upon initial commitments and anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	The estimated purchase volume (and related vendor funding through volume rebates) is based on the Company's current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	Although the Company believes it can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related volume rebates at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could differ from previously estimated amounts.
916365_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	Freight The Company incurs various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	The Company self-insures a significant portion of its employee medical insurance, workers compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	The Company has stop-loss insurance policies to protect it from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S2	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S3	Therefore, the Company estimates potential obligations based upon historical data and experience, including actuarial calculations.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S4	Although the Company believes the reserves established for these obligations are reasonably estimated, any significant increase in the number of claims or costs associated with claims made under these plans could have a material adverse effect on the Company's financial results.
916365_14_ITEM8_P36_S5	At December 28, 2013 , the Company had recorded net insurance reserves of $41.3 million compared to $37.4 million at December 29, 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	Sales Tax Audit Reserve A portion of the Company's sales are to tax-exempt customers, predominantly agricultural-based .
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	The Company obtains exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S2	Many of the states in which the Company conducts business will perform audits to verify the Company's compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S3	The business activities of the Company's customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by the Company create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that the Company could be challenged as to the accuracy of the Company's sales tax compliance.
916365_14_ITEM8_P37_S5	While the Company believes it appropriately enforces sales tax compliance with its customers and endeavors to fully comply with all applicable sales tax regulations, there can be no assurance that upon final completion of such audits, the Company will not have a significant liability for disallowed exemptions.
916365_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company reviews past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to continually determine if it has potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and historical experience with each state.
916365_14_ITEM8_P38_S2	The Company continually reassesses the exposure based on historical audit results, changes in policies, preliminary and final assessments made by state sales tax auditors, and additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_14_ITEM8_P38_S3	The reserve for these tax audits can fluctuate depending on numerous factors, including the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	Tax Contingencies The Company's income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_14_ITEM8_P39_S1	These audits include questions regarding tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_14_ITEM8_P39_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	In evaluating the exposures associated with the Company's various tax filing positions, the Company records a liability for uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
916365_14_ITEM8_P40_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which the Company has established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Company recognizes the effect of income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained.
916365_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely of being realized.
916365_14_ITEM8_P41_S2	Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
916365_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	The Company adjusts its tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from the established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company's tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with the Company's various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	The effective income tax rate is also affected by changes in tax law, the tax jurisdiction of new stores or business ventures, the level of earnings and the results of tax audits.
916365_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, the Company first compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated undiscounted future cash flows.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S3	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, the Company calculates an impairment loss.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S4	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S5	The Company recognizes an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_14_ITEM8_P46_S6	If the Company recognizes an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining estimated useful life of that asset.
916365_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	No significant impairment charges were recognized in fiscal 2013 and 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P48_S1	In fiscal 2011 , the Company recognized impairment charges of $0.5 million related to the write-off of certain assets which were not expected to provide any future benefit to the Company and were determined to have no significant fair value.
916365_14_ITEM8_P48_S2	Impairment charges are included in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	The Company recognizes revenue at the time the customer takes possession of merchandise.
916365_14_ITEM8_P49_S1	If the Company receives payment before completion of its customer obligations (as per the Company's special order and layaway programs), the revenue is deferred until the customer takes possession of the merchandise and the sale is complete.
916365_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	The Company is required to collect certain taxes and fees from customers on behalf of government agencies and remit such collections to the applicable governmental entity on a periodic basis.
916365_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	These taxes are collected from customers at the time of purchase, but are not included in net sales.
916365_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	The Company records a liability upon collection from the customer and relieves the liability when payments are remitted to the applicable governmental agency.
916365_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	The Company estimates a liability for sales returns based on a rolling average of historical return trends, and the Company believes that its estimate for sales returns is an accurate reflection of future returns associated with past sales.
916365_14_ITEM8_P51_S1	However, as with any estimate, refund activity may vary from estimated amounts.
916365_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	At December 28, 2013 , the Company had a liability of $3.1 million reserved for sales returns, compared to $3.0 million at December 29, 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when a gift card or merchandise return card is redeemed by the customer and recognizes income when the likelihood of the gift card or merchandise return card being redeemed by the customer is remote (referred to as breakage ).
916365_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	The gift cards and merchandise return card breakage rate is based upon historical redemption patterns and income is recognized for unredeemed gift cards and merchandise return cards in proportion to those historical redemption patterns.
916365_14_ITEM8_P53_S2	The Company recognized breakage income of $1.6 million , $1.2 million and $1.5 million in fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	Cost of merchandise sold includes the total cost of products sold; freight expenses associated with moving merchandise inventories from vendors to distribution centers, from distribution centers to retail stores, and from one distribution center to another; vendor support; damaged, junked or defective product; cash discounts from payments to merchandise vendors; and adjustments for shrinkage (physical inventory losses), lower of cost or market valuation, slow moving product and excess inventory quantities.
916365_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	SG A expenses include payroll and benefit costs for retail, distribution center and corporate employees; occupancy costs of retail, distribution center and corporate facilities; advertising; tender costs, including bank charges and costs associated with credit and debit card interchange fees; outside service fees; and other administrative costs, such as computer maintenance, supplies, travel and lodging.
916365_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	Advertising costs consist of expenses incurred in connection with newspaper circulars and customer-targeted direct mail, as well as limited television, radio and other promotions.
916365_14_ITEM8_P56_S1	Costs are expensed when incurred with the exception of television advertising and circular and direct mail promotions, which are expensed upon first showing.
916365_14_ITEM8_P56_S2	Advertising expenses for fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 were approximately $65.6 million , $62.6 million and $56.0 million , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P56_S3	Prepaid advertising costs were approximately $0.3 million and $0.9 million at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	Costs incurred at the Company's distribution centers for receiving, warehousing and preparing product for delivery are expensed as incurred and are included in SG A expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_14_ITEM8_P57_S1	Because the Company does not include these costs in cost of sales, the Company s gross margin may not be comparable to other retailers that include these costs in the calculation of gross margin.
916365_14_ITEM8_P57_S2	Distribution center costs for fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 were approximately $111.3 million , $90.2 million and $76.8 million , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	Non-capital expenditures incurred in connection with opening new stores, primarily payroll and rent, are expensed as incurred.
916365_14_ITEM8_P58_S1	Pre-opening costs were approximately $7.8 million , $7.1 million and $7.3 million in fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	The Company has share-based compensation plans covering certain members of management and non-employee directors, which include incentive and non-qualified stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_14_ITEM8_P59_S1	In addition, the Company offers an employee stock purchase plan to most employees that work at least 20 hours per week.
916365_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its stock option awards at the date of grant utilizing a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
916365_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of short-term traded options that have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
916365_14_ITEM8_P61_S1	However, key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model are adjusted to incorporate the unique characteristics of the Company's stock option awards.
916365_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	Option pricing models and generally accepted valuation techniques require management to make subjective assumptions including expected stock price volatility, expected dividend yield, risk-free interest rate and expected life.
916365_14_ITEM8_P62_S1	The Company relies on a blended volatility approach, weighting historical volatility trends and implied volatility, to estimate future volatility assumptions.
916365_14_ITEM8_P62_S2	The risk-free interest rates used were actual U.S. Treasury Constant Maturity rates for bonds matching the expected term of the option on the date of grant.
916365_14_ITEM8_P62_S3	The expected life of the option on the date of grant was estimated based on the Company's historical experience for similar options.
916365_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	In addition to the key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model, the estimated forfeiture rate at the time of valuation (which is based on historical experience for similar options) is a critical assumption, as it reduces expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_14_ITEM8_P63_S1	The Company adjusts this estimate periodically, based on the extent to which actual forfeitures differ, or are expected to differ, from the previous estimate.
916365_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	The fair value of the Company's restricted stock unit awards is the closing price of the Company's common stock the day preceding the grant date.
916365_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	The Company believes its estimates are reasonable in the context of historical experience.
916365_14_ITEM8_P65_S1	Future results will depend on, among other matters, levels of share-based compensation granted in the future, actual forfeiture rates and the timing of option exercises.
916365_14_ITEM8_P66_S0	Depreciation includes expenses related to all retail, distribution center and corporate assets.
916365_14_ITEM8_P66_S1	Amortization includes expenses related to definite-lived intangible assets.
916365_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	The Company uses the asset and liability method to account for income taxes whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between the financial carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
916365_14_ITEM8_P67_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that are anticipated to be in effect when temporary differences reverse or are settled.
916365_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	The effect of a tax rate change is recognized in the period in which the law is enacted in the provision for income taxes.
916365_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	The Company records a valuation allowance when it is more likely than not that a deferred tax asset will not be realized.
916365_14_ITEM8_P70_S0	Basic net income per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average number of shares outstanding during the period.
916365_14_ITEM8_P70_S1	Diluted net income per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average diluted shares outstanding.
916365_14_ITEM8_P70_S2	Dilutive shares are computed using the treasury stock method for stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_14_ITEM8_P71_S0	The Company s comprehensive income is equal to net income in fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	Temporary cash investments, with a maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
916365_14_ITEM8_P73_S0	The majority of payments due from banks for customer credit cards are classified as cash and cash equivalents, as they settle within 24 - 48 hours.
916365_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	Sales generated through the Company's private label credit cards are not reflected as accounts receivable.
916365_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	Under an agreement with Citi Cards, a division of Citigroup ( Citigroup ), consumer and business credit is extended directly to customers by Citigroup.
916365_14_ITEM8_P75_S1	All credit program and related services are performed and controlled directly by Citigroup.
916365_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	Payments due from Citigroup are classified as cash and cash equivalents as they settle within 24 - 48 hours.
916365_14_ITEM8_P77_S0	At December 28, 2013 , the Company did not have any restricted cash.
916365_14_ITEM8_P77_S1	At December 29, 2012 , the Company s restricted cash consisted of $8.4 million in time deposits held as collateral for a letter of credit at a financial institution outside of the Senior Credit Facility for certain insurance policies.
916365_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in an orderly transaction between market participants on the measurement date.
916365_14_ITEM8_P78_S1	The Company uses a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
916365_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists, therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.
916365_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	The Company's financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, short-term receivables, trade payables and long-term debt instruments.
916365_14_ITEM8_P80_S1	Due to their short-term nature, the carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, short-term receivables and trade payables approximate current fair value at each balance sheet date.
916365_14_ITEM8_P80_S2	The Company had no borrowings under the Senior Credit Facility at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P81_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or market.
916365_14_ITEM8_P82_S0	Inventory cost consists of the direct cost of merchandise including freight.
916365_14_ITEM8_P82_S1	Inventories are net of shrinkage, obsolescence, other valuations and vendor allowances.
916365_14_ITEM8_P83_S0	Property and equipment are carried at cost.
916365_14_ITEM8_P84_S0	Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
916365_14_ITEM8_P84_S1	Improvements to leased premises are amortized using the straight-line method over the initial term of the lease or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is less.
916365_14_ITEM8_P84_S2	Leasehold improvements added late in the lease term are amortized over the term of the lease (including the first renewal option, if the renewal is reasonably assured) or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is less.
916365_14_ITEM8_P84_S3	The following estimated useful lives are generally applied:
916365_14_ITEM8_P85_S0	The Company entered into agreements with various governmental entities in the states of Kentucky, Georgia and Tennessee to implement tax abatement plans related to its distribution center in Franklin, Kentucky (Simpson County), its distribution center in Macon, Georgia (Bibb County) and its new store support center in Brentwood, Tennessee (Williamson County).
916365_14_ITEM8_P85_S1	The tax abatement plans provide for reduction of real property taxes for specified time frames by legally transferring title to its real property in exchange for industrial revenue bonds.
916365_14_ITEM8_P85_S2	This property was then leased back to the Company.
916365_14_ITEM8_P86_S0	The lease payments are equal to the amount of the payments on the bonds.
916365_14_ITEM8_P86_S1	The tax abatement period extends through the term of the lease, which coincides with the maturity date of the bonds.
916365_14_ITEM8_P86_S2	At any time, the Company has the option to purchase the real property by paying off the bonds, plus $1 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P86_S3	The terms and amounts authorized and drawn under each industrial revenue bond agreement are outlined as follows, as of December 28, 2013 :
916365_14_ITEM8_P87_S0	Due to the form of these transactions, the Company has not recorded the bonds or the lease obligation associated with the sale lease-back transaction.
916365_14_ITEM8_P87_S1	The original cost of the Company s property and equipment is recorded on the balance sheet and is being depreciated over its estimated useful life.
916365_14_ITEM8_P88_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs related to the acquisition and development of software and amortizes these costs using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the software, which is three to five years.
916365_14_ITEM8_P89_S0	Computer software consists primarily of third-party software purchased for internal use.
916365_14_ITEM8_P89_S1	A subsequent addition, modification or upgrade to internal-use software is capitalized to the extent that it enhances the software s functionality or extends its useful life.
916365_14_ITEM8_P90_S0	software and hardware in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
916365_14_ITEM8_P91_S0	Certain software costs not meeting the criteria for capitalization are expensed as incurred.
916365_14_ITEM8_P92_S0	All goodwill is associated with the Company as a whole.
916365_14_ITEM8_P92_S1	Goodwill is not amortized, but is evaluated for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of the goodwill may not be recoverable.
916365_14_ITEM8_P92_S2	The Company completes its impairment evaluation by performing internal valuation analyses and considering other publicly available market information, as appropriate.
916365_14_ITEM8_P93_S0	The test for goodwill impairment is a two step process.
916365_14_ITEM8_P94_S0	The first step of the goodwill impairment test, used to identify the potential for impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with the carrying value of its net assets, including goodwill.
916365_14_ITEM8_P94_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit, the second step of the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recorded, if any.
916365_14_ITEM8_P94_S2	The second step, if required, would compare the implied fair value of goodwill with the current carrying amount of goodwill.
916365_14_ITEM8_P94_S3	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value, an impairment charge would be recorded as a charge to the Company's operations.
916365_14_ITEM8_P95_S0	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2013 , the Company completed its annual impairment testing of goodwill and no impairment was identified.
916365_14_ITEM8_P95_S1	The Company determined that the fair value of the reporting unit (including goodwill) was in excess of the carrying value of the reporting unit and as such, the second step was not necessary.
916365_14_ITEM8_P95_S2	In reaching this conclusion, the fair value of the reporting unit was determined based on a market approach.
916365_14_ITEM8_P96_S0	Under the market approach, the fair value is based on observed market prices.
916365_14_ITEM8_P97_S0	The Company regularly evaluates the performance of its stores and periodically closes those that are under-performing.
916365_14_ITEM8_P98_S0	The Company records a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred, usually in the period the store closes.
916365_14_ITEM8_P98_S1	Store closing costs were not significant to results of operations for any of the fiscal years presented.
916365_14_ITEM8_P99_S0	Assets under capital leases are amortized in accordance with the Company's normal depreciation policy for owned assets or over the lease term, if shorter, and the related charge to operations is included in depreciation expense in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_14_ITEM8_P100_S0	Certain operating leases include rent increases during the initial lease term.
916365_14_ITEM8_P100_S1	For these leases, the Company recognizes the related rental expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease (which includes the pre-opening period of construction, renovation, fixturing and merchandise placement) and records the difference between the expense charged to operations and amounts paid as a deferred rent liability.
916365_14_ITEM8_P101_S0	The Company occasionally receives reimbursements from landlords to be used towards improving the related store to be leased.
916365_14_ITEM8_P101_S1	Leasehold improvements are recorded at their gross costs including items reimbursed by landlords.
916365_14_ITEM8_P101_S2	Related reimbursements are deferred and amortized on a straight-line basis as a reduction of rent expense over the initial lease term.
916365_14_ITEM8_P102_S0	Share-based compensation includes stock option and restricted stock unit awards and certain transactions under the Company's Employee Stock Purchase Plan (the ESPP ).
916365_14_ITEM8_P102_S1	Share-based compensation expense is recognized based on grant date fair value of all stock option and restricted stock unit awards plus a discount on shares purchased by employees as a part of the ESPP.
916365_14_ITEM8_P102_S2	The discount under the ESPP represents the difference between the purchase date market value and the employee s purchase price.
916365_14_ITEM8_P103_S0	There were no significant modifications to the Company's share-based compensation plans during fiscal 2013 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P103_S1	In connection with the 2013 stock split as discussed in Note 1, the number of shares of common stock that are reserved under the ESPP increased from 8.0 million to 16.0 million and the number of shares of common stock that are reserved under the 2009 Stock Incentive Plan increased from 6.2 million to 12.4 million .
916365_14_ITEM8_P103_S2	At December 28, 2013 , the Company had approximately 6.5 million shares available for future equity awards under the Company s 2009 Stock Incentive Plan.
916365_14_ITEM8_P104_S0	Share-based compensation expense including changes in expense for modifications of awards was $13.9 million , $17.6 million and $15.0 million for fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P105_S0	Under the Company's 2009 Stock Incentive Plan, options may be granted to current or prospective officers or employees, non-employee directors and consultants.
916365_14_ITEM8_P105_S1	The per share exercise price of options granted shall not be less than the fair market value of the stock on the date of grant and such options will expire no later than ten years from the date of grant.
916365_14_ITEM8_P106_S0	Vesting of options commences at various anniversary dates following the dates of grant.
916365_14_ITEM8_P107_S0	The fair value is separately estimated for each option grant.
916365_14_ITEM8_P107_S1	The fair value of each option is recognized as compensation expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_14_ITEM8_P108_S0	The Company has estimated the fair value of all stock option awards as of the date of the grant by applying a Black-Scholes pricing valuation model.
916365_14_ITEM8_P108_S1	The application of this valuation model involves assumptions that are judgmental and highly sensitive in the determination of compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P108_S2	The ranges of key assumptions used in determining the fair value of options granted during fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , as well as a summary of the methodology applied to develop each assumption, are as follows:
916365_14_ITEM8_P109_S0	This is a measure of the amount by which a price has fluctuated or is expected to fluctuate.
916365_14_ITEM8_P110_S0	Prior to 2012, the Company used actual historical changes in the market value of the stock to determine volatility.
916365_14_ITEM8_P110_S1	Beginning in 2012, the Company uses a blended volatility approach, weighting (i) actual historical changes in the market value of the stock at 75% and (ii) average implied volatility using tradable option data at 25% .
916365_14_ITEM8_P110_S2	To calculate historical changes in market value, the Company uses daily market value changes from the date of grant over a past period generally representative of the expected life of the options to determine volatility.
916365_14_ITEM8_P111_S0	To derive implied volatility, the Company relies on publicly traded options, with maturities of six months or greater.
916365_14_ITEM8_P111_S1	The Company believes this blended calculation of historical and expected price volatility provides the most relevant indicator of future volatility.
916365_14_ITEM8_P111_S2	An increase in the expected volatility will increase compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P112_S0	This is the U.S. Treasury Constant Maturity rate over a term equal to the expected life of the option.
916365_14_ITEM8_P112_S1	An increase in the risk-free interest rate will increase compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P113_S0	This is the period of time over which the options granted are expected to remain outstanding and is based on historical experience.
916365_14_ITEM8_P113_S1	Options granted generally have a maximum term of ten years.
916365_14_ITEM8_P113_S2	An increase in the expected life will increase compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P114_S0	Forfeiture Rate This is the estimated percentage of options granted that are expected to be forfeited or cancelled before becoming fully vested.
916365_14_ITEM8_P114_S1	This estimate is based on historical experience.
916365_14_ITEM8_P114_S2	An increase in the forfeiture rate will decrease compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P115_S0	This is the estimated dividend yield for the weighted average expected life of the option granted.
916365_14_ITEM8_P115_S1	An increase in the dividend yield will decrease compensation expense.
916365_14_ITEM8_P116_S0	The Company issues shares for options when exercised.
916365_14_ITEM8_P116_S1	A summary of stock option activity is as follows:
916365_14_ITEM8_P117_S0	The aggregate intrinsic values in the table above represents the total difference between the Company's closing stock price at each year-end and the option exercise price, multiplied by the number of in-the-money options at each year-end.
916365_14_ITEM8_P118_S0	As of December 28, 2013 , total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested stock options was approximately $15.2 million with a weighted average expense recognition period of 1.3 years.

916365_14_ITEM8_P128_S0	Note 3 - Senior Credit Facility:
916365_14_ITEM8_P129_S0	The Senior Credit Facility provides for borrowings of up to $250 million (with a sublimit of $20 million for swingline loans).
916365_14_ITEM8_P129_S1	The Senior Credit Facility has an Increase Option for $150 million (subject to additional lender group commitments).
916365_14_ITEM8_P129_S2	This agreement is unsecured and matures in October 2016 , with proceeds available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases and other matters.
916365_14_ITEM8_P130_S0	At December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , there were no outstanding borrowings under the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_14_ITEM8_P130_S1	There were $38.2 million and $51.4 million outstanding letters of credit under the Senior Credit Facility as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P131_S0	Borrowings bear interest at either the bank s base rate ( 3.25% at December 28, 2013 ) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) ( 0.16% at December 28, 2013 ) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.40% to 1.00% per annum ( 0.50% at December 28, 2013 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM8_P131_S1	The Company is also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.08% to 0.20% per annum ( 0.10% at December 28, 2013 ), adjusted quarterly based on the Company's leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM8_P131_S2	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the Senior Credit Facility.
916365_14_ITEM8_P132_S0	The Senior Credit Facility requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_14_ITEM8_P132_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio compares earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, stock compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments).
916365_14_ITEM8_P132_S2	The leverage ratio compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_14_ITEM8_P132_S3	The Senior Credit Facility also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_14_ITEM8_P132_S4	The Company was in compliance with all covenants at December 28, 2013 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S0	The Company leases the majority of its retail store locations, its current office space, one distribution center, transportation equipment and other equipment under various non-cancellable operating leases.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S1	The leases have varying terms and expire at various dates through 2030 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S2	Store leases typically have initial terms of between 10 and 15 years, with two to four optional renewal periods of five years each.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S3	Some leases require the payment of contingent rent that is based upon store sales above agreed-upon sales levels for the year.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S4	The sales levels vary for each store and are established in the lease agreements.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S5	Generally, most of the leases also require that the Company pays associated taxes, insurance and maintenance costs.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S6	Total rent expense for fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 was approximately $216.8 million , $200.1 million and $186.8 million , respec tively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P133_S7	Total contingent rent expense for fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 was insignificant.

916365_14_ITEM8_P153_S0	Note 9 - Retirement Benefit Plans:
916365_14_ITEM8_P154_S0	The Company has a defined contribution benefit plan, the Tractor Supply Company 401(k) Retirement Savings Plan (the Plan ), which provides retirement benefits for eligible employees.
916365_14_ITEM8_P154_S1	The Company matches (in cash) 100% of the employee s elective contributions up to 3% of eligible compensation plus 50% of the employee s elective contributions from 3% to 6% of eligible compensation.
916365_14_ITEM8_P154_S2	In no event shall the total Company match made on behalf of the employee exceed 4.5% of the employee s eligible compensation.
916365_14_ITEM8_P154_S3	All current contributions are immediately vested.
916365_14_ITEM8_P154_S4	Company contributions to the Plan during fiscal 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , were approximately $4.9 million , $4.4 million and $4.3 million , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P155_S0	The Company offers, through a deferred compensation program, the opportunity for certain qualifying employees to elect to defer a portion of their annual base salary and/or their annual incentive bonus.
916365_14_ITEM8_P155_S1	Under the deferred compensation program, a percentage of the participants' salary deferral is matched by the Company, limited to a maximum annual matching contribution of $4,500 .
916365_14_ITEM8_P155_S2	The Company s contributions, including accrued interest, were $0.5 million , $0.4 million and $0.4 million in each of the fiscal years 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
916365_14_ITEM8_P156_S0	Construction and Real Estate Commitments At December 28, 2013 , the Company had commitments related to construction projects for new stores totaling approximately $6.0 million and commitments related to the construction of its new store support center in Brentwood, Tennessee of approximately $22.0 million .
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S0	Litigation The Company responded to a Request for Information from the United States Environmental Protection Agency ( EPA ) in the first quarter of fiscal 2009 relating to certain recreational vehicles and non-road spark ignition engines sold by the Company.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S1	In the first quarter of fiscal 2011, the Environmental Enforcement Section of the Department of Justice ( DOJ ), on behalf of the EPA, informed the Company that it believed the Company had violated the Clean Air Act by importing or causing the importation of certain engines that were noncompliant, and that unless the DOJ and the Company were able to reach a settlement, the DOJ was prepared to commence a civil action.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S2	The engines were purchased by the Company pursuant to agreements with vendors under which the vendors represented that their products complied with all applicable laws and regulations and under which the vendors agreed to indemnify the Company for any liabilities or costs relating to, among other matters, the noncompliance or alleged noncompliance of their products.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S3	The Company notified these vendors of the EPA's position and has worked with these vendors to provide additional information to the DOJ and EPA regarding the alleged violations.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S4	As a result of this process, the Company believes it has provided evidence that many of the products identified by the DOJ and EPA in early 2011 were, in fact, in compliance with the Clean Air Act and that most of the remaining issues relate to products purchased from one vendor.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S5	The vendor of these products and the Company are engaged in settlement discussions with the DOJ and EPA that would call for the payment of a civil penalty by and certain injunctive relief against the Company.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S6	The Company does not expect the resolution of this matters to have a material adverse effect on its financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.
916365_14_ITEM8_P157_S7	The Company does not believe it is reasonably possible that a loss in excess of the amount accrued will be incurred.
916365_14_ITEM8_P158_S0	The Company is also involved in various litigation matters arising in the ordinary course of business.
916365_14_ITEM8_P158_S1	The Company believes that any estimated loss related to such matters has been adequately provided in accrued liabilities to the extent probable and reasonably estimable.
916365_14_ITEM8_P158_S2	Accordingly, the Company currently expects these matters will be resolved without material adverse effect on its consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
916365_14_ITEM8_P159_S0	The Company has one reportable segment which is the retail sale of farm and ranch products.
916365_14_ITEM8_P160_S0	The Company manages the business on the basis of one operating segment.
916365_14_ITEM8_P160_S1	The following chart indicates the percentage of sales represented by each major product category during fiscal 2013 , 2012 , and 2011 :

916365_14_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on this evaluation, our principal executive officer and principal financial officer concluded that, as of December 28, 2013 our disclosure controls and procedures were effective.

916365_14_ITEM9A_P2_S0	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during our last fiscal quarter that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect our internal control over financial reporting.
