916365_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following selected financial data is derived from the Consolidated Financial Statements of Tractor Supply Company and provides summary historical financial information for the fiscal periods ended and as of the dates indicated (in thousands, except per share amounts and selected operating and other data):
916365_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	(a) Our fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	References to fiscal year mean the year in which that fiscal year ended.
916365_16_ITEM6_P2_S1	Fiscal year 2011 consisted of 53 weeks while all other fiscal years consisted of 52 weeks.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	(b) Basic net income per share is calculated based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding applied to net income.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S1	Diluted net income per share is calculated using the treasury stock method for stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S2	(c) Comparable store metrics are calculated on an annual basis using sales generated from all stores open at least one year and all online sales, excluding certain adjustments to net sales.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S3	Beginning in fiscal 2015, stores closed during the year are removed from our comparable store metrics calculations.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S4	This change in the calculation methodology did not have a material impact on the comparable store metrics reported in prior periods presented due to the minimal number of stores closed in those periods.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S5	Stores relocated during the years being compared are not removed from our comparable store metrics.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S6	If the effect of relocated stores on our comparable store metrics becomes material, we would remove relocated stores from the calculations.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S7	(d) New stores sales metrics are based on stores open for less than one year.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S8	(e) Assumes average inventory cost, excluding inventory in-transit.
916365_16_ITEM6_P3_S9	(f) Long-term debt includes amounts outstanding under the Company s 2011 Senior Credit Facility and capital lease obligations, excluding the current portions.
916365_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis is intended to provide the reader with information that will assist in understanding the significant factors affecting our consolidated operating results, financial condition, liquidity and capital resources during the three-year period ended December 26, 2015 (our fiscal years 2015 , 2014 and 2013 ).
916365_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	This discussion should be read in conjunction with our Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this report.
916365_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	See Forward-Looking Statements and Risk Factors included elsewhere in this report.
916365_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of rural lifestyle retail stores in the United States.
916365_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	The Company is focused on supplying the needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and others who enjoy the rural lifestyle (which we refer to as the Out Here lifestyle), as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	As of December 26, 2015 , we operated 1,488 retail stores in 49 states under the names Tractor Supply Company, Del s Feed Farm Supply and HomeTown Pet.
916365_16_ITEM7_P1_S3	We also operate a website under the name TractorSupply.com .
916365_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our stores are located primarily in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities, and they offer the following comprehensive selection of merchandise:
916365_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	Maintenance products for agricultural and rural use.
916365_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our current and long-term growth strategy is to: (1) expand domestic geographic market presence through opening new retail stores, (2) enhance financial performance through comparable store sales growth achieved through targeted merchandising and marketing programs with an everyday value price philosophy supported by strong customer service, (3) enhance product margin through strategic product sourcing, inventory and markdown management, a strong exclusive brand offering, and optimization of product pricing and transportation costs, (4) leverage operating costs by focusing on opportunities for continuous improvement and elimination of waste in all of our processes, (5) expand market opportunities via omni-channel enhancements, tying together our website product content, social media and online shopping experience, and (6) expand through selective acquisitions, as such opportunities arise, to enhance penetration into new and existing markets to complement organic growth.
916365_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	Over the past five years we have experienced considerable growth in stores, growing from 1,001 stores at the end of 2010 to 1,488 stores at the end of fiscal 2015 , and in sales, with a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 11.3% .
916365_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	Given the size of the communities that we target, we believe that there is ample opportunity for new store growth in existing and new markets.
916365_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified approximately 1,000 additional opportunities for new Tractor Supply stores.
916365_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	We opened 114 new stores in 2015 and 107 new stores in 2014 , a selling square footage increase of approximately 8.0% in fiscal 2015 and approximately 8.3% in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	During 2015 , we opened stores in 33 states and completed construction of a new distribution center in Casa Grande, Arizona to support our continued expansion into the western states.
916365_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	Also in 2015, we completed construction of two smaller cross-dock facilities ( mixing centers ) in Texas to improve distribution of certain high-volume bulk products.
916365_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Net sales increased 9.0% to $6.23 billion in fiscal 2015 from $5.71 billion in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	Comparable store sales increased 3.1% in fiscal 2015 versus a 3.8% increase in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	Gross profit increased 9.9% to $2.14 billion in fiscal 2015 from $1.95 billion in fiscal 2014 , and gross margin increased 30 basis points to 34.4% of sales in fiscal 2015 from 34.1% of sales in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	Operating income increased 10 basis points to 10.4% of net sales in fiscal 2015 from 10.3% of net sales in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	In fiscal 2015 , diluted earnings per share grew 12.8% , to $3.00 compared to $2.66 in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	We ended the year with $63.8 million in cash and outstanding debt of $ 150.0 million, after returning $395.8 million to our stockholders through stock repurchases and dividends.
916365_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Management s discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
916365_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make informed estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
916365_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our financial position and/or results of operations may be materially different when reported under different conditions or when using different assumptions in the application of such policies.
916365_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	In the event estimates or assumptions prove to be different from actual amounts, adjustments are made in subsequent periods to reflect more current information.
916365_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	Our significant accounting policies are disclosed in Note 1 to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
916365_16_ITEM7_P11_S1	The following discussion addresses our most critical accounting policies, which are those that are both important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results of operations and that require significant judgment or use of complex estimates.
916365_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	We identify potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	We have established an inventory valuation reserve to recognize the estimated impairment in value (i.e., an inability to realize the full carrying value) based on our aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	We do not believe our merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our impairment reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding forecasted customer demand and the promotional environment.
916365_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize inventory impairment reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate impairment.
916365_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	However, if assumptions regarding consumer demand or clearance potential for certain products are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	A 10% change in our impairment reserve as of December 26, 2015, would have affected net income by approximately $0.4 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	We perform physical inventories at each store at least once a year, and we have established a reserve for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods sales volumes.
916365_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	We believe historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	Our shrinkage reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding future shrinkage trends, the effect of loss prevention measures and new merchandising strategies.
916365_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to recognize shrinkage in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate our shrinkage reserve.
916365_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	However, if our estimates regarding inventory losses are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	A 10% change in our shrinkage reserve as of December 26, 2015, would have affected net income by approximately $1.2 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	We receive funding from substantially all of our significant merchandise vendors, in support of our business initiatives, through a variety of programs and arrangements, including vendor support funds ( vendor support ) and volume-based rebate funds ( volume rebates ).
916365_16_ITEM7_P24_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, most of which are evergreen , reflecting the on-going relationship with our significant merchandise vendors.
916365_16_ITEM7_P24_S2	Certain of our agreements, primarily volume rebates, are renegotiated annually, based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	During interim periods, the amount of vendor support is estimated based upon initial commitments and anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	The estimated purchase volume (and related vendor funding) is based on our current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Although we believe we can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related volume rebates at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could be different from previously estimated amounts.
916365_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Our allocation methodology contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding customer demand, purchasing activity, target thresholds, vendor attrition and collectability.
916365_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our vendor support reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	At the end of each fiscal year, a significant portion of the actual purchase activity is known.
916365_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	Thus, we do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the amounts recorded as vendor support.
916365_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	We do not believe there is a significant collectability risk related to vendor support amounts due us at the end of fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	If a 10% reserve had been applied against our outstanding vendor support due as of December 26, 2015, net income would have been affected by approximately $1.7 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Although it is unlikely that there will be any significant reduction in historical levels of vendor support, if such a reduction were to occur in future periods, the Company could experience a higher inventory balance and higher cost of sales.
916365_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	We incur various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	We allocate freight as a component of total cost of sales without regard to inventory mix or unique freight burden of certain categories.
916365_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	This assumption has been consistently applied for all years presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our capitalized freight balance or freight allocation in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	If a 10% increase or decrease had been applied against our current inventory capitalized freight balance as of December 26, 2015, net income would have been affected by approximately $6.6 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Self-Insurance Reserves:
916365_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	We self-insure a significant portion of our employee medical insurance, workers compensation and general liability insurance plans.
916365_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	We have stop-loss insurance policies to protect from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	Provisions for losses related to our self-insured liabilities are based upon periodic independent actuarially determined estimates that consider a number of factors including historical claims experience, demographic factors and severity factors.
916365_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	Our self-insured liabilities contain uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the ultimate cost to settle reported claims and claims incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date based upon historical data and experience, including actuarial calculations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our self-insurance reserves in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the assumptions we use to calculate insurance reserves.
916365_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	However, if we experience a significant increase in the number of claims or the cost associated with these claims, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	A 10% change in our self-insurance reserves as of December 26, 2015, would have affected net income by approximately $3.2 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	A portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers, predominantly agricultural-based.
916365_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	We obtain exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	Many of the states in which we conduct business will perform audits to verify our compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_16_ITEM7_P46_S3	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_16_ITEM7_P46_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that we could be challenged as to the accuracy of our sales tax compliance.
916365_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	When establishing our sales tax audit reserve, we review our past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to continually determine if we have potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_16_ITEM7_P47_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk as well as our historical experience with each respective state.
916365_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	We continually reassess the exposure based on historical audit results, changes in policies, preliminary and final assessments made by state sales tax auditors, and additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	Our sales tax audit reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment regarding the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	We have not made any material changes to our sales tax audit assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the future estimates or assumptions we use to calculate the sales tax liability reserve.
916365_16_ITEM7_P51_S1	However, if our estimates regarding the ultimate sales tax liability are inaccurate, we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	A 10% change in our sales tax audit reserve as of December 26, 2015, would have affected net income by approximately $0.8 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Tax Contingencies:
916365_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	Our income tax returns are periodically audited by U.S. federal and state tax authorities.
916365_16_ITEM7_P54_S1	These audits include questions regarding our tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_16_ITEM7_P54_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	In evaluating the exposures associated with our various tax filing positions, we record a liability for uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
916365_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which we have established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	We recognize the effect of income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained.
916365_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely of being realized.
916365_16_ITEM7_P56_S2	Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
916365_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	We adjust our tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from our established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	Our tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with our various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	We have not made any material changes in the accounting methodology used to establish our tax contingencies in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the reserves established for tax benefits not recognized.
916365_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	Although management believes that the judgments and estimates discussed herein are reasonable, actual results could differ, and we may be exposed to losses or gains that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	To the extent we prevail in matters for which reserves have been established, or are required to pay amounts in excess of our reserves, our effective income tax rate in a given financial statement period could be materially affected.
916365_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	An unfavorable tax settlement would require use of our cash and would result in an increase in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_16_ITEM7_P62_S2	A favorable tax settlement would be recognized as a reduction in our effective income tax rate in the period of resolution.
916365_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	A 10% change in our uncertain tax position reserve as of December 26, 2015 would have affected net income by approximately $0.2 million in fiscal 2015.
916365_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Effect if Actual Results Differ From Assumptions Impairment of Long-Lived Assets:
916365_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	Long-lived assets other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, which are separately tested for impairment, are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, we first compare the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges).
916365_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_16_ITEM7_P66_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, we calculate an impairment loss.
916365_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_16_ITEM7_P67_S2	We recognize an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_16_ITEM7_P67_S3	If we recognize an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining estimated useful life of that asset.
916365_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	Our impairment loss calculations contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate future cash flows and asset fair values, including forecasting useful lives of the assets and selecting the discount rate that reflects the risk inherent in future cash flows.
916365_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	We have not made any material changes in our impairment loss assessment methodology in the financial periods presented.
916365_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	We do not believe there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a material change in the estimates or assumptions we use to calculate long-lived asset impairment losses.
916365_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	None of these estimates and assumptions are significantly sensitive, and a 10% change in any of these estimates would not have a material impact on our analysis.
916365_16_ITEM7_P71_S2	However, if actual results are not consistent with our estimates and assumptions used in estimating future cash flows and asset fair values, we may be exposed to losses that could be material.
916365_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our unaudited quarterly operating results for each fiscal quarter of 2015 and 2014 are shown below (in thousands, except per share amounts):
916365_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	(a) Comparable store metrics are calculated using sales generated from all stores open at least one year and all online sales, excluding certain adjustments to net sales.
916365_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	Beginning in fiscal 2015, stores closed during the year are removed from our comparable store metrics calculations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	This change in the calculation methodology did not have a material impact on the comparable store metrics reported in prior periods presented due to the minimal number of stores closed in those periods.
916365_16_ITEM7_P73_S3	Stores relocated during the periods being compared are not removed from our comparable store metrics.
916365_16_ITEM7_P73_S4	If the effect of relocated stores on our comparable store metrics becomes material, we would remove relocated stores from the calculations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain items in our Consolidated Statements of Income expressed as a percentage of net sales.
916365_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	(a) Our gross margin amounts may not be comparable to those of other retailers since some retailers include all of the costs related to their distribution network in cost of merchandise sold and others (like our Company) exclude a portion of these distribution network costs from gross margin and instead include them in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses; refer to Note 1 Significant Accounting Policies, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, included in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
916365_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	Net sales increased 9.0% to $6.23 billion in fiscal 2015 from $5.71 billion in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	Comparable store sales for fiscal 2015 were $5.89 billion , a 3.1% increase over fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P76_S2	This compares to a 3.8% comparable store sales increase in the prior year.
916365_16_ITEM7_P76_S3	The comparable store transaction count increased 3.3% , while comparable store average ticket decreased (0.2)% for fiscal 2015 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	Comparable store metrics are calculated on an annual basis using sales generated from all stores open at least one year and all online sales, excluding certain adjustments to net sales.
916365_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	Beginning in fiscal 2015, stores closed during the year are removed from our comparable store metrics calculations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P77_S2	This change in the calculation methodology did not have a material impact on the comparable store metrics reported in prior periods due to the minimal number of stores closed in those periods.
916365_16_ITEM7_P77_S3	Stores relocated during the years being compared are not removed from our comparable store metrics.
916365_16_ITEM7_P77_S4	If the effect of relocated stores on our comparable store metrics becomes material, we would remove relocated stores from the calculations.
916365_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	The comparable store sales increase was driven by an increase in traffic counts and the year-round strength of consumable, usable, edible ("C.U.E.") products, principally animal- and pet-related merchandise.
916365_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	Hardline products such as fencing, trailers and towing also performed well throughout the year.
916365_16_ITEM7_P78_S2	The full year sales performance was negatively impacted by fourth quarter weakness in the key cold weather seasonal categories of heating (stoves and fuel) and insulated outerwear along with softness in seasonal big ticket items such as snow blowers, log splitters and generators.
916365_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	In addition to comparable store sales growth in fiscal 2015 , sales from stores opened less than one year were $351.0 million in fiscal 2015 , which represented 6.1 percentage points of the 9.0% increase over fiscal 2014 net sales.
916365_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	Sales from stores opened less than one year were $353.4 million in fiscal 2014 , which represented 6.8 percentage points of the 10.6% increase over fiscal 2013 net sales.

916365_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	As a percent of sales, gross margin increased 30 basis points to 34.4% for fiscal 2015 compared to 34.1% for fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	This increase in gross margin principally reflects improved direct product margin.
916365_16_ITEM7_P82_S3	Direct product margin increased as a result of strong execution on our four strategic margin initiatives which include inventory and markdown management, strategic sourcing, exclusive branding and retail price management.
916365_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	As a percent of sales, SG A expenses, including depreciation and amortization, increased 20 basis points to 24.0% in fiscal 2015 from 23.8% in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	costs at the stores and incremental costs associated with our two new mixing centers and our new distribution facility in Casa Grande, Arizona.
916365_16_ITEM7_P84_S1	Total SG A expenses, including depreciation and amortization, for fiscal 2015 increased 9.7% to $1.49 billion from $1.36 billion in fiscal 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P84_S2	The increase in SG A expenses primarily reflects new store growth and variable costs associated with our comparable store sales growth.
916365_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	Our effective tax rate decreased to 36.6% for fiscal 2015 compared to 36.9% in fiscal 2014 predominantly as a result of the reversal of various reserves for uncertain tax positions.
916365_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	As a result of the foregoing factors, net income for fiscal 2015 increased 10.7% to $410.4 million , or $3.00 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $370.9 million , or $2.66 per diluted share, in fiscal 2014 .

916365_16_ITEM7_P88_S2	This compares to a 4.8% comparable store sales increase in the prior year.
916365_16_ITEM7_P88_S3	The comparable store transaction count increased 3.2%, while comparable store average ticket increased 0.6% for fiscal 2014.

916365_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	This was a result of continued investment in C.U.E. inventory, expanded product assortments and improved localized product offerings.
916365_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	Seasonal merchandise, predominantly heating and outdoor power equipment, performed well during the year.

916365_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	In addition to normal operating expenses, our primary ongoing cash requirements are for new store expansion, remodeling and relocation programs, distribution facilities capacity and improvements, information technology, inventory purchases, share repurchases and cash dividends.
916365_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	Our primary ongoing sources of liquidity are existing cash balances, cash provided from operations, funds available under our credit facility (as discussed in Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements), capital and operating leases and normal trade credit.
916365_16_ITEM7_P99_S2	Our inventory and accounts payable levels typically build in the first and third fiscal quarters to support the higher sales volume of the spring and cold-weather selling seasons, respectively.

916365_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	The shifts in working capital were attributable to changes in the following components of current assets and current liabilities (in millions):
916365_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	In comparison to December 27, 2014 , working capital as of December 26, 2015 was impacted most significantly by changes in our inventory and accounts payable.
916365_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	We actively manage our inventory balances and in-stock levels at our stores.
916365_16_ITEM7_P102_S1	The increase in inventory was due to new store growth and an increase in average inventory per store of 9.0% compared to the prior year.
916365_16_ITEM7_P102_S2	The increase in average inventory per store is principally related to a carry-over of cold-weather merchandise, additional investment in C.U.E. products and early receipt of certain spring seasonal items.
916365_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	Accounts payable increased primarily as a result of new store growth and higher average inventory per store along with timing of payments to vendors.
916365_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	During the period of October 24, 2011 through February 19, 2016, the Company was party to a senior credit facility (the 2011 Senior Credit Facility ), which provided for borrowings up to $400 million (with a sublimit of $30 million for swingline loans) as of December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014.
916365_16_ITEM7_P104_S1	The 2011 Senior Credit Facility was unsecured and would have matured on October 24, 2016.
916365_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	On February 19, 2016, the Company replaced the 2011 Senior Credit Facility by entering into a new senior credit facility (the 2016 Senior Credit Facility ) consisting of a $200 million term loan and a $500 million revolving credit facility (with a sublimit of $50 million for swingline loans).
916365_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	This agreement is unsecured and matures in February 2021, with proceeds available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases, and other matters.
916365_16_ITEM7_P105_S2	As a result of the maturity date in the new agreement, the Company has presented any outstanding borrowings under the 2011 Senior Credit Facility as of December 26, 2015 as a non-current liability in the Consolidated Balance Sheet in accordance with the applicable accounting guidance.
916365_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	At December 26, 2015 there were $150.0 million in outstanding borrowings under the 2011 Senior Credit Facility and no outstanding borrowings at December 27, 2014 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P106_S1	There were $48.7 million and $40.7 million outstanding letters of credit under the 2011 Senior Credit Facility as of December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014 , respectively.
916365_16_ITEM7_P106_S2	Borrowings bore interest at either the bank s base rate ( 3.50% at December 26, 2015 ) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) ( 0.42% at December 26, 2015 ) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.40% to 1.00% per annum ( 0.50% at December 26, 2015 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P106_S3	The Company was also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.08% to 0.20% per annum ( 0.10% at December 26, 2015 ), adjusted quarterly based on the Company s leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P106_S4	There were no compensating balance requirements associated with the 2011 Senior Credit Facility.
916365_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	The 2011 Senior Credit Facility required quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P107_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio compared earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, stock compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments).
916365_16_ITEM7_P107_S2	The leverage ratio compared total debt plus rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_16_ITEM7_P107_S3	The 2011 Senior Credit Facility also contained certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_16_ITEM7_P107_S4	The Company was in compliance with all covenants at December 26, 2015 .
916365_16_ITEM7_P108_S0	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility contains a $200 million term loan which requires quarterly payments totaling $10 million a year in years one and two and $20 million a year in years three through five, with the remaining balance due in full on the maturity date of February 19, 2021.
916365_16_ITEM7_P108_S1	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility also contains a $500 million revolving credit facility (with a sublimit of $50 million for swingline loans).
916365_16_ITEM7_P109_S0	Borrowings for both the term loan and the revolving credit facility bear interest at either the bank s base rate or LIBOR plus an additional amount ranging from 0.500% to 1.125% per annum, adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P109_S1	The Company is also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.075% to 0.200% per annum, adjusted quarterly based on the Company s leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P110_S0	Proceeds from the 2016 Senior Credit Facility are available to be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases, and other matters.
916365_16_ITEM7_P110_S1	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the 2016 Senior Credit Facility.
916365_16_ITEM7_P111_S0	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_16_ITEM7_P111_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio compares consolidated EBITDAR to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments).
916365_16_ITEM7_P111_S2	The leverage ratio compares total debt plus rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments) multiplied by a factor of six to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_16_ITEM7_P111_S3	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_16_ITEM7_P112_S0	Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operations and funds available under our credit facility (as discussed in Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements).
916365_16_ITEM7_P112_S1	Principal uses of cash for investing activities are capital expenditures, while principal uses of cash for financing activities are repurchase of the Company s common stock and cash dividends paid to stockholders.
