916365_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
916365_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	Founded in 1938, Tractor Supply Company is the largest operator of rural lifestyle retail stores in the United States.
916365_17_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company is focused on supplying the needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and those who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_17_ITEM8_P20_S2	Stores are located primarily in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities.
916365_17_ITEM8_P20_S3	At December 31, 2016 , the Company operated a total of 1,738 retail stores in 49 states ( 1,595 Tractor Supply and Del s retail stores and 143 Petsense retail stores) and also offered a number of products online at TractorSupply.com .
916365_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	In the first quarter of fiscal 2016, the Company adopted accounting guidance which affected the presentation of deferred tax liabilities and assets as discussed in Note 15.
916365_17_ITEM8_P21_S1	This guidance was applied retrospectively for all periods presented and therefore, the presentation of previously reported deferred tax assets has been changed to conform to the presentation used in the current period.
916365_17_ITEM8_P21_S2	The adoption of this guidance resulted in the reclassification of deferred tax assets of $ 46.0 million from current assets to noncurrent assets in the Consolidated Balance Sheets as of December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	The Company s fiscal year includes 52 or 53 weeks and ends on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
916365_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	The fiscal year ended December 31, 2016 consisted of 53 weeks and the fiscal years ended December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014 consisted of 52 weeks.
916365_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries.
916365_17_ITEM8_P23_S1	All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
916365_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States inherently requires estimates and assumptions by management of the Company that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosures.
916365_17_ITEM8_P24_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
916365_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Significant estimates and assumptions by management primarily impact the following key financial statement areas:
916365_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	Inventory Impairment Risk The Company identifies potentially excess and slow-moving inventory by evaluating turn rates, historical and expected future sales trends, age of merchandise, overall inventory levels, current cost of inventory and other benchmarks.
916365_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	The Company has established an inventory valuation reserve to recognize the estimated impairment in value (i.e. - an inability to realize the full carrying value) based on the Company s aggregate assessment of these valuation indicators under prevailing market conditions and current merchandising strategies.
916365_17_ITEM8_P26_S2	The Company does not believe its merchandise inventories are subject to significant risk of obsolescence in the near term.
916365_17_ITEM8_P26_S3	However, changes in market conditions or consumer purchasing patterns could result in the need for additional reserves.
916365_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	Shrinkage The Company performs physical inventories at least once a year for each store that has been open more than 12 months, and the Company has established a reserve for estimating inventory shrinkage between physical inventory counts.
916365_17_ITEM8_P27_S1	The reserve is established by assessing the chain-wide average shrinkage experience rate, applied to the related periods sales volumes.
916365_17_ITEM8_P27_S2	Such assessments are updated on a regular basis for the most recent individual store experiences.
916365_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	The estimated store inventory shrink rate is based on historical experience.
916365_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	The Company believes historical rates are a reasonably accurate reflection of future trends.
916365_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	Vendor Funding The Company receives funding from substantially all of its significant merchandise vendors, in support of its business initiatives, through a variety of programs and arrangements, including guaranteed vendor support funds ( vendor support ) and volume-based rebate funds ( volume rebates ).
916365_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	The amounts received are subject to terms of vendor agreements, most of which are evergreen, reflecting the on-going relationship with our significant merchandise vendors.
916365_17_ITEM8_P29_S2	Certain of the Company s agreements, primarily volume rebates, are renegotiated annually, based on expected annual purchases of the vendor s product.
916365_17_ITEM8_P29_S3	Vendor funding is initially deferred as a reduction of the purchase price of inventory, and then recognized as a reduction of cost of merchandise as the related inventory is sold.
916365_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	During interim periods, the amount of vendor support and volume rebates are estimated based upon initial commitments and anticipated purchase levels with applicable vendors.
916365_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	The estimated purchase volume (and related vendor funding) is based on the Company s current knowledge of inventory levels, sales trends and expected customer demand, as well as planned new store openings and relocations.
916365_17_ITEM8_P30_S2	Although the Company believes it can reasonably estimate purchase volume and related volume rebates at interim periods, it is possible that actual year-end results could be different from previously estimated amounts.
916365_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	Freight The Company incurs various types of transportation and delivery costs in connection with inventory purchases and distribution.
916365_17_ITEM8_P31_S1	Such costs are included as a component of the overall cost of inventories (on an aggregate basis) and recognized as a component of cost of merchandise sold as the related inventory is sold.
916365_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	The Company self-insures a significant portion of its employee medical insurance, workers compensation insurance and general liability (including product liability) insurance plans.
916365_17_ITEM8_P32_S1	The Company has stop-loss insurance policies to protect it from individual losses over specified dollar values.
916365_17_ITEM8_P32_S2	For self-insured employee medical claims, we have a stop loss limit of $300,000 per person per year.
916365_17_ITEM8_P32_S3	Our deductible or self-insured retention, as applicable, for each claim involving workers compensation insurance and general liability insurance is limited to $500,000 and our Texas Work Injury Policy is limited to $750,000 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P32_S4	Further, we maintain a commercially reasonable umbrella/excess policy that covers liabilities in excess of the primary insurance policy limits.
916365_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	The full extent of certain claims, especially workers compensation and general liability claims, may not become fully determined for several years.
916365_17_ITEM8_P33_S1	Therefore, the Company estimates potential obligations based upon historical claims experience, industry factors, severity factors and other actuarial assumptions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P33_S2	Although the Company believes the reserves established for these obligations are reasonably estimated, any significant change in the number of claims or costs associated with claims made under these plans could have a material effect on the Company s financial results.
916365_17_ITEM8_P33_S3	At December 31, 2016 , the Company had recorded net insurance reserves of $54.3 million compared to $51.2 million at December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	Sales Tax Audit Reserve A portion of the Company s sales are to tax-exempt customers, predominantly agricultural-based .
916365_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	The Company obtains exemption information as a necessary part of each tax-exempt transaction.
916365_17_ITEM8_P34_S2	Many of the states in which the Company conducts business will perform audits to verify the Company s compliance with applicable sales tax laws.
916365_17_ITEM8_P34_S3	The business activities of the Company s customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by the Company create a challenging and complex tax compliance environment.
916365_17_ITEM8_P34_S4	These circumstances also create some risk that the Company could be challenged as to the accuracy of the Company s sales tax compliance.
916365_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	The Company reviews past audit experience and assessments with applicable states to continually determine if it has potential exposure for non-compliance.
916365_17_ITEM8_P35_S1	Any estimated liability is based on an initial assessment of compliance risk and historical experience with each state.
916365_17_ITEM8_P35_S2	The Company continually reassesses the exposure based on historical audit results, changes in policies, preliminary and final assessments made by state sales tax auditors, and additional documentation that may be provided to reduce the assessment.
916365_17_ITEM8_P35_S3	The reserve for these tax audits can fluctuate depending on numerous factors, including the complexity of agricultural-based exemptions, the ambiguity in state tax regulations, the number of ongoing audits and the length of time required to settle with the state taxing authorities.
916365_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	Tax Contingencies The Company s income tax returns are periodically audited by United States federal and state tax authorities.
916365_17_ITEM8_P36_S1	These audits include questions regarding tax filing positions, including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income among various tax jurisdictions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P36_S2	At any time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by the various tax authorities.
916365_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
916365_17_ITEM8_P37_S1	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which the Company has established a reserve, is audited and fully resolved or clarified.
916365_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company recognizes the effect of income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained.
916365_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely of being realized.
916365_17_ITEM8_P38_S2	Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
916365_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Company adjusts its tax contingencies reserve and income tax provision in the period in which actual results of a settlement with tax authorities differs from the established reserve, the statute of limitations expires for the relevant tax authority to examine the tax position or when more information becomes available.
916365_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	The Company s tax contingencies reserve contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and apply judgment to estimate the exposures associated with the Company s various filing positions and whether or not the minimum requirements for recognition of tax benefits have been met.
916365_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	The effective income tax rate is also affected by changes in tax law, the tax jurisdiction of new stores or business ventures, the level of earnings and the results of tax audits.
916365_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets Long-lived assets are evaluated for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, the Company first compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated undiscounted future cash flows.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S1	The evaluation for long-lived assets is performed at the lowest level of identifiable cash flows, which is generally the individual store level.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S2	The significant assumptions used to determine estimated undiscounted cash flows include cash inflows and outflows directly resulting from the use of those assets in operations, including margin on net sales, payroll and related items, occupancy costs, insurance allocations and other costs to operate a store.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S3	If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value of the asset, the Company calculates an impairment loss.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S4	The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying value of the asset to the asset s estimated fair value, which may be based on an estimated future cash flow model.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S5	The Company recognizes an impairment loss if the amount of the asset s carrying value exceeds the asset s estimated fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P43_S6	If the Company recognizes an impairment loss, the adjusted carrying amount of the asset becomes its new cost basis.
916365_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	For a depreciable long-lived asset, the new cost basis will be depreciated (amortized) over the remaining estimated useful life of that asset.
916365_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	No significant impairment charges were recognized in fiscal 2016 , 2015 or 2014 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	Impairment charges are included in selling, general and administrative ( SG A ) expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	Impairment of Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets Goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets are evaluated for impairment annually, or whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P47_S1	In accordance with the accounting standards, an entity has the option first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that goodwill or an indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired.
916365_17_ITEM8_P47_S2	If after such assessment an entity concludes that the asset is not impaired, then the entity is not required to take further action.
916365_17_ITEM8_P47_S3	However, if an entity concludes otherwise, then it is required to determine the fair value of the asset using a quantitative impairment test, and if impaired, the associated assets must be written down to fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	The quantitative test for goodwill impairment is a two-step process.
916365_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	The first step of the goodwill impairment test, used to identify the potential for impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with the carrying value of its net assets, including goodwill.
916365_17_ITEM8_P49_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit, the second step of the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recorded, if any.
916365_17_ITEM8_P49_S2	The second step, if required, would compare the implied fair value of goodwill with the current carrying amount of goodwill.
916365_17_ITEM8_P49_S3	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value, an impairment charge would be recorded to the Company s operations.
916365_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	We determine fair values for each reporting unit using the market approach, when available and appropriate, or the income approach, or a combination of both.
916365_17_ITEM8_P50_S1	If multiple valuation methodologies are used, the results are weighted appropriately.
916365_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	The quantitative impairment test for other indefinite-lived intangible assets involves comparing the carrying amount of the asset to the sum of the discounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset.
916365_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	If the implied fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset is less than the carrying value, an impairment charge would be recorded to the Company s operations.
916365_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	No significant impairment charges were recognized in fiscal 2016 , 2015 or 2014 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	Impairment charges are included in SG A expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	The Company recognizes revenue at the time the customer takes possession of merchandise.
916365_17_ITEM8_P53_S1	If the Company receives payment before completion of its customer obligations (as per the Company s special order and layaway programs), the revenue is deferred until the customer takes possession of the merchandise and the sale is complete.
916365_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company is required to collect certain taxes and fees from customers on behalf of government agencies and remit such collections to the applicable governmental entity on a periodic basis.
916365_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	These taxes and fees are collected from customers at the time of purchase, but are not included in net sales.
916365_17_ITEM8_P54_S2	The Company records a liability upon collection from the customer and relieves the liability when payments are remitted to the applicable governmental agency.
916365_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	The Company estimates a liability for sales returns based on a rolling average of historical return trends, and the Company believes that its estimate for sales returns is an accurate reflection of future returns associated with past sales.
916365_17_ITEM8_P55_S1	However, as with any estimate, refund activity may vary from estimated amounts.
916365_17_ITEM8_P55_S2	At December 31, 2016 , the Company had a liability of $4.2 million reserved for sales returns compared to $3.3 million at December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P56_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when a gift card or merchandise return card is redeemed by the customer and recognizes income when the likelihood of the gift card or merchandise return card being redeemed by the customer is remote (referred to as breakage ).
916365_17_ITEM8_P56_S1	The gift cards and merchandise return card breakage rate is based upon historical redemption patterns and income is recognized for unredeemed gift cards and merchandise return cards in proportion to those historical redemption patterns.
916365_17_ITEM8_P56_S2	The Company recognized breakage income of $1.9 million , $1.6 million and $0.9 million in fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P57_S0	Cost of merchandise sold includes the total cost of products sold; freight expenses associated with moving merchandise inventories from vendors to distribution facilities, from distribution facilities to retail stores, and from one distribution facility to another; vendor support; damaged, junked or defective product; cash discounts from payments to merchandise vendors; and adjustments for shrinkage (physical inventory losses), lower of cost or net realizable value, slow moving product and excess inventory quantities.
916365_17_ITEM8_P58_S0	SG A expenses include payroll and benefit costs for retail, distribution facility and corporate employees; occupancy costs of retail, distribution and corporate facilities; advertising; tender costs, including bank charges and costs associated with credit and debit card interchange fees; outside service fees; and other administrative costs, such as computer maintenance, supplies, travel and lodging.
916365_17_ITEM8_P59_S0	Advertising costs consist of expenses incurred in connection with newspaper circulars and customer-targeted direct mail, as well as limited television, radio, digital and social media offerings and other promotions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P59_S1	Costs are expensed when incurred with the exception of television advertising and circular and direct mail promotions, which are expensed upon first showing.
916365_17_ITEM8_P59_S2	Advertising expenses for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 were approximately $84.2 million , $73.9 million and $70.4 million , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P59_S3	Prepaid advertising costs were approximately $2.1 million and $1.6 million at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	Costs incurred at the Company s distribution facilities for receiving, warehousing and preparing product for delivery are expensed as incurred and are included in SG A expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	Because the Company does not include these costs in cost of sales, the Company s gross margin may not be comparable to other retailers that include these costs in the calculation of gross margin.
916365_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	Distribution facility costs including depreciation for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 were approximately $166.8 million , $145.4 million and $121.1 million , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	Pre-opening Costs Non-capital expenditures incurred in connection with opening new stores, primarily payroll and rent, are expensed as incurred.
916365_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	Pre-opening costs were approximately $9.9 million , $9.6 million and $8.9 million in fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Company has share-based compensation plans covering certain members of management and non-employee directors, which include incentive and non-qualified stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_17_ITEM8_P62_S1	In addition, the Company offers an Employee Stock Purchase Plan ( ESPP ) to most employees that work at least 20 hours per week.
916365_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its stock option awards at the date of grant utilizing a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
916365_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of short-term traded options that have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P64_S1	However, key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model are adjusted to incorporate the unique characteristics of the Company s stock option awards.
916365_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	Option pricing models and generally accepted valuation techniques require management to make subjective assumptions including expected stock price volatility, expected dividend yield, risk-free interest rate and expected life.
916365_17_ITEM8_P65_S1	The Company relies on a blended volatility approach, weighting historical volatility trends and implied volatility, to estimate future volatility assumptions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P65_S2	The risk-free interest rates used were actual U.S. Treasury Constant Maturity rates for bonds matching the expected term of the option on the date of grant.
916365_17_ITEM8_P65_S3	The expected term of the option on the date of grant was estimated based on the Company s historical experience for similar options.
916365_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	In addition to the key assumptions used in the Black-Scholes model, the estimated forfeiture rate at the time of valuation (which is based on historical experience for similar options) is a critical assumption, as it reduces expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_17_ITEM8_P66_S1	The Company adjusts this estimate periodically, based on the extent to which actual forfeitures differ, or are expected to differ, from the previous estimate.
916365_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	The fair value of the Company s restricted stock unit awards is the closing price of the Company s common stock the day preceding the grant date, discounted for the expected dividend yield over the term of the award.
916365_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	The Company believes its estimates are reasonable in the context of historical experience.
916365_17_ITEM8_P68_S1	Future results will depend on, among other matters, levels of share-based compensation granted in the future, actual forfeiture rates and the timing of option exercises.
916365_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	Depreciation includes expenses related to all retail, distribution facility and corporate assets.
916365_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	Amortization includes expenses related to definite-lived intangible assets.
916365_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	The Company uses the asset and liability method to account for income taxes whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between the financial carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
916365_17_ITEM8_P70_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that are anticipated to be in effect when temporary differences reverse or are settled.
916365_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	The effect of a tax rate change is recognized in the period in which the law is enacted in the provision for income taxes.
916365_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	The Company records a valuation allowance when it is more likely than not that a deferred tax asset will not be realized.
916365_17_ITEM8_P73_S0	Basic net income per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average number of shares outstanding during the period.
916365_17_ITEM8_P73_S1	Diluted net income per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted average diluted shares outstanding.
916365_17_ITEM8_P73_S2	Dilutive shares are computed using the treasury stock method for stock options and restricted stock units.
916365_17_ITEM8_P74_S0	Temporary cash investments, with a maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
916365_17_ITEM8_P75_S0	The majority of payments due from banks for customer credit cards are classified as cash and cash equivalents, as they generally settle within 24 - 48 hours.
916365_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	Sales generated through the Company s private label credit cards are not reflected as accounts receivable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	Under an agreement with Citi Cards, a division of Citigroup, consumer and business credit is extended directly to customers by Citigroup.
916365_17_ITEM8_P77_S1	All credit program and related services are performed and controlled directly by Citigroup.
916365_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	Payments due from Citigroup are classified as cash and cash equivalents as they generally settle within 24 - 48 hours.
916365_17_ITEM8_P79_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in an orderly transaction between market participants on the measurement date.
916365_17_ITEM8_P79_S1	The Company uses a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P79_S2	These tiers include: Level 1, defined as observable inputs such as quoted prices in active markets; Level 2, defined as inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are either directly or indirectly observable; and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists, therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P80_S0	The Company s financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, short-term receivables, trade payables, debt instruments and an interest rate swap.
916365_17_ITEM8_P80_S1	Due to their short-term nature, the carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, short-term receivables and trade payables approximate current fair value at each balance sheet date.
916365_17_ITEM8_P80_S2	The Company had $275.0 million in borrowings under the senior credit facility (as discussed in Note 5) at December 31, 2016 , and $150.0 million in borrowings as of December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P80_S3	Based on current market interest rates (Level 2 inputs), the carrying value of our borrowings under the senior credit facility approximates fair value for each period reported.
916365_17_ITEM8_P81_S0	The fair value of the Company s interest rate swap is determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows using forward rate curves (a Level 2 input).
916365_17_ITEM8_P81_S1	As described in further detail in Note 6, the fair value of the interest rate swap, excluding accrued interest, is a $2.8 million asset at December 31, 2016 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P81_S2	The interest rate swap did not have a fair value at December 26, 2015 , as it was not in place at that date as described in Note 6.
916365_17_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Company accounts for derivative financial instruments in accordance with applicable accounting standards for such instruments and hedging activities, which require that all derivatives are recorded on the balance sheet at fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P82_S1	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivatives depends on the intended use of the derivative, whether the Company has elected to designate a derivative in a hedging relationship and apply hedge accounting and whether the hedging relationship has satisfied the criteria necessary to apply hedge accounting.
916365_17_ITEM8_P83_S0	Derivatives designated and qualifying as a hedge of the exposure to changes in the fair value of an asset, liability, or firm commitment attributable to a particular risk are considered fair value hedges.
916365_17_ITEM8_P83_S1	Derivatives designated and qualifying as a hedge of the exposure to variability in expected future cash flows, or other types of forecasted transactions, are considered cash flow hedges.
916365_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	Hedge accounting generally provides for the matching of the timing of gain or loss recognition on the hedging instrument with the recognition of the changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or liability that are attributable to the hedged risk in a fair value hedge or the earnings effect of the hedged forecasted transactions in a cash flow hedge.
916365_17_ITEM8_P85_S0	The Company may enter into derivative contracts that are intended to economically hedge a certain portion of its risk, even though hedge accounting does not apply or the Company elects not to apply the hedge accounting standards.
916365_17_ITEM8_P86_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost, as determined by the average cost method, or net realizable value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P87_S0	Inventory cost consists of the direct cost of merchandise including freight.
916365_17_ITEM8_P87_S1	Inventories are net of shrinkage, obsolescence, other valuations and vendor allowances.
916365_17_ITEM8_P88_S0	Property and equipment are carried at cost.
916365_17_ITEM8_P89_S0	Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
916365_17_ITEM8_P89_S1	Improvements to leased premises are amortized using the straight-line method over the initial term of the lease or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is less.
916365_17_ITEM8_P89_S2	The following estimated useful lives are generally applied:
916365_17_ITEM8_P90_S0	The Company entered into agreements with various governmental entities in the states of Kentucky, Georgia and Tennessee to implement tax abatement plans related to its distribution center in Franklin, Kentucky (Simpson County), its distribution center in Macon, Georgia (Bibb County) and its Store Support Center in Brentwood, Tennessee (Williamson County).
916365_17_ITEM8_P91_S0	plans provide for reduction of real property taxes for specified time frames by legally transferring title to its real property in exchange for industrial revenue bonds.
916365_17_ITEM8_P91_S1	This property was then leased back to the Company.
916365_17_ITEM8_P92_S0	The lease payments are equal to the amount of the payments on the bonds.
916365_17_ITEM8_P92_S1	The tax abatement period extends through the term of the lease, which coincides with the maturity date of the bonds.
916365_17_ITEM8_P92_S2	At any time, the Company has the option to purchase the real property by paying off the bonds, plus $1 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P92_S3	The terms and amounts authorized and drawn under each industrial revenue bond agreement are outlined as follows, as of December 31, 2016 :
916365_17_ITEM8_P93_S0	Due to the form of these transactions, the Company has not recorded the bonds or the lease obligation associated with the sale lease-back transaction.
916365_17_ITEM8_P93_S1	The original cost of the Company s property and equipment is recorded on the balance sheet and is being depreciated over its estimated useful life.
916365_17_ITEM8_P94_S0	The Company capitalizes certain costs related to the acquisition and development of software and amortizes these costs using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the software, which is three to five years.
916365_17_ITEM8_P95_S0	Computer software consists primarily of third-party software purchased for internal use.
916365_17_ITEM8_P95_S1	A subsequent addition, modification or upgrade to internal-use software is capitalized to the extent that it enhances the software s functionality or extends its useful life.
916365_17_ITEM8_P95_S2	These costs are included in computer software and hardware in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
916365_17_ITEM8_P95_S3	Certain software costs not meeting the criteria for capitalization are expensed as incurred.
916365_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	The Company regularly evaluates the performance of its stores and periodically closes those that are under-performing.
916365_17_ITEM8_P97_S0	The Company records a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred, usually in the period the store closes.
916365_17_ITEM8_P97_S1	Store closing costs were not significant to the results of operations for any of the fiscal years presented.
916365_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	Assets under capital leases are amortized in accordance with the Company s normal depreciation policy for owned assets or over the lease term, if shorter, and the related charge to operations is included in depreciation expense in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_17_ITEM8_P99_S0	Certain operating leases include rent increases during the lease term.
916365_17_ITEM8_P99_S1	For these leases, the Company recognizes the related rental expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease (which includes the pre-opening period of construction, renovation, fixturing and merchandise placement) and records the difference between the expense charged to operations and amounts paid as a deferred rent liability.
916365_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	The Company occasionally receives reimbursements from landlords to be used towards improving the related store to be leased.
916365_17_ITEM8_P100_S1	Leasehold improvements are recorded at their gross costs, including items reimbursed by landlords.
916365_17_ITEM8_P100_S2	Related reimbursements are deferred and amortized on a straight-line basis as a reduction of rent expense over the applicable lease term.
916365_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	Share-based compensation includes stock option and restricted stock unit awards and certain transactions under the Company s ESPP.
916365_17_ITEM8_P101_S1	Share-based compensation expense is recognized based on the grant date fair value of all stock option and restricted stock unit awards plus a discount on shares purchased by employees as a part of the ESPP.
916365_17_ITEM8_P101_S2	The discount under the ESPP represents the difference between the purchase date market value and the employee s purchase price.
916365_17_ITEM8_P102_S0	There were no significant modifications to the Company s share-based compensation plans during fiscal 2016 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P102_S1	At December 31, 2016 , the Company had approximately 3.8 million shares available for future equity awards under the Company s 2009 Stock Incentive Plan.
916365_17_ITEM8_P103_S0	Share-based compensation expense, including changes in expense for modifications of awards, was $23.6 million , $19.4 million and $16.2 million for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P104_S0	Under the Company s 2009 Stock Incentive Plan, options may be granted to current or prospective officers or employees, non-employee directors and consultants.
916365_17_ITEM8_P104_S1	The per share exercise price of options granted shall not be less than the fair market value of the stock on the date of grant and such options will expire no later than ten years from the date of grant.
916365_17_ITEM8_P105_S0	Vesting of options commences at various anniversary dates following the dates of grant.
916365_17_ITEM8_P106_S0	The fair value is separately estimated for each option grant.
916365_17_ITEM8_P106_S1	The fair value of each option is recognized as compensation expense ratably over the vesting period.
916365_17_ITEM8_P107_S0	The Company has estimated the fair value of all stock option awards as of the date of the grant by applying a Black-Scholes pricing valuation model.
916365_17_ITEM8_P107_S1	The application of this valuation model involves assumptions that are judgmental and highly sensitive in the determination of compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P107_S2	The ranges of key assumptions used in determining the fair value of options granted during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , as well as a summary of the methodology applied to develop each assumption, are as follows:
916365_17_ITEM8_P108_S0	This is a measure of the amount by which a price has fluctuated or is expected to fluctuate.
916365_17_ITEM8_P108_S1	The Company uses a blended volatility approach, weighting (i) actual historical changes in the market value of the stock at 75% and (ii) average implied volatility using tradable option data at 25% .
916365_17_ITEM8_P108_S2	To calculate historical changes in market value, the Company uses daily market value changes from the date of grant over a past period generally representative of the expected life of the options to determine volatility.
916365_17_ITEM8_P109_S0	To derive implied volatility, the Company relies on publicly traded options, with maturities of six months or greater.
916365_17_ITEM8_P109_S1	The Company believes this blended calculation of historical and expected price volatility provides the most relevant indicator of future volatility.
916365_17_ITEM8_P109_S2	An increase in the expected volatility will increase compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P110_S0	This is the United States Treasury Constant Maturity rate over a term equal to the expected life of the option.
916365_17_ITEM8_P110_S1	An increase in the risk-free interest rate will increase compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P111_S0	This is the period of time over which the options granted are expected to remain outstanding and is based on historical experience.
916365_17_ITEM8_P111_S1	Options granted generally have a maximum term of ten years.
916365_17_ITEM8_P111_S2	An increase in the expected life will increase compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P112_S0	Forfeiture Rate This is the estimated percentage of options granted that are expected to be forfeited or canceled before becoming fully vested.
916365_17_ITEM8_P112_S1	This estimate is based on historical experience.
916365_17_ITEM8_P112_S2	An increase in the forfeiture rate will decrease compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P113_S0	This is the estimated dividend yield for the weighted average expected life of the option granted.
916365_17_ITEM8_P113_S1	An increase in the dividend yield will decrease compensation expense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P114_S0	The Company issues shares for options when exercised.
916365_17_ITEM8_P114_S1	A summary of stock option activity is as follows:
916365_17_ITEM8_P115_S0	The aggregate intrinsic values in the table above represent the total difference between the Company s closing stock price at each year-end and the option exercise price, multiplied by the number of in-the-money options at each year-end.
916365_17_ITEM8_P116_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested stock options was approximately $21.3 million with a weighted average expense recognition period of 1.7 years.
916365_17_ITEM8_P117_S0	There were no material modifications to options in fiscal 2016 , 2015 or 2014 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P118_S0	Other information relative to option activity during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 is as follows (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P119_S0	The Company issues shares for restricted stock unit awards once vesting occurs and related restrictions lapse.
916365_17_ITEM8_P119_S1	The units vest over a one to four year term; some plan participants have elected to defer receipt of shares of common stock upon vesting of restricted stock units, and as a result, shares are not issued until a later date.
916365_17_ITEM8_P119_S2	The status of restricted stock units is presented below:
916365_17_ITEM8_P120_S0	Other information relative to restricted stock unit activity during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 is as follows (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P121_S0	For the majority of restricted stock units granted, the number of shares issued on the date the restricted stock units vest is net of shares withheld by the Company for the minimum statutory tax withholding requirements, which the Company pays on behalf of its employees.
916365_17_ITEM8_P121_S1	The Company issued 48,267 , 72,206 , and 134,964 shares as a result of vested restricted stock units during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P121_S2	Although shares withheld are not issued, they are treated similar to common stock repurchases as they reduce the number of shares that would have been issued upon vesting.
916365_17_ITEM8_P121_S3	The amounts are net of 10,236 , 35,342 , and 77,192 shares withheld to satisfy $0.8 million , $3.0 million , and $4.8 million of employees tax obligations during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P122_S0	There were no material modifications to restricted stock units in fiscal 2016 , 2015 or 2014 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P123_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested restricted stock units was approximately $5.4 million with a weighted average expense recognition period of 1.6 years.
916365_17_ITEM8_P124_S0	The ESPP provides Company employees the opportunity to purchase, through payroll deductions, shares of common stock at a 15% discount.
916365_17_ITEM8_P124_S1	Pursuant to the terms of the ESPP, the Company issued 69,562 , 68,428 and 78,670 shares of common stock during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P124_S2	The total cost related to the ESPP, including the compensation expense calculations, was approximately $1.1 million , $1.1 million and $1.0 million in fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P125_S0	There are a maximum of 16.0 million shares of common stock that are reserved under the ESPP.
916365_17_ITEM8_P125_S1	At December 31, 2016 , there were approximately 12.1 million remaining shares of common stock reserved for future issuance under the ESPP.
916365_17_ITEM8_P126_S0	Note 3 - Acquisition of Petsense:
916365_17_ITEM8_P127_S0	On September 29, 2016 , the Company completed the acquisition of Petsense.
916365_17_ITEM8_P127_S1	Headquartered in Scottsdale, Arizona, Petsense is a small-box pet specialty supply retailer focused on meeting the needs of pet owners, primarily in small and mid-size communities, and offering a variety of pet products and services.
916365_17_ITEM8_P127_S2	Pursuant to the agreement governing the transaction, the Company acquired all the outstanding equity interests in Petsense for an all-cash purchase price of $145.7 million .
916365_17_ITEM8_P127_S3	The acquisition was financed with cash-on-hand and revolver borrowings under the 2016 Senior Credit Facility (as defined in Note 5).
916365_17_ITEM8_P128_S0	The total consideration transferred in connection with the Petsense acquisition has been allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon their respective fair values.
916365_17_ITEM8_P128_S1	The fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is estimated based on one or a combination of income, cost or market approaches as determined based on the nature of the asset or liability and the level of inputs available.
916365_17_ITEM8_P128_S2	With respect to assets and liabilities, the determination of fair value requires management to make subjective judgments as to projections of future operating performance, the appropriate discount rate to apply, long-term growth rates, etc. (i.e. - unobservable inputs classified as Level 3 inputs under the fair value hierarchy) which affect the amounts recorded in the purchase price allocation.
916365_17_ITEM8_P128_S3	The excess of the consideration transferred over the fair value of the identifiable assets, net of liabilities, is recorded as goodwill, which is indicative of the expected continued growth and development of the pet specialty retail business acquired.
916365_17_ITEM8_P129_S0	The table below summarizes the consideration transferred and provisional allocation of the purchase price for the Petsense acquisition (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P130_S0	The fair value estimates of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as reflected in the table above are subject to adjustments during the measurement period.
916365_17_ITEM8_P130_S1	The preliminary values of the consideration transferred, assets acquired and liabilities assumed, including the related tax effects, are subject to receipt of a final working capital settlement, pursuant to the agreement governing the transaction.
916365_17_ITEM8_P131_S0	The resulting goodwill of $ 84.2 million and tradename of $ 31.3 million are deductible for income tax purposes.
916365_17_ITEM8_P132_S0	Approximately $ 2.8 million of transaction costs related to the Petsense acquisition were expensed during the year ended December 31, 2016 , and are included in selling, general and administrative expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Income.
916365_17_ITEM8_P133_S0	The results of operations of Petsense have been included in the Consolidated Financial Statements since the date of acquisition.
916365_17_ITEM8_P134_S0	Note 4 - Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets:
916365_17_ITEM8_P135_S0	The Company had approximately $ 94.4 million and $10.3 million of goodwill at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P135_S1	The changes in the carrying amount of goodwill for the years ended December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015 are as follows (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P136_S0	Goodwill is allocated to each identified reporting unit, which is defined as an operating segment or one level below the operating segment.
916365_17_ITEM8_P137_S0	Goodwill is not amortized, but is evaluated for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of goodwill may not be recoverable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P137_S1	The Company completes its impairment evaluation by performing valuation analyses and considering other publicly available market information, as appropriate.
916365_17_ITEM8_P138_S0	The test for goodwill impairment is a two-step process.
916365_17_ITEM8_P139_S0	The first step of the goodwill impairment test, used to identify the potential for impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with the carrying value of its net assets, including goodwill.
916365_17_ITEM8_P139_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit, the second step of the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recorded, if any.
916365_17_ITEM8_P139_S2	The second step, if required, would compare the implied fair value of goodwill with the current carrying amount of goodwill.
916365_17_ITEM8_P139_S3	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value, an impairment charge would be recorded to the Company s operations.
916365_17_ITEM8_P140_S0	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 , the Company completed its annual impairment testing of goodwill and no impairment was identified.
916365_17_ITEM8_P140_S1	The Company determined that the fair value of each reporting unit (including goodwill) was in excess of the carrying value of the respective reporting unit and as such, the second step was not necessary.
916365_17_ITEM8_P140_S2	In reaching this conclusion, the fair value of each reporting unit was determined based on either a market or an income approach.
916365_17_ITEM8_P141_S0	Under the market approach, the fair value is based on observed market prices.
916365_17_ITEM8_P142_S0	Approximately $ 31.3 million of intangible assets other than goodwill were acquired during the year ended December 31, 2016 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P142_S1	The acquired intangible asset represents the estimated fair value of the Petsense tradename, which is not subject to amortization as it has an indefinite useful life on the basis that it is expected to contribute cash flows beyond the foreseeable horizon.
916365_17_ITEM8_P143_S0	With respect to intangible assets, we evaluate for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
916365_17_ITEM8_P143_S1	We recognize an impairment loss only if the carrying amount is not recoverable through its discounted cash flows and measure the impairment loss based on the difference between the carrying value and fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P143_S2	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 , the Company completed its annual impairment testing of intangible assets and no impairment was identified.
916365_17_ITEM8_P144_S0	Note 5 - Senior Credit Facility:
916365_17_ITEM8_P145_S0	On February 19, 2016, the Company entered into a senior credit facility (the 2016 Senior Credit Facility ) consisting of a $200 million term loan and a $500 million revolving credit facility (with a sublimit of $50 million for swingline loans).
916365_17_ITEM8_P145_S1	This agreement is unsecured and matures on February 19, 2021 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P146_S0	During the period of October 24, 2011 through February 19, 2016, the Company was party to a senior credit facility (the 2011 Senior Credit Facility ), which provided for borrowings up to $400 million (with a sublimit of $30 million for swingline loans) as of December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P147_S0	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility contains a $200 million term loan which requires quarterly payments totaling $10 million per year in years one and two and $20 million per year in years three through five, with the remaining balance due in full on the maturity date of February 19, 2021 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P147_S1	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility also contains a $500 million revolving credit facility (with a sublimit of $50 million for swingline loans).
916365_17_ITEM8_P148_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , the Company had outstanding total borrowings of $275.0 million under the 2016 Senior Credit Facility consisting of $190.0 million in borrowings under the term loan and $85.0 million in borrowings under the revolving credit facility.
916365_17_ITEM8_P148_S1	Unamortized debt issuance costs recorded as an offset to the outstanding borrowings were approximately $1.1 million at December 31, 2016 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P148_S2	Additionally, there were $44.3 million of outstanding letters of credit under the 2016 Senior Credit Facility as of December 31, 2016 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P149_S0	Borrowings under both the term loan and the revolver bear interest at either the bank s base rate ( 3.750% at December 31, 2016 ) or the London Inter-Bank Offer Rate ( LIBOR ) ( 0.772% at December 31, 2016 ) plus an additional amount ranging from 0.500% to 1.125% per annum ( 0.625% at December 31, 2016 ), adjusted quarterly based on our leverage ratio.
916365_17_ITEM8_P149_S1	The Company is also required to pay, quarterly in arrears, a commitment fee for unused capacity ranging from 0.075% to 0.200% per annum ( 0.100% at December 31, 2016 ), adjusted quarterly based on the Company s leverage ratio.
916365_17_ITEM8_P150_S0	Proceeds from the 2016 Senior Credit Facility may be used for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends, share repurchases, and other matters.
916365_17_ITEM8_P150_S1	There are no compensating balance requirements associated with the 2016 Senior Credit Facility.
916365_17_ITEM8_P151_S0	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility requires quarterly compliance with respect to two material covenants: a fixed charge coverage ratio and a leverage ratio.
916365_17_ITEM8_P151_S1	Both ratios are calculated on a trailing twelve-month basis at the end of each fiscal quarter.
916365_17_ITEM8_P152_S0	The fixed charge coverage ratio compares earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, share-based compensation and rent expense ( consolidated EBITDAR ) to the sum of interest paid and rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments).
916365_17_ITEM8_P152_S1	The fixed charge coverage ratio shall be greater than or equal to 2.00 as of the last day of each fiscal quarter.
916365_17_ITEM8_P153_S0	The leverage ratio compares rental expense (excluding any straight-line rent adjustments) multiplied by a factor of six plus total debt to consolidated EBITDAR.
916365_17_ITEM8_P153_S1	The leverage ratio shall be less than or equal to 4.00 as of the last day of each fiscal quarter.
916365_17_ITEM8_P153_S2	The 2016 Senior Credit Facility also contains certain other restrictions regarding additional indebtedness, capital expenditures, business operations, guarantees, investments, mergers, consolidations and sales of assets, transactions with subsidiaries or affiliates, and liens.
916365_17_ITEM8_P153_S3	As of December 31, 2016 , the Company was in compliance with all debt covenants.
916365_17_ITEM8_P154_S0	Under the 2011 Senior Credit Facility, the Company had outstanding borrowings of $150.0 million as of December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P154_S1	In addition, there were $48.7 million of outstanding letters of credit under the 2011 Senior Credit Facility as of December 26, 2015 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P155_S0	Note 6 - Interest Rate Swap:
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S0	On March 28, 2016, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement which became effective on March 31, 2016 , with a maturity date of February 19, 2021 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S1	The interest rate swap was executed for risk management and is not held for trading purposes.
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S2	The objective of the interest rate swap is to mitigate interest rate risk associated with future changes in interest rates.
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S3	To accomplish this objective, the interest rate swap is intended to hedge the variable cash flows associated with the variable rate term loan borrowings under the 2016 Senior Credit Facility.
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S4	The notional amount of the interest rate swap began at $197.5 million (the principal amount of the term loan borrowings as of March 31, 2016) and will amortize at the same time and in the same amount as the term loan borrowings as described in Note 5.
916365_17_ITEM8_P156_S5	As of December 31, 2016 , the notional amount of the interest rate swap was $190.0 million .
916365_17_ITEM8_P157_S0	The interest rate swap entitles the Company to receive, at specified intervals, a variable rate of interest based on LIBOR in exchange for the payment of a fixed rate of interest throughout the life of the agreement without exchange of the underlying notional amount.
916365_17_ITEM8_P158_S0	The Company has designated this interest rate swap as a cash flow hedge and will account for the underlying activity in accordance with hedge accounting.
916365_17_ITEM8_P158_S1	The interest rate swap is presented within the consolidated balance sheets at fair value.
916365_17_ITEM8_P159_S0	In accordance with hedge accounting, the effective portion of gains and losses on interest rate swaps that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges are recorded as a component of Other Comprehensive Income ( OCI ) and reclassified into earnings in the period during which the hedged transactions affect earnings.
916365_17_ITEM8_P159_S1	The ineffective portion of gains and losses on the interest rate swap, if any, are recognized in current earnings.
916365_17_ITEM8_P160_S0	The amounts measured at fair value related to the Company s interest rate swap, excluding accrued interest, were as follows (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P161_S0	The offset to the interest rate swap asset is recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income ( AOCI ) (a component of equity), net of deferred taxes, and will be reclassified into earnings over the term of the underlying debt as interest payments are made.
916365_17_ITEM8_P162_S0	The following table summarizes the changes in AOCI, net of tax, related to the Company s interest rate swaps (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P163_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , the estimated pre-tax portion of AOCI that is expected to be reclassified into earnings over the next twelve months is $0.4 million .
916365_17_ITEM8_P164_S0	Cash flows related to the interest rate swap are included in operating activities on the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
916365_17_ITEM8_P165_S0	The following table summarizes the impact of pre-tax gains and losses derived from the interest rate swap (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P166_S0	The following table summarizes the impact of taxes affecting AOCI as a result of the interest rate swap (in thousands):
916365_17_ITEM8_P167_S0	In accordance with the underlying interest rate swap agreement, the Company could be declared in default on its interest rate swap obligations if repayment of the underlying indebtedness (i.e. - the Company s term loan) is accelerated by the lender due to the Company's default on such indebtedness.
916365_17_ITEM8_P168_S0	If the Company had breached any of the provisions in the underlying agreement at December 31, 2016 , it could have been required to post full collateral or settle its obligations under the interest rate swap agreement.
916365_17_ITEM8_P168_S1	However, as of December 31, 2016 , the Company had not breached any of these provisions or posted any collateral related to the underlying interest rate swap agreement.
916365_17_ITEM8_P168_S2	Further, as of December 31, 2016 , the interest rate swap is in a net asset position and therefore the Company would hold no obligation upon default.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S0	The Company leases the majority of its retail store locations, two distribution sites, its Merchandise Innovation Center, transportation equipment and other equipment under various non-cancellable operating leases.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S1	The leases have varying terms and expire at various dates through 2033 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S2	Store leases typically have initial terms of between 10 and 15 years, with two to four optional renewal periods of five years each.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S3	Some leases require the payment of contingent rent that is based upon store sales above agreed-upon sales levels for the year.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S4	The sales levels vary for each store and are established in the lease agreements.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S5	Generally, most of the leases also require that the Company pays associated taxes, insurance and maintenance costs.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S6	Total rent expense for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 was approximately $293.0 million , $262.1 million and $239.3 million , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P169_S7	Total contingent rent expense for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 was insignificant.

916365_17_ITEM8_P177_S2	The repurchases may be made from time to time on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P177_S3	The timing and amount of any shares repurchased under the program will depend on a variety of factors, including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, capital availability, and other market conditions.
916365_17_ITEM8_P177_S4	Repurchased shares are accounted for at cost and will be held in treasury for future issuance.
916365_17_ITEM8_P177_S5	The program may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
916365_17_ITEM8_P178_S0	The Company repurchased approximately 4.4 million , 3.4 million and 4.7 million shares of common stock under the share repurchase program at a total cost of $331.7 million , $292.7 million and $298.5 million in fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P178_S1	As of December 31, 2016 , the Company had remaining authorization under the share repurchase program of $1.2 billion , exclusive of any fees, commissions, or other expenses.

916365_17_ITEM8_P191_S0	Note 12 - Retirement Benefit Plans:
916365_17_ITEM8_P192_S0	The Company has a defined contribution benefit plan, the Tractor Supply Company 401(k) Retirement Savings Plan (the 401(k)Plan ), which provides retirement benefits for eligible employees.
916365_17_ITEM8_P192_S1	The Company matches (in cash) 100% of the employee s elective contributions up to 3% of eligible compensation plus 50% of the employee s elective contributions from 3% to 6% of eligible compensation.
916365_17_ITEM8_P192_S2	In no event shall the total Company match made on behalf of the employee exceed 4.5% of the employee s eligible compensation.
916365_17_ITEM8_P192_S3	All current contributions are immediately vested.
916365_17_ITEM8_P192_S4	Company contributions to the 401(k) Plan during fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , were approximately $6.6 million , $5.9 million and $5.6 million , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P193_S0	The Company offers, through a deferred compensation program, the opportunity for certain qualifying employees to elect to defer a portion of their annual base salary and/or their annual incentive bonus.
916365_17_ITEM8_P193_S1	Under the deferred compensation program, a percentage of the participants salary deferral is matched by the Company, limited to a maximum annual matching contribution of $4,500 .
916365_17_ITEM8_P193_S2	The Company s contributions, including accrued interest, were $0.6 million in fiscal 2016 and $0.5 million in each of fiscal 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
916365_17_ITEM8_P194_S0	Construction and Real Estate Commitments As of December 31, 2016 , the Company had no material commitments related to construction projects extending greater than twelve months.
