916365_17_ITEM15_P11_S0	In connection with the Annual Report ( Report ) of Tractor Supply Company (the Company ) on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016 , as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof, we, Gregory A. Sandfort, Chief Executive Officer, and Anthony F. Crudele, Chief Financial Officer, of the Company, certify, pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (18 U.S.C. section 1350), that:
916365_17_ITEM15_P12_S0	(2) The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
916365_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	Tractor Supply Company (the Company or we ) is the largest operator of rural lifestyle retail stores in the United States ( U.S. ).
916365_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company is focused on supplying the needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and others who enjoy the rural lifestyle (which we refer to as the Out Here lifestyle), as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	We operate retail stores under the names Tractor Supply Company, Del s Feed Farm Supply and Petsense and operate websites under the names TractorSupply.com and Petsense.com .
916365_18_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our stores are located primarily in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities.
916365_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Tractor Supply Company has one reportable industry segment which is the retail sale of products that support the rural lifestyle.
916365_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	At December 30, 2017 , we operated 1,853 retail stores in 49 states ( 1,685 Tractor Supply and Del s retail stores and 168 Petsense retail stores).
916365_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our Tractor Supply stores typically range in size from 15,000 to 20,000 square feet of inside selling space, along with additional outside selling space, and our Petsense stores have approximately 5,500 square feet of inside selling space.
916365_18_ITEM1_P1_S3	For Tractor Supply retail locations, we use a standard design for most new built-to-suit locations that includes approximately 15,500 square feet of inside selling space.
916365_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	We believe our sales and earnings growth is the result of executing our business strategy, which includes the following key components:
916365_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	Market Niche We have identified a specialized market niche: supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers and others who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_18_ITEM1_P3_S1	By focusing our product assortment on these core customers, we believe we are differentiated from general merchandise, home center and other specialty retailers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P3_S2	We cater to the rural lifestyle and often serve a market by being a trip consolidator for many basic maintenance needs for farm, ranch and rural customers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	Customers Our target customers are home, land, pet and livestock owners who generally have above average income and below average cost of living.
916365_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	We seek to serve a customer base that primarily lives in towns outlying major metropolitan markets and in rural communities.
916365_18_ITEM1_P4_S2	This customer base includes recreational farmers and ranchers and others who enjoy the rural lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	Customer Service We are committed to providing our customers reliable product availability and a high level of in-store service through our motivated, well-trained store team members.
916365_18_ITEM1_P5_S1	We believe the ability of our store team members to provide friendly, responsive and seasoned advice helps our customers find the right products to satisfy their everyday needs as well as the specialty items needed to complete their rural lifestyle projects.
916365_18_ITEM1_P5_S2	We also engage with our customers through our e-commerce website ( TractorSupply.com ), which provides the opportunity to allow customers to shop at a time and place that fits their schedule while delivering enhanced product information, research and decision tools that support product selection and informational needs in specific subject areas.
916365_18_ITEM1_P5_S3	Additionally, we maintain a customer solutions center at our Store Support Center located in Brentwood, Tennessee to support our in-store and online customers as well as our store team members.
916365_18_ITEM1_P5_S4	We believe this commitment to customer service promotes strong customer loyalty and repeat shopping.
916365_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	We use a third-party provider to measure our level of customer service.
916365_18_ITEM1_P6_S1	This process allows customers to provide feedback on their shopping experience.
916365_18_ITEM1_P6_S2	Based on the third-party provider s data, we believe our customer satisfaction scores to be among the best-in-class.
916365_18_ITEM1_P6_S3	We carefully evaluate the feedback we receive from our customers and implement improvements at the individual store level based on that feedback.
916365_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	Store Personnel and Training We seek to hire store team members with farming and ranching backgrounds, with particular emphasis on general maintenance, equine and welding.
916365_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	We endeavor to staff our stores with courteous, highly motivated team members and devote considerable resources to training store team members, often in cooperation with our vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	an annual store manager meeting with vendor product presentations.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our stores are designed and managed to make shopping an enjoyable experience and to maximize sales and operating efficiencies.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S1	Stores are strategically arranged to provide an open environment for optimal product placement and visual display.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S2	In addition, these layouts allow for departmental space to be easily re-allocated and visual displays to be changed for seasonal products and promotions.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S3	Display and product placement information is routinely sent to stores to ensure quality and uniformity among the stores.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S4	Informative signs are located in key product categories to assist customers with purchasing decisions and merchandise location.
916365_18_ITEM1_P9_S5	These signs provide customers with a comparison of product qualities, clear pricing, useful information regarding product benefits, and suggestions for appropriate accessories.
916365_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our store layouts and visual displays are designed to provide our customers a feeling of familiarity and enhance the shopping experience.
916365_18_ITEM1_P10_S1	Also, our store team members wear highly visible red vests, aprons or smocks with nametags, and our customer service and checkout counters are conveniently located near the front of the store.
916365_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	Merchandising and Purchasing We offer an extensive assortment of products for those seeking to enjoy the Out Here lifestyle, as well as tradesmen and small businesses.
916365_18_ITEM1_P11_S1	Our product assortment is tailored to meet the needs of our customers in various geographic markets.
916365_18_ITEM1_P11_S2	Our full line of product offerings includes a broad selection of high quality, reputable brand name and exclusive brand products and is supported by a strong in-stock inventory position with an average of 15,500 to 20,000 products per store.
916365_18_ITEM1_P11_S3	No one product accounted for more than 10% of our sales during 2017 .
916365_18_ITEM1_P11_S4	Our comprehensive selection of merchandise is comprised of the following major product categories:
916365_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	Maintenance products for agricultural and rural use.
916365_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	The following table indicates the percentage of net sales represented by each of our major product categories during fiscal 2017 , 2016 and 2015 :
916365_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our buying team continuously reviews and updates our product assortment to respond to customer needs and to offer new, relevant products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	needs with emphasis on consumable, usable, and edible ( C.U.E. ) products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P15_S1	Examples of C.U.E. product categories include, but are not limited to, livestock feed and bedding, pet food, lubricants, and various seasonal products, such as heating, pest control and twine.
916365_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	Our products are sourced through both domestic and international vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our business is not dependent upon any one vendor or particular group of vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1_P16_S2	We purchase our products from a group of approximately 900 vendors, with no one vendor representing more than 10% of our purchases during fiscal 2017 .
916365_18_ITEM1_P16_S3	Approximately 350 core vendors accounted for 90% of our merchandise purchases during fiscal 2017 .
916365_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	We have not experienced any significant difficulty in obtaining satisfactory alternative sources of supply for our products, and we believe that adequate sources of supply exist at substantially similar costs for nearly all of our products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P17_S1	We have no material long-term contractual commitments with any of our product vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	Our buying teams focus on merchandise procurement, vendor line reviews and testing of new products and programs.
916365_18_ITEM1_P18_S1	We also employ a dedicated inventory management team that focuses exclusively on forecasting and inventory replenishment, a committed merchandise planning team that concentrates on assortment planning and a specialized pricing team that seeks to optimize market-specific pricing for our products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P18_S2	Through the combined efforts of these teams, we continue to focus on improving our overall inventory productivity and in-stock position.
916365_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	Intellectual Property Our subsidiary, Tractor Supply Co. of Texas, LP ( TSCT ), owns registrations with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office ( USPTO ) for various service marks including TSC , Tractor Supply Co. , TSC Tractor Supply Co. and the trapezium design for retail store services.
916365_18_ITEM1_P19_S1	We consider these service marks, and the accompanying goodwill and name recognition, to be valuable assets of our business.
916365_18_ITEM1_P19_S2	TSCT also owns several other service marks for retail services, some of which have been registered with the USPTO and some of which are the subject of applications for registration pending before the USPTO.
916365_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	In addition to selling products that bear nationally-known manufacturer brands, we also sell products manufactured for us under a number of exclusive brands that we consider to be important to our business.
916365_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	These exclusive brands are manufactured for us by a number of vendors and provide an alternative to the national brands, which helps provide value for our customers and positions us as a destination store.
916365_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	Our exclusive brands represented approximately 32% of our total sales in both fiscal 2017 and 2016 and 31% in fiscal 2015 .
916365_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	The exclusive brands identified above have been registered as trademarks with the USPTO for certain products and are the subject of applications for registration pending before the USPTO for other products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our trademark and service mark registrations have various expiration dates; however, provided that we continue to use the marks and renew the registrations in a timely manner, the registrations are potentially perpetual in duration.
916365_18_ITEM1_P24_S0	We believe our intellectual property, which includes the trademarks and service marks identified above, together with certain trade names, domain names, patents and copyrights, has significant value and is an important component of our merchandising and marketing strategies.
916365_18_ITEM1_P25_S0	Distribution We currently operate a distribution network for supplying stores with merchandise and delivering product ordered through TractorSupply.com .
916365_18_ITEM1_P25_S1	In fiscal 2017 , our Tractor Supply stores received approximately 74% of merchandise through this network while the remaining merchandise shipped directly to the stores from our vendors or directly to our customers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P25_S2	We believe this flow facilitates the prompt and efficient distribution of merchandise in order to enhance in-stocks, minimize freight costs and improve the inventory turn rate.
916365_18_ITEM1_P25_S3	Our distribution facilities, located in Arizona, Georgia, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Nebraska, Texas, and Washington, represent total distribution capacity of 5.0 million square feet.
916365_18_ITEM1_P25_S4	In fiscal 2017, we began construction on a new northeast distribution center in Frankfort, New York, as well as an expansion of our existing distribution center in Waverly, Nebraska, which will provide additional distribution capacity once construction is completed.
916365_18_ITEM1_P26_S0	We select the locations of our distribution facilities in an effort to minimize logistics costs and optimize the distance from distribution facilities to our stores.
916365_18_ITEM1_P26_S1	Our distribution centers utilize warehouse and labor management tools that support the planning, control and processing of inventory.
916365_18_ITEM1_P26_S2	We manage our inbound and outbound transportation activity in-house through the use of a transportation management system.
916365_18_ITEM1_P26_S3	We utilize multiple common carriers for store and direct to customer deliveries.
916365_18_ITEM1_P26_S4	We manage our transportation costs through carrier negotiations, the monitoring of transportation routes, and the scheduling of deliveries.
916365_18_ITEM1_P27_S0	Marketing We utilize an everyday value price philosophy to consistently offer our products at competitive prices complemented by strategically planned promotions throughout the year.
916365_18_ITEM1_P27_S1	To drive store traffic and position ourselves as a destination store, we promote broad selections of merchandise with newspaper circulars, customer targeted direct mail as well as e-mail, digital and social media initiatives.
916365_18_ITEM1_P27_S2	In addition, our Neighbor s Club loyalty program enhances our ability to create engagement with our best customers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P27_S3	Vendors frequently support these specific programs by offering temporary cost reductions and honoring coupons.
916365_18_ITEM1_P27_S4	Our vendors also provide assistance with product presentation and fixture design, brochures, support for in-store events and point-of-purchase materials for customer education and product knowledge for our team members.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S0	Omni-Channel We connect with our customers in their manner of choosing, whether that is in store, on our e-commerce website ( TractorSupply.com ), e-mail, social media, direct mail or through our customer solutions center.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S1	Our goal is to be available anytime, anywhere and in any way our customers choose to engage with our brand.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S2	We provide our customers the opportunity to shop in a manner that fits their lifestyle and is most convenient for them.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S3	We offer an expansive product assortment, search capabilities and information that is relevant for their lifestyle.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S4	We provide our customers the ability to have products shipped direct to our retail stores, their homes or offices.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S5	We maintain two fulfillment centers within our distribution center network to support our e-commerce activities.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S6	In 2017, we completed the expansion of our buy online and pick up in store program which provides convenient customer pick up in our store locations.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S7	We also began providing additional convenience through flexible payment options and simplified checkout.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S8	We are focused on delivering an enhanced mobile and tablet experience, improving the site response time and expanding our product offerings for vendor direct to customer shipments, allowing us to serve our customers at any time.
916365_18_ITEM1_P28_S9	Digital capabilities have further enhanced customer service and allowed us to target markets outside of our current retail store locations.
916365_18_ITEM1_P29_S0	Management and Team Members As of December 30, 2017 , we employed approximately 14,000 full-time and 14,000 part-time Tractor Supply team members.
916365_18_ITEM1_P29_S1	We also employ additional part-time team members during peak periods.
916365_18_ITEM1_P29_S2	We are not party to any collective bargaining agreements.
916365_18_ITEM1_P30_S0	At the end of fiscal 2017 , our store operations were organized into ten regions.
916365_18_ITEM1_P30_S1	Each region is led by a regional vice president, and the region is further organized into districts, each of which is led by a district manager.
916365_18_ITEM1_P30_S2	We have two internal advisory boards, one comprised of store managers and the other comprised of district managers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P30_S3	These groups bring a grassroots perspective to operational initiatives and generate chain-wide endorsement of proposed best-practice solutions.
916365_18_ITEM1_P31_S0	All of our team members participate in one of various bonus incentive programs, which provide the opportunity to receive additional compensation based upon team and/or Company performance.
916365_18_ITEM1_P31_S1	In addition to bonus incentive programs, we provide our eligible team members the opportunity to participate in an employee stock purchase plan and a 401(k) retirement savings plan.
916365_18_ITEM1_P31_S2	We also share in the cost of health insurance provided to eligible team members, and team members receive a discount on merchandise purchased from the Company.
916365_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	We encourage a promote-from-within environment when internal resources permit.
916365_18_ITEM1_P32_S1	We also provide internal leadership development programs designed to prepare our high-potential team members for greater responsibility.
916365_18_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our current team of district managers and store managers have an average tenure of approximately nine and six years, respectively.
916365_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	promotions, coupled with the hiring of individuals with previous retail experience, will provide the management structure necessary to support our planned growth.
916365_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	Continuous Improvement We are committed to a continuous improvement program to drive change throughout our organization.
916365_18_ITEM1_P34_S1	Using data analytics and team member engagement, we examine business processes and identify opportunities to reduce costs, drive innovation, and improve effectiveness.
916365_18_ITEM1_P34_S2	We have implemented numerous continuous improvement projects (with team members from multiple areas of our business) to evaluate key operations and implement process changes.
916365_18_ITEM1_P34_S3	Team members are empowered and expected to challenge current paradigms and improve processes.
916365_18_ITEM1_P34_S4	Our management encourages the participation of all team members in decision-making, regularly solicits input and suggestions from our team members and incorporates suggestions into our improvement activities.
916365_18_ITEM1_P35_S0	We have invested resources in management information and control systems to provide legendary customer service.
916365_18_ITEM1_P35_S1	This includes use of digital technologies to integrate the customer experience in store, online, and through our customer solutions center, offering customers the ability to shop anytime, anywhere, and in any way they choose.
916365_18_ITEM1_P35_S2	Our key platforms include a point-of-sale system, in-store mobility and digital technology system, an e-commerce platform, a supply chain management and replenishment system, a transportation management system, warehouse and labor management tools, a price optimization system, a vendor purchase order control system, a merchandise presentation system, and a customer loyalty system.
916365_18_ITEM1_P35_S3	These systems are integrated through an enterprise resource planning ( ERP ) system.
916365_18_ITEM1_P35_S4	This ERP system tracks merchandise from initial order through ultimate sale and interfaces with our financial systems.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S0	We continue to invest in technology to support store, online, and distribution facility expansion.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S1	We also continue to evaluate and improve the functionality of our systems to maximize their effectiveness.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S2	Such efforts include ongoing hardware and software evaluations, refreshes and upgrades to support optimal software configurations and application performance.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S3	We plan to continue to invest in information technology and implement efficiency-driving system enhancements, as well as evaluate use of technologies to improve productivity such as artificial intelligence, automation software, and other technologies.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S4	We also maintain and continue to strengthen the security of our information systems to help protect and prevent unauthorized access to personal information of our customers, employees and vendors or other confidential Company data.
916365_18_ITEM1_P36_S5	Collectively, these efforts are directed toward improving business processes, maintaining secure, efficient and stable systems, and enabling the continued growth and success of our business.
916365_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	Petsense Petsense is a small-box pet specialty supply retailer focused on meeting the needs of pet owners, primarily in small and mid-sized communities, and offering a variety of pet products and services.
916365_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	At December 30, 2017, we operated a total of 168 Petsense stores in 26 states, with 400 full-time and 900 part-time team members, and an e-commerce website ( Petsense.com ).
916365_18_ITEM1_P37_S2	The Petsense name is registered with the USPTO.
916365_18_ITEM1_P38_S0	Tractor Supply believes we can grow our business by being the most dependable supplier of relevant products and services for the Out Here lifestyle, creating customer loyalty through personalized experiences and providing convenience that our customers expect at anytime, anywhere, and in any way they choose.
916365_18_ITEM1_P38_S1	Our long-term growth strategy is to: (1) drive profitable growth through new store openings and by expanding omni-channel capabilities, thus tying together our website product content, social media, digital and online shopping experience, attracting new customers and driving loyalty, (2) build customer-centric engagement by leveraging analytics to deliver legendary customer service, seasoned advice and personalized experiences, (3) offer relevant assortments and services across all channels through exclusive and national brands and continue to introduce new products through our test and learn strategy, (4) enhance our core and foundational capabilities by investing in infrastructure and process improvements which will support growth, scale and agility while improving the customer experience, and (5) expand through selective acquisitions, as such opportunities arise, to add complementary businesses and to enhance penetration into new and existing markets to supplement organic growth.
916365_18_ITEM1_P39_S0	Achieving this strategy will require a foundational focus on: (1) organizing, optimizing and empowering our team members for growth by developing skills, talent and leadership across the organization, and (2) implementing operational efficiency initiatives to align our cost structure to support new business capabilities for margin improvement and cost reductions.
916365_18_ITEM1_P40_S0	Over the past five years, we have experienced considerable sales growth, resulting in a compounded annual growth rate of approximately 9.2% .
916365_18_ITEM1_P40_S1	We plan to open approximately 80 new Tractor Supply and 20 new Petsense stores in fiscal 2018 , a selling square footage increase of approximately 5.0% .
916365_18_ITEM1_P41_S0	In fiscal 2016, we opened 113 new Tractor Supply stores and began operating 143 Petsense stores.
916365_18_ITEM1_P41_S1	This represents a selling square footage increase of approximately 6.3% during fiscal 2017 and 10.8% during fiscal 2016 .
916365_18_ITEM1_P42_S0	At December 30, 2017 , we operated 1,853 retail stores in 49 states ( 1,685 Tractor Supply and Del s retail stores and 168 Petsense retail stores).
916365_18_ITEM1_P43_S0	Given the size of the communities that we target, we believe that there is ample opportunity for new store growth in many existing and new markets.
916365_18_ITEM1_P43_S1	We have developed a proven method for selecting store sites and have identified approximately 800 additional markets for new Tractor Supply stores.
916365_18_ITEM1_P43_S2	We also believe that there is opportunity for up to 1,000 Petsense stores.
916365_18_ITEM1_P43_S3	Approximately 40% of our Tractor Supply stores are in freestanding buildings and 60% are located in strip shopping centers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P43_S4	We lease approximately 93% of our stores and own the remaining 7% .
916365_18_ITEM1_P44_S0	We operate in a competitive retail industry.
916365_18_ITEM1_P44_S1	The principal competitive factors include location of stores, fulfillment options, price, quality of merchandise, in-stock consistency, merchandise assortment and presentation, product knowledge and customer service.
916365_18_ITEM1_P44_S2	We compete with general merchandise retailers, home center retailers, specialty and discount retailers, independently owned retail farm and ranch stores, numerous privately-held regional farm store chains and farm cooperatives, as well as internet-based retailers.
916365_18_ITEM1_P44_S3	However, we believe we successfully differentiate ourselves from many of these retailers by focusing on our specialized market niche for customers living the rural lifestyle.
916365_18_ITEM1_P44_S4	See further discussion of competition in 1A, Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
916365_18_ITEM1_P45_S0	Historically, our sales and profits are the highest in the second and fourth fiscal quarters due to the sale of seasonal products.
916365_18_ITEM1_P45_S1	We experience our highest inventory and accounts payable balances during our first fiscal quarter for purchases of seasonal products to support the higher sales volume of the spring selling season, and again during our third fiscal quarter to support the higher sales volume of the cold-weather selling season.
916365_18_ITEM1_P45_S2	We believe that our business can be more accurately assessed by focusing on the performance of the halves, not the quarters, due to the fact that different weather patterns from year-to-year can shift the timing of sales and profits between quarters, particularly between the first and second fiscal quarters and the third and fourth fiscal quarters.
916365_18_ITEM1_P46_S0	Historically, weather conditions, including unseasonably warm weather in the fall and winter months and unseasonably cool weather in the spring and summer months, have affected the timing and volume of our sales and results of operations.
916365_18_ITEM1_P46_S1	In addition, extreme weather conditions, including snow and ice storms, flood and wind damage, hurricanes, tornadoes, extreme rain and droughts, have impacted operating results both negatively and positively, depending on the severity and length of these conditions.
916365_18_ITEM1_P47_S0	Our strategy is to manage product flow and adjust merchandise assortments and depth of inventory to capitalize on seasonal demand trends.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our operations are subject to numerous federal, state and local laws and regulations, enacted or adopted, regulating the discharge of materials into the environment or otherwise relating to the protection of the environment.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S1	We are committed to complying with all applicable environmental laws and regulations.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S2	We are also committed to becoming a more environmentally sustainable company.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S3	This commitment is demonstrated through our Stewardship Program, which is our environmental sustainability program.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S4	Through this program, the Company has implemented a number of initiatives designed to reduce our impact on the environment.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S5	These initiatives include the installation of energy management systems, LED lighting, high efficiency heating/air conditioning systems in our stores, and recycling programs in our stores, distribution facilities and the Store Support Center.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S6	Our Store Support Center, opened in 2014, and our distribution center in Casa Grande, Arizona, opened in 2015, were each awarded LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) Silver certification for environmentally sustainable design, construction and operation.
916365_18_ITEM1_P48_S7	We also installed solar arrays at the Store Support Center in Brentwood, Tennessee and our store in Hendersonville, Tennessee.

916365_18_ITEM1_P50_S0	The following is a list of the names and ages of all executive officers of the registrant, indicating all positions and offices with the registrant held by each such person and each person s principal occupations and employment during at least the past five years:

916365_18_ITEM1_P51_S1	He served as President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company from December 2012 to May 2016.
916365_18_ITEM1_P51_S2	Prior to that time, he served as President and Chief Operating Officer of the Company since February 2012.

916365_18_ITEM1_P56_S4	He began his career with Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., where he served as an assistant manager and sales associate.

916365_18_ITEM1_P58_S0	From 2005 to 2011, Mr. Mills was Vice President, Chief Information Officer for the online business unit at Sears Holdings Corporation where he began as an Information Technology Customer Relationship Leader in 2001.
916365_18_ITEM1_P58_S1	Prior to 2001, Mr. Mills held roles at Allstate Insurance, Rockwell International Telecommunications Division, and Household Finance Corporation.
916365_18_ITEM1_P59_S0	We file reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), including Annual Reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and other reports as required.

916365_18_ITEM1_P59_S2	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
916365_18_ITEM1_P59_S3	We are an electronic filer and the SEC maintains an Internet site at sec.gov that contains the reports, proxy and information statements, and other information filed electronically.
916365_18_ITEM1_P60_S0	We make available, free of charge through our Internet website, TractorSupply.com , our Annual Report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and all amendments to those reports as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.
916365_18_ITEM1_P60_S1	The information provided on our website is not part of this report, and is therefore not incorporated by reference unless such information is otherwise specifically referenced elsewhere in this report.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Those risks of which we are currently aware and deem to be material are described below.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the events or circumstances described in the following risk factors occur, our business, financial condition or results of operations may significantly suffer, and the trading price of our common stock could decline.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	These risk factors should be read in conjunction with the other information in this Form 10-K.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	General economic conditions may adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our results of operations may be sensitive to changes in overall economic conditions that impact consumer spending, including discretionary spending.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P1_S2	A weakening of economic conditions affecting disposable consumer income such as lower employment levels, uncertainty or changes in business or political conditions, higher interest rates, higher tax rates, higher fuel and energy costs, higher labor and healthcare costs, the impact of natural disasters or acts of terrorism, and other matters could reduce consumer spending or cause consumers to shift their spending to competitors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P1_S3	A general reduction in the level of discretionary spending, shifts in consumer discretionary spending to our competitors or shifts in discretionary spending to less profitable products sold by us could result in lower net sales, slower inventory turnover, greater markdowns on inventory, and a reduction in profitability due to lower margins.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Failure to protect our reputation could have a material adverse effect on our brand name.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our success depends in part on the value and strength of the Tractor Supply name.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The Tractor Supply name is integral to our business as well as to the implementation of our strategies for expanding our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Maintaining, promoting, and positioning our brand will depend largely on the success of our marketing and merchandising efforts and our ability to provide high quality merchandise and a consistent, high quality customer experience.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Our brand could be adversely affected if we fail to achieve these objectives or if our public image or reputation were to be tarnished by negative publicity.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Failure to comply or accusation of failure to comply with ethical, social, product, labor, data privacy, and environmental standards could also jeopardize our reputation and potentially lead to various adverse consumer actions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P2_S6	Any of these events could result in decreased revenue or otherwise adversely affect our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may be unable to increase sales at our existing stores.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We experience fluctuations in our comparable store sales, defined as sales in stores which have been open for at least twelve months.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Various factors affect comparable store sales, including the general retail sales environment, our ability to efficiently source and distribute products, changes in our merchandise assortment, competition, proximity of our locations to one another or to the locations of other retailers, increased presence of online retailers, current economic conditions, customer satisfaction with our products, the timing of promotional events, the release of new merchandise, the success of marketing programs and weather conditions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P3_S3	These factors may cause our comparable store sales results to differ materially from prior periods and from expectations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Past comparable store sales are not an indication of future results, and there can be no assurance that our comparable store sales will not decrease in the future.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Purchase price volatility, including inflationary and deflationary pressures, may adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Although we cannot determine the full effect of inflation and deflation on our operations, we believe our sales and results of operations are affected by both.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We are subject to market risk with respect to the pricing of certain products and services, which include, among other items, grain, corn, steel, petroleum, cotton and other commodities as well as diesel fuel and transportation services.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Therefore, we may experience both inflationary and deflationary pressure on product cost, which may impact consumer demand and, as a result, sales and gross margin.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Our strategy is to reduce or mitigate the effects of purchase price volatility principally by taking advantage of vendor incentive programs, economies of scale from increased volume of purchases, adjusting retail prices and selectively buying from the most competitive vendors while maintaining product quality.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Should our strategy to mitigate purchase price volatility not be effective, our financial performance could be adversely impacted.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Weather conditions may have a significant impact on our financial results.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Weather conditions affect the demand for, and in some cases the supply of, products, which in turn has an impact on prices.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Historically, weather conditions, including unseasonably warm weather in the fall and winter months and unseasonably cool weather in the spring and summer months, have affected the timing and volume of our sales and results of operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	While extreme weather conditions can positively impact our operating results by increasing demand in affected locations for products needed to cope with the weather condition and its effects, they can also negatively affect our business depending on the severity and length of these conditions as a result of store closings or the inability of customers to shop at our stores due to weather conditions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our strategy is to manage product flow and adjust merchandise assortments and depth of inventory to capitalize on seasonal demand trends.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Should such a strategy not be effective, the weather may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our merchandising and marketing initiatives may not provide expected results.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We believe our past performance has been based on, and future success will depend upon, in part, the ability to develop and execute merchandising initiatives with effective marketing programs.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	These merchandising initiatives and marketing programs may not deliver expected results, and there is no assurance that we will correctly identify and respond in a timely manner to evolving trends and consumer preferences and expectations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	If we misjudge the market or our marketing programs are not successful, we may overstock unpopular products and be forced to take inventory price reductions that have a material adverse effect on our profitability.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Failure to execute and promote such initiatives in a timely manner could harm our ability to grow the business and could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Shortages of key merchandise could also have a material adverse impact on operating results and financial condition.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Capital required for growth may not be available.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The construction or acquisition of new stores, store support center facilities, distribution facilities or other facilities, the remodeling and renovation of existing facilities and investments in information technology require significant amounts of capital.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S2	In the past, our growth has been funded through internally generated cash flow and bank borrowings.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Disruptions in the capital and credit markets could adversely affect the ability of the banks to meet their commitments.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Our access to funds under our debt facilities is dependent on the ability of the banks that are parties to the facility to meet their funding commitments.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Those banks may not be able to meet their funding commitments to us if they experience shortages of capital and liquidity or if they experience excessive volumes of borrowing requests within a short period of time.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S6	In addition, tight lending practices may make it difficult for our real estate developers to obtain financing under acceptable loan terms and conditions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P9_S7	Unfavorable lending practices could impact the timing of our store openings and materially adversely affect our ability to open new stores in desirable locations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Longer term disruptions in the capital and credit markets as a result of uncertainty, changing or increased regulation, reduced funding alternatives, or failures of significant financial institutions could adversely affect our access to liquidity needed for our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Any disruption could require us to take measures to conserve cash until the markets stabilize or until alternative credit arrangements or other funding for our business needs can be arranged.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Such measures could include deferring capital expenditures and reducing or eliminating future share repurchases, cash dividends or other discretionary uses of cash.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Failure to open and manage new stores in the number and manner currently contemplated could adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	An integral part of our business strategy includes the expansion of our store base through new store openings.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	This expansion strategy is dependent on our ability to find suitable locations, and we face competition from many retailers for such sites.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P12_S2	If we are unable to implement this strategy, our ability to increase our sales, profitability, and cash flow could be impaired significantly.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P12_S3	To the extent that we are unable to open new stores in the manner we anticipate (due to, among other reasons, site approval or unforeseen delays in construction), our sales growth may be impeded.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	As we execute this expansion strategy, we may also experience managerial or operational challenges which may prevent any expected increase in sales, profitability or cash flow.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our ability to manage our planned expansion depends on the adequacy of our existing information systems, the efficiency and expansion of our distribution systems, the adequacy of the hiring and training process for new personnel (especially store managers), the effectiveness of our controls and procedures, and the ability to identify customer demand and build market awareness in different geographic areas.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	There can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve our planned expansion, that the new stores will be effectively integrated into our existing operations or that such stores will be profitable.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Although we have a rigorous real estate site selection and approval process, there can be no assurance that our new store openings will be successful or result in incremental sales and profitability for the Company.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	New stores build their sales volumes and refine their merchandise selection over time and, as a result, generally have lower gross margins and higher operating expenses as a percentage of net sales than our more mature stores.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	As we continue to open new stores, there may be a negative impact on our results from a lower contribution margin of these new stores until their sales levels ramp to chain average, if at all, as well as from the impact of related pre-opening costs.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our failure to attract and retain qualified team members, increases in wage and labor costs and changes in laws and other labor issues could adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Our ability to continue expanding operations depends on our ability to attract and retain a large and growing number of qualified team members.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Our ability to meet labor needs while controlling wage and related labor costs is subject to numerous external factors, including the availability of a sufficient number of qualified persons in the work force, unemployment levels, prevailing wage rates, changing demographics, health and other insurance costs, changes in employment legislation and the potential for changes in local labor practices or union activities.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P15_S3	If we are unable to locate, attract or retain qualified personnel, or if costs of labor or related costs increase significantly, our financial performance could be adversely affected.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We are subject to federal, state, and local laws governing employment practices and working conditions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	These laws cover wage and hour practices, labor relations, paid and family leave, workplace safety and immigration, among others.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P16_S2	The laws and regulations being passed at the state and local level create unique challenges for a multi-state employer.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P16_S3	We must continue to monitor and adapt our employment practices to comply with these various laws and regulations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P16_S4	If our costs of labor or related costs increase significantly as new or revised labor laws, rules or regulations or healthcare laws are adopted or implemented, our financial performance could be adversely affected.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We may pursue strategic acquisitions and the failure of an acquisition to produce the anticipated results or the inability to fully integrate the acquired companies could have an adverse impact on our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We may, from time to time, acquire businesses we believe to be complementary to our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The success of an acquisition is based on our ability to make accurate assumptions regarding the valuation, operations, growth potential, integration and other factors relating to the target business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Acquisitions may result in difficulties in assimilating acquired companies and may result in the diversion of our capital and our management s attention from other business issues and opportunities.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S3	We may not be able to successfully integrate an organization that we acquire, including their personnel, financial systems, distribution, operations and general operating procedures.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S4	If we fail to successfully integrate acquisitions, we could experience increased costs associated with operating inefficiencies which could have an adverse effect on our financial results.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Also, while we employ several different methodologies to assess potential business opportunities, the new businesses may not meet our expectations and, therefore, adversely affect our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Competition may hinder our ability to execute our business strategy and adversely affect our operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	We operate in the highly competitive retail merchandise sector with numerous competitors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S2	These competitors include general merchandise retailers, home center retailers, specialty and discount retailers, independently owned retail farm and ranch stores, numerous privately-held regional farm store chains and farm cooperatives, as well as internet-based retailers.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S3	We compete for customers, merchandise, real estate locations, and employees.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S4	This competitive environment subjects us to various other risks, including the inability to continue our store and sales growth and to provide attractive merchandise to our customers at competitive prices that allow us to maintain our profitability.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Our failure to compete effectively in this environment could adversely impact our financial performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We face risks associated with vendors from whom our products are sourced.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	The products we sell are sourced from a variety of domestic and international vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S2	We have agreements with our vendors in which the vendors agree to comply with applicable laws, including labor and environmental laws, and to indemnify us against certain liabilities and costs.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Our ability to recover liabilities and costs under these vendor agreements is dependent upon the financial condition and integrity of the vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S4	We rely on long-term relationships with our suppliers but have no long-term contracts with such suppliers.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S5	Our future success will depend in large measure upon our ability to maintain our existing supplier relationships or to develop new ones.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S6	This reliance exposes us to the risk of inadequate and untimely supplies of various products due to political, economic, social, or environmental conditions, transportation delays, or changes in laws and regulations affecting distribution.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P20_S7	Our vendors may be forced to reduce their production, shut down their operations or file for bankruptcy protection, which could make it difficult for us to serve the market s needs and could have a material adverse effect on our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	While the Company selects these third-party vendors carefully, it does not control their actions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Any problems caused by these third parties, including those resulting from breakdowns or other disruptions in communication services provided by a vendor, failure of a vendor to handle current or higher volumes, and cyber attacks or security breaches at a vendor could adversely affect the Company s ability to deliver products and services to its customers and otherwise conduct its business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We rely on foreign manufacturers for various products that we sell.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P22_S1	In addition, many of our domestic suppliers purchase a portion of their products from foreign sources.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P22_S2	As an importer, our business is subject to the risks generally associated with doing business internationally, such as domestic and foreign governmental regulations, economic disruptions, delays in shipments, transportation capacity and costs, currency exchange rates and changes in political or economic conditions in countries from which we purchase products.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	U.S. quotas, duties, taxes or other charges or restrictions were imposed upon the importation of our products in the future, our financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The current political landscape in the U.S. has introduced greater uncertainty with respect to tax and trade policies, tariffs and regulations affecting trade between the U.S. and other countries.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	We source a portion of our merchandise from manufacturers located outside the U.S., primarily in Asia and Central America.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Major developments in tax policy or trade relations, such as the disallowance of tax deductions for imported merchandise or the imposition of tariffs on imported products, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and liquidity.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	A significant disruption to our distribution network or to the timely receipt of inventory could adversely impact sales or increase our transportation costs, which would decrease our profits.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We rely on our distribution and transportation network to provide goods to our stores in a timely and cost-effective manner through deliveries to our distribution facilities from vendors and then from the distribution facilities or direct ship vendors to our stores by various means of transportation, including shipments by sea, air, rail and truck.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Any disruption, unanticipated expense or operational failure related to this process could affect store operations negatively.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S3	For example, unexpected delivery delays (including delays due to weather, fuel shortages or other reasons) or increases in transportation costs (including increased fuel costs or a decrease in transportation capacity for overseas shipments) could significantly decrease our ability to provide adequate product for sale, or products at a desired price, resulting in lower sales and profitability.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S4	In addition, labor shortages or work stoppages in the transportation industry or long-term disruptions to the national and international transportation infrastructure that lead to delays or interruptions of deliveries could negatively affect our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P26_S5	Also, a fire, tornado, or other disaster at one of our distribution facilities could disrupt our timely receiving, processing and shipment of merchandise to our stores which could adversely affect our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The implementation of our supply chain initiatives could disrupt our operations in the near term, and these initiatives might not provide the anticipated benefits or might fail.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We maintain a network of distribution facilities and have plans to build new facilities and expand existing facilities to support our growth objectives.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Delays in opening new or expanded distribution facilities could adversely affect our future operations by slowing store growth, which may in turn reduce revenue growth.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P27_S3	In addition, distribution-related construction or expansion projects entail risks which could cause delays and cost overruns, such as: shortages of materials; shortages of skilled labor or work stoppages; unforeseen construction, scheduling, engineering, environmental or geological problems; weather interference; fires or other casualty losses; and unanticipated cost increases.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The completion date and ultimate cost of future projects could differ significantly from initial expectations due to construction-related or other reasons.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P28_S1	We cannot guarantee that all projects will be completed on time or within established budgets.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We continue to make significant technology investments in our supply chain.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P29_S1	These initiatives are designed to streamline our distribution process so that we can optimize the delivery of goods and services to our stores and distribution facilities in a timely manner and at a reasonable cost.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The cost and potential problems and interruptions associated with the implementation of these initiatives, including those associated with managing third-party service providers and employing new web-based tools and services, could disrupt or reduce the efficiency of our operations in the near term.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P29_S3	In addition, our improved supply chain technology might not provide the anticipated benefits, it might take longer than expected to realize the anticipated benefits, or the initiatives might fail altogether.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We are subject to personal injury, workers compensation, product liability, discrimination, harassment, wrongful termination and other claims in the ordinary course of business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our business involves a risk of personal injury, workers compensation, product liability, discrimination, harassment, wrongful termination and other claims in the ordinary course of business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Product liability claims from customers and product recalls for merchandise alleged to be defective or harmful could lead to the disposal or write-off of merchandise inventories, the incurrence of fines or penalties and damage to our reputation.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We maintain general liability and workers compensation insurance with a self-insured retention for each policy type and a deductible for each occurrence.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P32_S1	We also maintain umbrella limits above the primary general liability and product liability coverage.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P32_S2	In many cases, we have indemnification rights against the manufacturers of the products and their products liability insurance as well as the property owners of our leased buildings.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P32_S3	Our ability to recover costs and damages under such insurance or indemnification arrangements is subject to the financial viability of the insurers, manufacturers and landlords and the specific allegations of a claim.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P32_S4	No assurance can be given that our insurance coverage or the manufacturers or landlords indemnity will be available or sufficient in any claims brought against us.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Compliance with these laws, including the remediation of any alleged violation, may have a material adverse effect on our business or results of operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Failure to maintain an effective system of internal control over financial reporting could materially impact our business and results.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P35_S1	An internal control system, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P35_S2	Further, the design of a control system must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Because of the inherent limitations in all internal control systems, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Any failure to maintain an effective system of internal control over financial reporting could limit our ability to report our financial results accurately and timely or to detect and prevent fraud, and could expose us to litigation or adversely affect the market price of our common stock.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Any failure to maintain the security of the information relating to our business, customers, employees and vendors that we hold, whether as a result of cybersecurity attacks or otherwise, could damage our reputation with customers, employees and vendors, could cause us to incur substantial additional costs and to become subject to litigation, and could adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We receive certain personal and other confidential information about our customers, employees and vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S1	We also rely on business partners to provide services to us that may include important business information or data about our customers, employees and vendors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S2	In addition, our online operations at TractorSupply.com and Petsense.com depend upon the secure transmission of confidential information over public networks, including information permitting cashless payments.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S3	While we maintain substantial security measures to help protect and prevent unauthorized access to such information, it is possible that unauthorized parties (through cybersecurity attacks, which are rapidly evolving and becoming increasingly sophisticated, or by other means) might compromise our security measures and obtain and misuse the personal information of customers, employees and vendors that we hold or other confidential Company data.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S4	It is possible that such a compromise could go undetected by us.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S5	Such an occurrence could materially adversely affect our reputation with our customers, employees, and vendors, as well as our operations, results of operations, financial condition and liquidity, and could result in significant legal and financial exposure beyond the scope or limits of insurance coverage.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P38_S6	Moreover, a security breach could require that we expend significant additional resources to respond to the breach and could result in a disruption of our operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P39_S0	In addition, states and the federal government are increasingly enacting laws and regulations relating to data breaches and theft of employee and customer data.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P39_S1	These laws will likely increase the costs of doing business and, if we fail to comply with these laws and regulations or to implement appropriate safeguards or to detect and provide prompt notice of unauthorized access as required by some of these new laws, we could be subject to potential claims for damages and other remedies, which could harm our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Our business and operations could suffer material losses in the event of system interruptions or failures.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Our information technology systems, some of which are dependent on services provided by third parties, serve an important role in the operation and administration of our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S2	These systems are vulnerable to damages from any number of sources, including, but not limited to, human error, cybersecurity attacks, computer viruses, unauthorized access, fire, flood, power outages, telecommunication failures, facility or equipment damage, natural disasters, terrorism, and war.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S3	In addition, we continually make investments in technology to implement new processes and systems as well as to maintain and update our existing processes and systems.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S4	Implementing process and system changes increases the risk of disruption.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S5	If our information technology systems are interrupted or fail and our redundant systems or recovery plans are not adequate to address such interruptions or failures on a timely basis, our revenues and profits could be reduced and the reputation of our brand and our business could be materially adversely affected.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P40_S6	Additionally, remediation of any problems with our systems could result in significant, unplanned expenses.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P41_S0	As customer-facing technology systems become an increasingly important part of our sales and marketing strategy, the failure of those systems to perform effectively and reliably could keep us from delivering positive customer experiences.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Through our continued information technology enhancements, we are able to provide an improved overall shopping environment and an omni-channel experience that empowers our customers to shop and interact with us from computers, tablets, smart phones and other mobile communication devices.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P41_S2	We use our website both as a sales channel for our products and also as a method of providing product, project and other relevant information to our customers to drive both in-store and online sales.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P41_S3	Omni-channel retailing is continually evolving and expanding, and we must effectively respond to changing customer expectations and new developments.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P41_S4	Disruptions, failures or other performance issues with these customer-facing technology systems could impair the benefits that they provide to our online and in-store business and negatively affect our relationship with our customers.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P42_S0	If we are unable to maintain or upgrade our management information systems and software programs or if we are unable to convert to alternate systems in an efficient and timely manner, our operations may be disrupted or become less efficient and our strategic business initiatives may not be successful.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We depend on management information systems for many aspects of our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P43_S1	We rely on certain software vendors to maintain and periodically upgrade many of these systems so that we can continue to support our business.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P43_S2	We could be materially adversely affected if we experienced a disruption or data loss relating to our management information systems and are unable to recover timely.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P43_S3	We could also be adversely impacted if we are unable to improve, upgrade, maintain and expand our management information systems, particularly in light of the contemplated continued store growth.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The success of our strategic business initiatives designed to increase our sales and improve margin is dependent in varying degrees on the timely delivery and the functionality of information technology systems to support them.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Extended delays or cost overruns in securing, developing and otherwise implementing technology solutions to support the strategic business initiatives would delay and possibly even prevent us from realizing the projected benefits of those initiatives.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We cannot provide any guaranty of future dividend payments or that we will continue to repurchase our common stock pursuant to our stock repurchase program.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Although our Board of Directors has indicated an intention to pay future quarterly cash dividends on our common stock, any determination to pay or increase cash dividends on our common stock in the future will be based primarily upon our financial condition, results of operations, business requirements, and our Board of Directors continuing determination that the declaration of dividends is in the best interests of our stockholders and is in compliance with all laws and agreements applicable to the dividend.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P45_S2	Furthermore, although our Board of Directors has authorized a share repurchase program of up to $3 billion through December 2020, we may discontinue this program at any time or significantly reduce repurchases under the program.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The market price for our common stock might be volatile and could result in a decline in value.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The price at which our common stock trades may be volatile and could be subject to significant fluctuations in response to our operating results, general trends and prospects for the retail industry, announcements by our competitors, analyst recommendations, our ability to meet or exceed analysts or investors expectations, the condition of the financial markets and other factors.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P47_S0	The Company s stock price is dependent in part on the multiple of earnings that investors are willing to pay.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P47_S1	That multiple is in part dependent on investors perception of the Company s future earnings growth prospects.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P47_S2	If investor perceptions of the Company s earnings growth prospects change, the Company s earnings multiple may decline and its stock price could be adversely affected.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P47_S3	In addition, the stock market in recent years has experienced extreme price and volume fluctuations that often have been unrelated or disproportionate to the operating performance of companies.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P47_S4	These fluctuations, as well as general economic and market conditions, may adversely affect the market price of our common stock notwithstanding our actual operating performance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our costs of doing business could increase as a result of federal, state, local or foreign laws and regulations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P48_S1	We are subject to numerous federal, state, local and foreign laws and governmental regulations including those relating to environmental protection, personal injury, intellectual property, consumer product safety, building, land use and zoning requirements, workplace regulations, wage and hour, privacy and information security and employment law matters.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P48_S2	If we fail to comply with existing or future laws or regulations, or if these laws or regulations are violated by importers, manufacturers or distributors, we may be subject to governmental or judicial fines or sanctions, while incurring substantial legal fees and costs.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P48_S3	In addition, our capital expenditures could increase due to remediation measures that may be required if we are found to be noncompliant with any existing or future laws or regulations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P49_S0	We are also subject to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (the FCPA ), which prohibits U.S. companies and their intermediaries from making improper payments to foreign officials for the purposes of obtaining or retaining business, and the anti-bribery laws of other jurisdictions.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Failure to comply with the FCPA and similar laws could subject us to, among other things, penalties and legal expenses that could harm our reputation and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Potential noncompliance with environmental regulations could materially impact our results of operations or financial condition.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P50_S1	Our business is subject to various federal, state and local laws, regulations and other requirements pertaining to protection of the environment and public health, including, for example, regulations governing the management of waste materials and waste waters.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P50_S2	Governmental agencies on the federal, state and local levels have, in recent years, increasingly focused on the retail sector s compliance with such laws and regulations, and have at times pursued enforcement activities.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P50_S3	We periodically receive information requests and notices of potential noncompliance with environmental laws and regulations from governmental agencies, which are addressed on a case-by-case basis with the relevant agency.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P50_S4	Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations or financial condition.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Effective tax rate changes and results of examinations by taxing authorities could materially impact our results.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Our future effective tax rates could be adversely affected by legislative tax reform, changes in statutory rates or changes in tax laws, or interpretations thereof.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P51_S2	Additionally, our future effective tax rates could be adversely affected by the earnings mix being lower than historical results in states where we have lower statutory rates and higher than historical results in states where we have higher statutory rates or by changes in the measurement of our deferred tax assets and liabilities.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P52_S0	We are subject to periodic audits and examinations by the Internal Revenue Service ( IRS ), as well as state and local taxing authorities.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Like many retailers, a portion of our sales are to tax-exempt customers.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P52_S2	The business activities of our customers and the intended use of the unique products sold by us create a challenging and complex compliance environment.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P52_S3	These circumstances create risk that we could be challenged as to the propriety of our sales tax compliance.
916365_18_ITEM1A_P52_S4	Our results could be materially impacted by the determinations and expenses related to these and other proceedings by the IRS and other state and local taxing authorities.
916365_18_ITEM2_P0_S0	At December 30, 2017 , the Company operated 1,853 stores in 49 states.
916365_18_ITEM2_P0_S1	The Company leases approximately 93% of its stores.
916365_18_ITEM2_P0_S2	Store leases typically have initial terms of 10 to 15 years, with two to four renewal periods of five years each, exercisable at our option.
916365_18_ITEM2_P0_S3	No single lease is material to Company operations.
